Keeping it short and sweet: great appropriated warehouse space converted to a coffee/cafe spot. The havana latte is great, as is the tomato soup.

Great little couches and tables-- definitely conducive to conversation.

How amazing to find a gem of a caffeine space that has indoor, outdoor and parking space!
author: C. P.

description:
I work nearby and love going to this cafe for my morning latte. The decor is awesome, and it's a real nice space. The pastries are pretty good, but the lattes are amazing. Sometimes I think the food is a little overpriced, but I just avoid those items.
Friendly baristas!
author: Allie D.

description:
Three stars for the eats and drinks. Regardless of the food, this is an awesome place to chill.

When I walked into this joint, I saw so many Apple laptops/iPads/iPhones I thought I had walked into an Apple store. This must be the secret lair of  Apple fanboys and SF start-ups. The space is large and airy with free wi-fi available. Convenient for checking FB on your laptop while pretending to look important and busy with lots of innovative dot-com ideas.

They run out of certain foods towards the end of the night, so be aware. I ordered a portabella sandwich on foccacia and ended up with a turkey club on a baguette. Decent sandwich, $1 overpriced.
author: Kel S.

description: Coffee bar is a great little lunch spot in the Somisspo area. While parking and seating can be a challenge, Coffee Bar saves some seats for diners by placing signage to notify laptop users that the tables are for lunch customers (no laptops) only (during lunch hours). You'll find a lot of people working remotely from Coffee Bar and a great selection of espresso beverages. There are salads, sandwiches, soups, and pastries on a daily basis. A very nice place for a pleasant lunch. Check out the outdoor seating if the weather is nice.
author: Krysta G.

description:
My favorite working cafe!

-Pretty good food and drink selection.

-Boosting environment! If you don't feel like working or studying, this is the place to pump you up! Almost all the people there are on their books or laptops.

-Very friendly staff.

-Patio is great if the weather is nice.

-There are plenty of parking spots around and there is no time limitation. 

Would definitely recommend this place.
author: Azi Z.

description:
Do you own a Mac? 

I don't know exactly when this change happened but this excellent coffee shop has turned into the office away from the office. On any given day you can wander in here and see coffee shop chicks and dudes hammering away on their Macs(yup like 99% Macs).  Definitely a place to be seen unless you are me. I dig the coffee and the vibe is lofty mission hipster goodness.     

Check it out!
author: Joseph M.

description: This is my new mobile office.  Free wi-fi, great coffee and salads, plus all the fellow Mac users scattered all around.  Who could ask for more?  :)
author: Kristen S.

description:
Ok, I'm not a hipster. I'm not someone pretending to be cooler than I am. I'm just a simple nerdy asian guy looking for a nice hip place to study with decent caffeinated drinks and snacks! That being said, I do feel significantly cooler when i study here. =x 

Interesting table layout - mixture of small tables, long cafeteria type tables, and also bar type seating. There are abundant plugs, relatively well lit, comfortable! Yesterday I walked in and I literally saw walls of lighted apples facing me. I had mixed feelings. It was actually too crowded so I had to go to the starbucks across the street! bah!

Now... as far as the drinks go... I love their latte's. Esp bec they come in those huge white cups with fun designs made in the foam =) 
ALSO LOVE their vietnamese iced coffee and havana iced coffee on a"warm" sunny mission neighborhood day ... bliss! 

...omg and the bart station map in the bathroom... i dont know why but i love it! haha
author: Tim B.

description:
Maple Bacon Scone! 
The coffee here is so creamy you don't need to add milk.
Super friendly energy on the little terrace out front.
An OASIS.
author: Junie C.

description:
I was planning to give Coffee Bar 3.5 and round it up to 4, but now they've achieved the solid 4 stars. Minus one because it's just always busy-- even if you place an order for pickup, you have to wait a good chunk of time to ring up and get out of there. Since I always run here on very limited breaks from work, I need it to move just a *little* faster.

Anyway. I've never had a sandwich, salad, pastry, or beverage here that I didn't love. They've got creative and delicious menu options, and while they're a little pricey for an everyday thing, a Coffee Bar lunch is a good biweekly treat for me.  It's also really great for settling in for a day of work, with plenty of space and outlets all around.

So why originally only 3.5 stars? Because of two things: I called around 5 pm a few weeks ago to order a salad, and was told that they didn't have the lunch menu anymore that day, and they'd moved on to the tapas menu. And I really wanted the salad. More importantly, their website said nothing about a tapas menu, or about the salad/sandwich menu ending at any point of the day. Then the next week I called for a sandwich and was told that that sandwich was no longer on their regular menu. I picked another sandwich off the website menu, and THAT wasn't available either. Grrrr.

BUT. Today I checked the website to see what I might want for lunch, and it's updated! Tapas menu, new lunch menu, hours of availability for each-- WOW! Way to go, Coffee Bar. Just move the lines a little faster and it would be 5 stars.
author: LC H.

description: When you first walk in you feel like you're the odd one out if you don't have a macbook ready to open.  The way the inside counters are set up on the upper floor makes you feel like everyone is looking down at you while you order.  The only not overpriced thing to eat here are the pre-made sandwiches, either that or I'm cheap.  If you're not a yuppie or hipster with a macbook and headphones on, get your food or drink and sit outside.  The staff is nice and the drinks are great, though.
author: Durty D.

description:
I never, ever go into coffee shops because I'm generally against the whole sit-around-and-do-nothing-on-your-laptop culture, but this place is pretty sweet. I think I caught it on a good day, too. The outdoor area was gleaming in the sun, and the inside was cozy without being overheated. Plus there's this mesmerizing light fixture thing on the second floor that I couldn't stop staring at. 

I had a jasmine green tea, which kept me awake until about 3 a.m., so at least we know it worked. I also indulged in an orange-ginger Dynamo Donut, and I can understand from its light, fluffy texture that all the hype was worth it. When I find myself in this incredibly tranquil little patch of San Francisco again, I'm coming back here for a treat. Sans laptop.
author: Stefanie L.

description:
Dear friends in SF -

Want me to cross the bridge for a meeting. Host it here.

I LOVE. this place. I wish I lived closer. Yummy sandwiches and soup. Good coffee. Great vibe. Sure, seats are hard to find, but people are friendly and willing to share the larger tables. 

So who wants to have a meeting with me here?
author: Gracie B.

description:
I haven't been by there yet but Jason P., if you're reading this, CONGRATULATIONS!  

Update (1/26):  I finally found the Coffee Bar.  I kept looking for it on Bryant but you can't see it from Bryant.  It's very close to the Starbucks - look for it on Florida.  I'm bummed that Jason wasn't there that day.

Coffee Bar is fantastic - it is sophisticated without being pretentious.  Imagine having a cocktail party at your friend's loft.  The place is understated and modern but still inviting. There are leather couches in one corner, wooden tables with wooden benches, and counters to sit at.  

The lattes are strong and smooth ($3.25 for a 16 oz. latte).  Croissants are provided by Patisserie Philippe and other bakery items come from Jasmine Rae.  They toast your pastries which is a very nice touch.  The chocolate croissant is good but doesn't have much chocolate.  They also offer fruit bowls, granola, toast, salads, sandwiches.  Then there's the "bar" part of the Coffee Bar name; they serve beer, wine, champagne and little plates of olives, baked artichoke stems, cheese, etc.  Very cool.  

Free secure wi-fi.  Tasteful bathroom.  Coffee + wine + top notch treats = brilliant.
author: Lolia S.

description: This place has great coffee and a great vibe. You can practically feel the startups starting up.
author: Krishan G.

description: Good quality coffee/tea place though the tables were 95% packed with wifi sucking computer users.  This place feels like it's a virtual office for about 20 people.
author: H. H.

description:
My girlfriend refuses to go back because of the "attitude" of the staff.  She was violating one of their many rules about who sits where, or something. 

The pastry is good, the coffee is nothing special, and they do not know how to make Vietnamese coffee although they have it on the menu. And yes, I find the staff kind of snobby although the place is very attractive.  It's the sort of clean cut folks on fancy bicycle type of place that some people like.
author: Paul M.

description:
Service: Good service, the staff is nice. 

Cleanliness: The place is clean, tables are cleaned fairly quickly. The bathroom is clean which is big plus for me. 

Food/Coffee: Not that big of a coffee person, but there's a good variety of other options for me. My favorite item here is their breakfast burrito. Very good. The only down side is that there is a bit of a wait for them to make it, but it's worth the wait. It's a good bang for the buck. 

An upscale version of Starbucks with lots of people working. The breakfast burrito is very good and the place is clean. 

Parking: Free public parking, it might be a challenging to find parking during weekdays.
author: Steven Z.

description: It's cute and they have a nice seating area outside, but it's tough to find a place to sit. Everyone lingers for hours. I ordered an iced tea and asked if they bring it to the table. They said it's just done on the spot and to wait by the register. It took almost 15 minutes to get my iced tea and I had to inquire on it twice. No, it was not especially busy either.
author: Natasha F.

description:
God I LOVE this space. So much sunlight filling up the sprawling floor up to the ceiling far above. It's clean and airy and the tone is a quietly diligent tech geek buzz, broken occasionally by a nasally voice boasting about this or that new deal or other schmoozing. While these folks are friendlier than most SF coffee drinkers, often starting inquisitive conversations with strangers, it is the best place I've found to get work done. (And who doesn't mind the odd chit chat break?)

The FOH has never been cafe-snobby and make tasty drinks while the kitchen offers up truly yummy, bright, and healthy sandwiches, salads, and soups. Sadly, there's only one bathroom and sometimes Coffee Bar is so crowded it's tough to get a table (even outside), let alone into the throne room.
author: Stella S.

description:
Inside, most people are doing work and it's contagious. Easy to concentrate here. Outside is often sunny and a good spot to chat with friends.

Good tea, decent prices. The ambiance is SF tech, a great place check out.
author: Phillip W.

description:
Great space, open, hight ceilings, lots of tables and free wifi.

Great coffee / espresso drinks. Their egg sandwich is really tasty.. I forget the exact name, but basically has a fried egg inside it!
author: Sumit C.

description:
My girlfriend used to play soccer at Franklin square on the weekends and we'd usually go to Home Depot or IKEA right after at that point in our lives. So, I'd head down to that area with her and sometimes grab a coffee and some wifi while she played.

Speaking of wifi, this is the most wifi place ever. So much so there are tables where you're not allowed to use laptops! Pretty funny.

The coffee is good and I remember it blowing my head off, so I usually stuck with smaller ones. Good cappuccino, I recall.

It really does the job, gets pretty busy and is kind of expensive coffee but worth it if you manage to get a good seat. I'd probably make it 'I'm a fan' and 4 stars if I went more often and they learned what I ordered or something like that.
author: Spencer H.

description:
This is the number 1 coffee shop in SF.  Not only is the coffee divine, but the ambience is conducive to getting large amounts of work done in one sitting.  They have free wifi, ample seating, and a hordes of hackers and students that come to spend hours in front of their tablets and Macbooks. 

On a hot day, I highly recommend getting an iced coffee and one of their healthy, delicious lunch specials and sitting on the porch with some friends.
author: Anneliese N.

description:
You are in a warehouse.  A very modern one, with daylight pouring in through the massive, delivery-truck-sized windows.  The ceilings are way, way higher than I could jump and touch.  This place could double as an awesome club/lounge if they felt like it.

The coffee is tasty, the tea is pretentious but not at expense of the price.  The baristas are friendly, and the vibe is chill.  They import Dynamo Donuts but hike the price up (gas prices, I'm sure).  I've never tried their food.  I can forgive the sluggish wireless, given I am surrounded by hundreds of transfixed Macbook users currently logged in.  (It can be crowded.)  Still, one of my mission favorites for sure.
author: Chris H.

description:
If you didn't use such hot water with the coffee it would taste WAY better and not taste burnt (sometimes).

Thanks!
author: John A.

description:
Why I like Coffee Bar:
1. Great lattes. Never bitter, always smooth, usually with heart shaped foamy thing on top.
2. Tuna melt sandwich with tomatoes. I order this for lunch at least once every week or two. It is the best.
3. Fresh squeezed orange juice
4. Steel cut oatmeal with cranberries and brown sugar for breakfast - soooo good!
5. The staff are always super nice. Only once did they accidentally give my to go order to someone else. One out of a hundred isn't bad. Did I mention how nice they are?
6. Only two blocks from my office makes for a great mid-morning or mid-day getaway.

Why you might like it too:
1. Patio is right on the corner but feels secluded from the neighborhood (which isn't that busy to begin with, but it's nice to sit in the sun, next to some large succulents instead of looking at the trash bins waiting to be picked up).
2. Mac laptops always outnumber PC laptops by at least 6 to 1.

Why I don't like it:
1. Lunch lines can get really long. I mean really really long. So long that I think about getting a Tonayense taco truck taco to hold me over while waiting to order and receive my tuna sammy.
author: jennie p.

description:
This place could be really great, but for the ambient groove on the overhead speakers competing for the attention of my left ear with the mariachi music blaring out from the kitchen.  I feel like my brain is going to explode from the cacophony. Pity, because the coffee is great, the place has a spacious, hip vibe, there is FREE wi-fi, and there is plenty of room to work. 

I don't think I can come back and bear another assault on my eardrums.
author: Michele W.

description:
Seriously, I'm falling in love with this place. The atmosphere, the coffee, the people. Wireless access, wine and beer, a very cool Clover coffee extraction machine... I think this is going to be a daily addiction.

Big bonuses: wheelchair accessible

Times visited: 5+
author: Amy L.

description:
Pretty much the best daytime hangout in the Mission.  I've been there every other day for two months, no joke, and I never grow tired of it.  The two-story windows gently flood the space with natural light.  Lots of outlets for laptops, enough even for the lunch rush.  The bar-style seating on the second floor is comfortable for long stretches of work, and I can watch the crowd drift in and out while I'm at it.  Attracts a decent clientele.  Most of the regulars have a better command of personal hygiene and friendliness than the folks who flock to the other Mission cafes I explored before succumbing to my Coffee Bar addiction.   I've met cool and ambitious people from all over the world just by chillin' with a smile.  

Food is reasonably priced with consistent quality.  Lots of healthy options.  While the menu items don't offer much excitement, some of the baked goods are great - the almond croissant in particular is a delightful, layered mess.   

The coffee didn't wow me at first, yet that might have more to do with missin' the aroma of my usual cafe back in DC rather than anything lacking in the quality.  And lately I find myself swinging by for a cup to go whenever I need to work at my studio a couple blocks away.  

Oh, and the staff is awesome.  Easy conversation to be had while you place your order, if you like.
author: Djuna W.

description: This is my favorite place to go on a Saturday/Sunday Morning to grab a carmel latte and breakfast and work on homework. They play great music in the background as well as amazing coffee/food!
author: Katrina W.

description:
I love the architecture of this place and that's the only reason I go back  there again and again. 
I don't like the atmosphere because every one is working, which is good if it's in the middle of the week and you also want to have your laptop with and work. But I don't like this atmosphere on weekend because I would rather take a break and talk to my friends. But hipsters are sitting so seriously at the their lap tops on weekend as if they have the most important jobs in the world and you can't talk and laugh without feeling guilty.;-) I would like to go back to this place when it's not so crowded with young important kids.:-)

Coffee and snacks are ok but not great. In sunny days you can sit outside and enjoy the nice weather.
author: Visda G.

description:
I had an amazing Fresh Mozzarella sandwich with sun-dried tomato and pesto.  Yum!

My friend said the coffee was really good so I'll be sure to go back with my laptop and lounge for a while.  

Free Wifi!!

The decor is clean and modern.  I would love to come here for a private party!
author: Lauren C.

description:
Came in here for the donuts surprised by how incredible quiet and packed this place is. Downstairs you'd think it's empty, walk up the stairs, every seat it taken!! 

I'm happy they had donuts, the worker at Dynamo donuts said they sell their donuts (Dynamo was out!). The coffee bar only had two choices :( chocolate star anise & vanilla bean. I like the vanilla bean.

This place seems to have alot of options cookie/sandwich/coffee/wine/water etc-wise. Pleasent workers and accessable parking.
author: Christina C.

description:
FOOD/DRINK:
1.) "Big Daddy IPA" beer = but good lord! It's a coffee house that has beer! :D They also have lunch food, and wine!
2.) Hot sandwich = I forget what it was called but it was the one with avocado. It was alright, nothing amazing, but nothing bad. 
3.) Cold sandwich = Yeah I forget again, but it has some kind of white soft cheese and this minty tasting greenery. It was good, but again, nothing amazing. Just basic.


SERVICE:
Very down to earth nice people :)



ATMOSPHERE:
Kind of an industrial feel with the cement floors and stainless steel paneling. Chill background music, filled with cool peoples on their laptops, occasional artwork on the white walls. Btw, FREE WIFI, always a plus.
author: Angela L.

description:
This place is great- good coffee, good breakfast (how do they make oatmeal taste so good?!) and lots of space.  I love the decor.

A few issue I have with it though. The address is not the actual site so it can confusing to find the first time (just around the corner). It's a little intimidating if you're not a regular, which I'm not. The employees are not particularly warm or welcoming and the patrons are either sitting there with their macs or ipads, staring up at you when you walk by without giving a friendly smile, or sitting in little hip groups together that make you feel like you're an outsider- which like me, you likely are. 

If it was friendlier, I'd probably come more often even though its not in my neighborhood.
author: Inna L.

description:
What I like about this place is the outside patio -- during the sunny times this is an awesome area to hang out, read, or just enjoy the coffee. I usually get the Havana Latte which is delicious -- the shape of the leaf drawn on the cream says it all. 


The indoor area is good for work, but remember you gotta have a mac :)
author: Betim D.

description:
"Oh my god, it's full of macbooks!"

.... aside from that, it's a pretty nice place to work, read, meet, fix a bicycle, or have a coffee or beer.

And for some reason it turns into a restaurant after 6pm - oh well.
author: Max R.

description:
I was very, very outnumbered. There were 40 or so of you, typing away on your iPads, iPhones, iMacs, iWhatever. Then there was me, reading the Sunday Chronicle in the oldest school way possible - actually reading a hard copy version. I felt like an outcast. But you didn't stare. Thanks.

Regardless of information consumption method, no doubt we were all loving the gorgeous space, the amazing coffee, and the nourishing eats. Wish I could remember the blend, it was awesome, and the medley of fresh fruit in my parfait was a perfect afternoon snack.

When the tour of all restaurants (and coffee shops) in the city comes to an end, I'll be back here often. Paper, or laptop, in hand.
author: Jason B.

description:
Havana Latte - Surprisingly Good.

Sandwiches - Good but not filling

Salads - I don't know. I don't order salads. 

Try them if you're in the neighborhood, and don't want Starbucks or Peets.
author: Clinton L.

description: Coffeebar is a good place to come to get work done (free WiFi and lots of outlets) and get good food.  They are sticklers about their menu times however.  We were told they could not serve us granola and yogurt at 11:03am because the breakfast menu ended at 11:00am.
author: Garth W.

description:
My new favorite coffee place. I don't even drink coffee but this place has it all for the mobile professional: good food, free wireless and large tables to lay your stuff out on. 

The building is a large loft-like space. It's what my dream house would look like. I had a hot chocolate and a ham and cheese croissant which were cheap and much better than a lot of the things I have paid a lot more money for at other places in SF.

No joke - I am going to schedule my work meetings here.
author: Carlos A.

description:
Loved the garden patio and red patio furniture.  

Simple circular sign outside "COFFEE BAR"

good looking men abound

simple menu written on rolls of butcher paper. 

breakfast items

drip coffee.  good drip coffee.  EXCELLENT drip coffee.  I should've purchased the 16oz for $2 instead of the 8oz for $1.50, but I am trying to cut back.  but GREAT COFFEE.

I saw a wall of 4505 Meats Chicharrones.  I purchased the entire wall.  9 bags. can you say addict?  (Though they do charge a little more here than if you purchase these at the Ferry Building direct from supplier)

the restroom has a huge map of the BART system above the toilet (HECKA USEFUL).

free wifi

delicious almond croissant (had hints of rose water...ohhh it was DIVINE)

comfy couch.  

so comfy, I just farted into it.

great morning.

=8)
author: Grace M.

description:
I LOVE the Cobb Salad. It was well prepared-- grilled and seasoned chicken, bits of bacon, intricately cut hard boiled egg, cherry tomatoes, generous amount of avocado, and cheese. 

In addition, this place is spacious and simplistic. I like the upstairs area and large windows. I find this place comforting.
author: Kissy F.

description:
Hands down. My FAVORITE coffee shop. I love the big open space, all the delicious lunchy sandwich options, and OH.. they have Vietnamese and Havana iced coffee! whaaaa? :) 

Also a huge plus -- free wi-fi and plenty of electrical outlets to plug your laptop into. Every time I'm here, i sit for a few hours and am actually, REALLY productive. It's amazing. 

My favorite spot is along the bar on the second level, so I can peak down and watch the magic happen.. or see if any nerdy eye candy walks in. LOL.. i kid.. I'm working.. really!

Save me a spot will you? kisses. thx.
author: Tammy S.

description:
I've always seen this place walking around the area and finally got the cajones to go through the plant covered fence and order something. I got there on a hot day and everyone was looking for a spot indoors. The place is a nice and clean with plenty of tables and wooden benches to go around. Some of the tables are designated at certain times for people who are just there to eat and not hog the table with their laptops, updating their blogs every friggin' second, but that's only a select few. The majority of the crowd in there is pretty considerate and make it an enjoyable place to eat and catch up on your email. Other than that, the menu looked very appetizing. I was craving something cold so I got the tomato gazpacho with cucumber relish and a nice, cold iced tea to wash it down. My friend got their version of a grilled cheese sandwich with sundried tomatoes. I've got to say, they make a pretty mean grilled cheese sandwich.

Now I am glad that I decided to go see what was on the other side of the fence. It's not like Starbucks or Peets by any means. Coffee Bar is definitely a league of its own. It has become my new favorite spot.
author: Leslie K.

description:
5 stars = great coffee, good food although a little pricey for what you get
1 stars = staff - couldn't they be a little nicer or more efficient?  They only seem to be engaged when the manager's present.
author: Marissa W.

description: Single origin pour over, green juice, beautiful baked goods (even a gluten free option!).  What more could you ask for?
author: Katharyn W.

description: Love the coffee, love the pastries love the staff but the service is geological (hence three stars).  II have to wait so long 'm always worried about getting a ticket.   If you're not worried about waiting around it's a great place to hang but don't expect to be outta there with your coffee in under 10 minutes.
author: Nigel P.

description:
This has become my favorite cafe in the city.  I've gone during the weekdays and on weekends and it's always packed but I've been fortunate to always find seating.  Coffee is yummy and the lunch entrees are always good.  I'm never left unsatisfied with my orders.  The most recent dishes I've had are the tomato cream soup and portabello sandwich.  I highly recommend those.

The service is hit or miss.  Some guys are standoffish while others are pretty flirtatious...there's a particularly cute foreign barista so whenever he's around, you can expect great service with a friendly smile.
author: Karen N.

description:
Coffee Bar lights a flame that attracts all the hipster and web addicts in the vicinity.

Coffee Bar is generally packed. There aren't a lot of tables. I'd say it seats about sixty with an additional five to ten outside. There's counter seating, a couch, and a table with back wall seating. Even if you can find a seat, that doesn't mean you can use your laptop at it. Half of the area is reserved for laptops while the other is for non-laptop use. If you're a PC user prepare to get stares because you'll be the only one in here. I overheard a customer say "Is this place sponsored by Apple?"

The food is overpriced. The lunch items look like something I could throw together at home for a fraction of the price. The pastries are way overpriced. I tried their vanilla custard bun and it was borrring. I could literally count the amount of vanilla bean specks in the custard. They carry Dynamo Donuts but of course they push up the price even though they're located a few blocks away.

On the bright side the decor and music is nice. The ambient atmosphere makes it easy to get into a book or work yet still have a nice conversation. The noise isn't too loud although you might have something yell "We just made a website!"

_____

Great atmosphere and soundscape yet the prices, crowds, and pretentiousness are too thick for me. Nobody smiles here.
author: Michael H.

description:
#1 - the coffee is amazing
#2 - the food is fresh and delicious
#3 - there are lots of tables and even when it's crowded, you can find a space 
#4 - the music is never too loud or annoying
#5 - the people are great -- both the people who work there and the people who frequent it. 
#6 - everyone there is working or they're quiet. no annoying chatter-boxes with nothing to do
author: Meredith A.

description:
One of the coolest looking warehouse cafes I've ever been to... except for the emo music.

I like how un-snobby the employees are here.  Some really trendy coffee places tend to have people who just don't want to serve you but they are not at all like that here.  I got the 12 oz. Iced Mocha ($3.25) which was very rich, strong, and flavorful.  Lots of chocolate on the bottom.  An employee told my friend that they brew hot and cold drinks separately--I'm not sure how this makes a difference but it shows that they do know their stuff here.  They even have a clover coffee machine which is supposedly the next big coffee thing.

Oh! and I wouldn't recommend coming here on too hot of a day because there is no a/c and it gets really hot upstairs.
author: Shannon L.

description:
----------------------------
(10/12/10)  Currently my favorite place for a simple Nicoise salad.  I'm not a big fan of the citrus dressing; so I'm still looking for that perfect version. 

http://www.yelp.com/topic/san-francisco-nicoise-salad
----------------------------
(8/5/10) I'll up this to five from four stars now that I've got my ratings calibrated a bit.  Plus, it seems fair to compare places to others in town and not some kind of ideal. 

Even though there has been staff turn-over, they manage to produce consistently good espresso coffee without the long wait or attitude of some of the competition.  The limited lunch and breakfast menus contain tasty, good items.  Prices seem reasonable.

The place still looks quite nice.  The mid-day table situation seems to have improved with some spots now reserved for those eating during the lunch hour.   However, it still can be difficult to find a seat outside of those times (especially on a rainy day); there's still a problem with lingerers.
----------------------------

Really good coffee place.  

They make a proper cappuccino; I often find myself ordering a second when I'm there on a leisurely weekend morning.  Overall, very good espresso drinks.  The baristi (is that the proper plural?) seem to take pride in their work.  I've never ordered their filter coffee, but they do have a Clover machine (when it's not in the shop) and those are always fun to watch.

Good selection of beer and wine make this a nice choice for afternoon hang out as well.  Breakfast pastries and oatmeal are good, as are the sandwiches.  I've not tried the Radio Africa dinners.

The minimalist decor is handsome and the staff is friendly.  My minor quibble is with the preponderance of people working on laptops on weekdays (makes the atmosphere both crowded and a bit glum).  However, on nice days the small sunny patio is the perfect alternative.

Indoor can sometimes be too loud, especially on the afternoons when a dj is present (in my opinion, not a good idea with all the hard surfaces).  Again, the outdoor patio is a good escape.

The crowd is pretty mixed; it averages out to a slightly artsy 30 something.

Too many people come here to work.  Even on a Saturday afternoon, many people are sitting alone staring at a computer screen; this detracts from the ambiance.  Weekend mornings seem to have a lower contingent of workers.

A good addition to SF's cafe scene (which has greatly improved in the past 2 or 3 years).
author: Jice E.

description:
O hipsters how I do love some of your hang outs. The Coffee Bar is hipster central in what used to be a working class neighborhood just down the street from the Muni parking lot. Everyone's on a laptop and dressed to impress and there's plenty of industrial chic going on in the interior.

But I do have to say the food is awesome. I had a great cobb salad and the sandwiches people ordered were delicious served with a nice little side salad. If I'm ever down in Potrero Hill I could see myself going here again. They also have a bit of outdoor seating that I expect is mobbed when the sun is out.
author: Rebecca D.

description:
I haven't had the chance to get much from here, but I adore their chocolate walnut brownie. It is so gooey, and the top is just the right amount of crunchy, and it's dark and not too sweet. YUM! I used to crave these all the time when I worked nearby. Also delicious coffee, and always very friendly staff.

I love the feel of this place. It's got a very modern decor, and lots of windows, and plenty of seating. Doesn't mean it won't be packed when you get there though, so be prepared to wait for a table, or get there before the lunch crowd! (I'm assuming not everyone comes in for a brownie like I do, so the rest of their food / drink menu must be pretty awesome).  

Looking forward to an excuse to go back.
author: Roxane W.

description: The food and beverages are both exceptional. I had a caramel latte, which I could rank within some of the best coffee shops I've had thus far in the city. Great atmosphere with fun and interesting staff and customers, so great for people watching. You must be flexible with seating (upper level where the power adapters tends to be crowded), but if you like a great atmosphere and tasty delectable order a coffee and lunch and await to be amazed.
author: Henry W.

description:
I don't drink coffee but...wow. I was here on Saturday night for a friend's birthday party. I thought it odd that my Marina friends would want to host a party in my old hood, generally considered BFE to them, but I quickly discovered why. This place is AWESOME. For starters, the espresso is excellent. It was smoky, and rich, and sweet with hints of blueberry and fruit and a little bitter on the finish. Yes, I'm talking about espresso! 

The wine list was phenomenal and incredibly modestly priced.  Andrew, the sommelier, absolutely knows his stuff and was engaging and great to talk to. We didn't try anything on the tapas menu but it all looked delicious and we can't wait to go back and try it.  I'm also glad that Potrero is finally getting some of the credit it deserves for having cool/great places worth the trek across town, because as my neighborhood of three years, I'm sure my friends got tired of me talking about how under appreciated it was ad nauseum. My boyfriend did a double take when we saw a party bus rolling by outside and we realized what we should have when whole foods moved in: this isn't the sleepy little potrero of before.  

Also adorable was the little seating area outside with the potted cactus garden. The only thing though, is that the address says Bryant St. but I could have sworn the entrance was on Florida and Mariposa....
author: Dee I.

description: Interesting space, great coffee made as you like it (unlike an increasing number of boutique roasters), delicious food, really nice people.
author: Beth W.

description: The best coffee shop in the area! Try their Havana latte, it's soo good!
author: Magnus V.

description:
If I had the expendable cash to do so, I'd get coffee here every day. This is just about as good as it gets: delicious coffee, fun and vibrant ambiance, knowledgable and friendly baristas, and prices that are great for the quality of the experience.

I recommend the iced caramel latte: it's a great pick-me-up in the mid-afternoon, and a delicious sipper while enjoying their outdoor patio seating in the sun.
author: Joseph N.

description:
This place has very good coffee, great sandwiches, salads, and other simple dishes.

The main reason I keep coming back again and again, though, is the atmosphere. They nailed it. It's always busy, but not too crowded; there is always a spot to sit down with a friend or - most importantly for me - a place to sit down and do work on your laptop. Always lots of hacker and designer types. The cool decor in a converted warehouse, outdoor seating, and funky desert plants outside add to it as well.
author: A K.

description:
Their food is good and sometimes even delicious. It's a little pricey and 9 times out of 10 they screw up my order. It's pretty frustrating, but there aren't many choices in the neighborhood for lunch, so I keep going back. Sigh.

Tip: ALWAYS check your order before you leave if you are taking out.
author: Sharon G.

description:
The baristas here really take pride in their craft, which is what makes their coffees quite possibly the best I've had in SF and the country. I've seen them dump out unclaimed lattes on the counter only to remake it and place a fresh cup there again. The baristas will also sometimes choose to not fill the cappuccino cup to the brim lest it end up tasting more like a latte. It's the little things they take into consideration that make this place stand out from the rest. 

As for the extra details, they have it all--WiFi, outlets (unlike some other coffee shops in the Mission...*ahem* Ritual *cough* Four Barrel), seating, reserved seating for brunch (highly recommend their Breakfast Sando), and special events on the weekend evenings. I've yet to attend one of their game nights or guest chef nights, but it's another thing that differentiates this place from the others.
author: Vivian S.

description:
Coffee bar has some good and STRONG coffee.  Like it will leave you jittery all day coffee.  It's a cute place but there's almost never a seat indoors because it's always occupied with a tons of people on their macs.

The food is pretty good although pricey.  The only complaint I have is the service.  It's a hit or miss depending on who you get.  Sometimes they are really nice and fast and sometimes you will get a  too-cool- for school hipster dude who doesn't care that you've been waiting for your to go order for over 25 min.  

Overall, it's a nice place though and the outdoor patio and wifi is nice as well.
author: Nancy C.

description:
If I owned a coffeeshop, I would want it to be just like this: sleek, industrial, lots of air and light--a warehouse loft of a coffeeshop.   The music was jazzy and the crowd was neighborhoody, with an impressive collection of macbooks scattered across communal tables.  

The food and coffee qualify as very good--portions are smallish, but nice touches stand out, like the intricate leaf the espresso guy drew in my latte and the combo of fig jam and goat cheese.  

The only drawback was the disconcerting, intermittent BOOM, like an explosion down the block, that turned out to be the giant industrial door rattling the whole building as it closed.
author: Dana S.

description:
Love this place!  The soups are delicious.  The salads are really fresh.  My favorite sandwich is the shazam! The coffee bar only has it once a week but it's worth the wait!  Also the teas & coffees are the best in SF.  

They have plenty of outlets & free wifi if you need to take care of business.
author: Mikky T.

description:
In my original review for Coffee Bar I explained how disappointed I was with the owner's answer to whether the beans were fair trade and shade grown. In response he sent me this  message to clarify things:

--------
"Hi Jeremy, I'm the barista (owner) that you spoke with at Coffee Bar and my name is Luigi.  

I wish I hadn't glossed over the subject so quickly because it is very complicated as you know. We do in fact ensure (as Barefoot does) that the growing conditions are acceptable  with the farmers that we purchase our coffee from.   My brother is our Roastmaster and he travels to origin 3 to 4 times a year to visit farms that we've purchased from for years.

I've been in the specialty coffee business for 9 years and my brother for 30 years, we're both part of the family that owns Mr. Espresso in Oakland.  John (my brother) was one of the first green coffee buyers to bring in organic and fair trade certified coffees into the bay area on a consistent basis as early as 1999.

My point was simply that certifications aren't everything, but we still use them.  We judge the validity of a coffee based on specific set of circumstances within each country, because it varies, and in general, more responsible growing conditions produce better coffee.  The definition of "Responsible" growing conditions also varies from country to country.

I didn't mean to imply that ONLY responsible growing conditions produce good coffee.  

Sorry to confuse and I should have been more careful with my words.

Thank you for stopping in and we look forward to your next visit.

Luigi"
--------

Thank you Luigi, this clears things up and I really respect coffee businesses that have personal relationships with the bean growers.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
Delicious coffee, check

Sunny outdoor seating, check

Dynamo donuts, check

Delightful housemade pastries, check

Tasty salads and sandwiches, check.

Coffee Bar has it all.  It will really serve all your coffee needs.  Hungry?  They have great food.  Hot?  They have great iced coffee-- usually several options.  Too sober?  They have a great selection of beers.  One of my favorite places to start the weekend.
author: Kristin P.

description:
Grabbed an iced coffee and set up to take care of some business late afternoon on a Sunday. It was busy, but we found spots, and an outlet opened up quickly.

Iced coffee was perfectly strong and delicious. Music was excellent. Didn't find it too hipster-y, though there were definitely a ton of apple computers around, as other reviewers mentioned.

Definitely a solid place to hang out and stare at the computer screen.
author: Caitlin S.

description:
I FOUND YOU!!!  MY HUNT FOR MY COFFEE SHOP MATCH HAS ENDED!  (Well ok, I like you A LOT but I still need to see other coffee shops... Sorry, can't give up the forest for just one tree :)

Anyways, what makes Coffee Bar 5 Star worthy?  My rating for a perfect coffee shop follows:

1. Free Wi-Fi - has become a personal necessity.

2. Tables - there are a few big "community" tables and a "laptop" bar.  The laptop bar has outlets right underneath the table.  And yes, everyone sitting at the laptop bar and 95% of the patrons own a mac.  There is also a few outdoor tables - perfect for that one sunny day.  If you come alone, your bound to find a seat.  Not good for large groups as seating tends to be scattered.

3. Abundance of outlets - except for the community tables.

4. COFFEE - damn good coffee, nothing more to be said. Strong, robust, espressos. Lattes, perfectly concocted.

4a Baristas - Friendly, informative. 
4b (side story, feel free to skip) I ordered a small almond based cake, a "financier" and I pronounced it: fie-nan-see-er.  The friendly barista, said in a "careful not to embarrass the dumb American" tone, "oh it's a fie-nan-see-ay. It's called that because it's very affordable small french cake, and it's shaped like a gold bar."  Cooooool, learned something new.
4c. BONUS: they have wine and beer. WHAT?!  Yes, it's true... they doooo. 

5. Food - sandwiches and salads made with TLC and they use fresh and quality ingredients. Made from SCRATCH.  Not the typical coffee shop with costco-bought foods. 

6. Parking - free street parking fairly easy to find.  During peak (12-3pm) may be a farther walk.

7. Atmosphere - Big open space. Loft-style. I love the modern layout and the architectural

8. Music - they play from barista's ipod hasn't been consistent. Usually not top 40's but I've heard hip-hop, r&b, oldies, to indie. Only thing is, sometimes they play it a tad too loud.

9. People watching - Given the Mission district, there's an abundance of interesting subjects to spy on, uh, no creeper status though.  Also, heavy foot traffic at the entrance keeps me entertained when I get bored of my work.  Diverse crowd.  I love picking out the artsy hipsters to the med students to the environmentalists.

This about sums up what entails my perfect coffee shop, which Coffee Bar has done a fine job to meet.  I would come here for work, but I would also take a friend here to catch-up.  I wish there was a Coffee Bar down the block from where I lived!
author: Mee Y.

description:
Scene: Met up with two friends for a late lunch and coffee. 

Food: The turkey sandwich ($8) was terrible. Plain white bread, twice as much cheese as turkey, simply not good. The side salad was essentially mixed greens with tomatoes. Dressing was so light I wondered if it was even there. 

Drink: One amigo had a latte, another a straight cup of coffee. Both thought they were great. 

Service: Friendly staff took the orders promptly and brought the food served directly to the table. 

Atmosphere: Light, fun, trendy. Plenty of room to bring a laptop and work. Outdoor seating. 

Bottom Line: I can see myself pecking away at a laptop here, but I'll pass on the food.
author: Travis S.

description:
Great song choices over the superb volume level of an open space cafe, coffee, food, snacks, couches, electrical outlets, tables designated for no laptops at certain times, outside seating, couch side tables, counter areas, attractive people to daydream at . . .

only thing is that it gets crowded because of all the great things mentioned above.  it doesn't take much to make a coffee shop, but it takes a good eye to make a great one - this place does it.
author: Kevin H.

description:
This place is like some bad parody of a Ridley Scott movie.  Walk in on any given day, and you're going to be confronted by the disturbing image of a line of pale, skinny dudes with shaved heads (maybe this is the mothership?), perched on stainless-steel chairs, bathed in the pale blue glow of their silver Macbooks -- I swear I saw a bar-code tattoo the other day.

I don't know why I keep coming here.  The coffee is great, but it's basically useless because you can never find a seat.  And truthfully, even if you *could* sit down, you wouldn't really want to -- the minimalist decor, coupled with the aforementioned nerd-replicant problem, creates an atmosphere as warm, comfortable and inviting as a cryogenics lab.  It's not exactly the sort of place where you want to curl up with a good book on a Sunday morning.

Ordinarily, I would feel bad about giving a business a bad review on the basis of the clientele, but in this case, the management *must* know that there's a problem.  More importantly, they could *easily* fix the problem by covering the electrical outlets, limiting the wi-fi, or simply luring the zombies away from the den once in a while.  After all, this is the Mission -- there's bound to be a taco truck full of brains somewhere nearby, right?
author: Tim R.

description:
Hands down my favorite coffee shop in San Francisco. The open space allows my brain to think more freely, or perhaps it's the strong coffee. Most of my co-workers know if I am "working from home", it really means working at Coffee Bar. The food is always great, coffee always strong and tasty and ambiance is clean, open and modern. Also the music is great 75% of the time and the staff always friendly. 

In terms of the crowd, it's a real mix of all types from the techy to med students to artsy skinny pants fixie riding hipsters. 

This place really blends together and captures the best of San Francisco. 

OH ALSO, parking is generally very easy and free!
author: Joseph C.

description:
My studio is a few block away from Coffee Bar, I attempt to eat there for lunch often but I think I'm done with them. When they first opened the food was great and it was busy though never crowded. You could always find a seat.

These days the food has gone down hill, they give attitude with each order, and they have managed to mess something up the last three times I've been there. Though, the main reason I'm giving them a bottom feeder rating isn't because of the food or service, It's because of the ridiculous amount douche bags hogging up the seats pretending to do something important on their laptops! There usually isn't a wait for food or coffee because the place really isn't that busy, but it's impossible to find a seat!

Attention people, It's RUDE! to sit in a crowded cafe sipping on a coffee skimming the internet or pretending to write a novel.  There are hungry paying customers waiting for a seat, it's a cafe! Go to a library, or maybe pay for WIFI in your home you cheap ass!

Coffee Bar, your quickly getting a crappy reputation in the neighborhood. Unless your planning on opening an Apple Store you better start charging for WIFI! While your at it, check the attitude, make your food the way you use to, and stop f@$king up my order!

Update: May 2011
- TOO MANY COMPUTERS - Get an office!
- Screwing up orders
- Impossible to find a seat
- Filled with big egos, both patrons and staff..

The owner emailed me trying to change my mind about a year ago.. Nothings changed.. Nobody in my studio will go there.. Sucks going to Starbucks.. Sucks having so many cheap asses that can't fess up for internet in SF..
author: Jeff C.

description:
Lively, large open space, delicious offerings, genuine warm service, and of course, the hipster set.

...but I don't see what the big deal is.
author: kunamatata w.

description:
salad nicoise, awesome.

espresso, best around.

Emailed them to see if I could get their nutritional info on the citrus dressing, and though they didn't have it, they gave me the recipe so I could figure it out myself.  I am used to restaurants blowing me off when I ask (and I only ask because I LOVE YOUR FOOD AND I WANT TO EAT IT BUT I NEED TO KNOW IT'S NUTRITIONAL CONTENT)  but coffee bar was super cool about it.

Thanks guys, now I can enjoy my salad very happily!
author: Sarah K.

description:
Good coffee, decent pastry, clean, nice environment, wi-fi.  Mostly a a nice staff although they are never in a hurry regardless of how long the line might be.

Full of LOTS of ill-mannered hipsters who will hog a table for two or four to themselves and sit for hours on their computers doing nothing with no regard to how that affects others or the business they are in.  An annoying lot.    

I take mine to go thanks.  Still a decent place near home for a good cup of joe or latte and a pastry.
author: Russell D.

description:
Dearest Coffee Bar.  You are my grown-up Motley.  Minus the ovaries (makes sense if you know me).  This is a serious compliment. 

I am desperately in love with this place.  The coffee is good, the food is good, the sweets are good, the outlets are good, the decor is good, the free internet is good.  There's even a bathroom!  Space can be an issue if you come with another person, but it is the dream setup for this solo-flying, at-home workaholic.   

I love you!
author: Wendy L.

description:
OMG! This place absolutely rocks!! When you enter, you see a really hip coffee counter under tons of sunlight! The seating area is huge and have tons of tables to sit around. There are many group tables which you end up sharing if you are single or in a small group. 

Food and Drink:
They have one of my favorite types of latte - Havana Latte! Latte with condensed milk. Also got Tropical Chicken Sandwich.. It was absolutely delicious! 

Wifi:
Wifi works perfect even there are more than 25 laptops open at one time! Great place to co-work! 

Overall:
This has become my favorite coffee shop in the city! I love it! :)
author: Shikha C.

description:
Coffee is good and reasonably priced. The chicken and hella onion sandwich isn't worth a damn and it costs 9 bucks? It's that San Fran effect I guess. Let me tell all the dweebs in here on their laptops that paying more for a sandwich doesn't make it taste better. 

They do get a bonus star for reserving tables for lunch patrons, otherwise the Mac Book posse would overrun the joint for the free wifi. The atmosphere is pretty quiet and relaxed considering how crowded it is, but don't come here looking for a date because the girls look like guys and the guys look like girls - or maybe your into that, in which case you should hurry on over!
author: Miguel L.

description: This is the perfect place to sip some coffee and work on your laptop.  The lattes are GREAT -- milk steamed to perfection.  The interior is open and airy with a industrial tech feel.  The second floor has a bar with high stools which overlooks the service counter.  I have usually been able to find parking in the area too.  Lunch sandwiches are good too.
author: Brad B.

description: Excellent coffee (I ordered the Guittard mocha $4 - yum!) and chill vibe. Great place to catch up with friends or to bring a laptop (free wifi) to get work done.
author: Faith L.

description: I really like the atmosphere here. I had a vanilla bean latte and it was very good. They got my order wrong so I gave 4 stars but it's a great place to sit and be on your laptop.
author: Jessica C.

description:
My last memory of 2009 is driving around San Francisco trying to get breakfast with my friends. Axis Cafe . . . closed. Liberty Cafe . . . closed. Breakfast at Tiffany's . . . closed. Yes, I know, we could have called or cooked, but where's the fun in that? 

Finally, my friend said: "let's just go to Coffee Bar. I know for a fact they're open." And so we did. Did I mention we were in 2 separate cars? Never fear, there is abundant parking in the area. 

The first thing I noticed was the makeshift courtyard with red metal chairs and tables. Although it was a bit chilly, I was tempted to sit outside - it looked very inviting. I don't think my friends were particularly excited about sitting outside, so scratch that idea. 

After perusing the menu and ordering at the counter, we went upstairs to find a seat. The place looks like a giant loft because, well, it is. We found one small table in the middle of the room and borrowed a third chair. A girl working on her laptop has no problem surrendering the extra chair, as she was not expecting company. As a matter of fact, no one was. Everyone was typing away on their laptops, and most people had their headphones on. "Don't bother me, I am typing." The three of us were the only people actually talking at Coffee Bar (I am not exaggerating). In fact, I believe the talking earned us a few dirty looks from the patrons. Sorry guys, it's NOT a library. 

My friends ordered lattes which looked pretty, dusted with something in a shape of a heart. My regular coffee was very strong, but I wasn't excited that I had to carry my cup down the stairs to get some milk and sugar. Why wouldn't they put a milk/sugar/napkin station upstairs, where the majority of people sit? Did they need that space for yet another outlet for yet another laptop? 

The gingerbread muffin I ordered was actually pretty good. It was very moist and not excessively sweet. I also made the mistake of ordering a bowl of oatmeal. When they say a bowl, they mean a bowl. It's a lot more oatmeal than an average person could eat. If you're not a big eater, I'd recommend ordering a cup. The oatmeal itself was pretty good, with dried cranberries and brown sugar. 

I almost feel bad giving Coffee Bar only three stars, but I feel like I have to. I have no problem with the Coffee part; it's the Bar part that's the problem. The place has a very cold and uninviting feel, not because of the industrial look or because of the mispositioned milk and sugar station, but because of the patrons. A bunch of people staring intently into the neon glow of their Macbooks does not exactly scream "come on in, neighbor!" 

4 stars for the food, 2 stars for the ambiance.
author: Yan G.

description: amazing food. amazing coffee... as well as juices.. quality counts.. and this is it. Keep it up!
author: Sugar S.

description:
Great Environment. Great Service. Great Coffee. Great Eats.

Love their french toast, potato madness and spiced doughnuts... Really like their friendly staff and fun atmosphere...
author: Sunil K.

description:
OK. I Go hear a fair bit, my studio is next door. I'm a designer, and a change of scene on a nice day is kind of nice.  Its a pretty chill spot to go and get some work done. But, there is a slight air of pretentiousness from some of the people there. 

There have been times where I've gotten attitude from some baristas there. I hate bitching about this, since some baristas are really nice. But just because they're cool doesn't mean the douches get a free pass. 

The food is good. Servings could be bigger. Price could be a little lower. 

Overall, a good place to go get work done... grab a bite, coffee/beer and sun.
author: Anish B.

description: What a let down. Wanted my cranberry scone and PAID for it. And when I went to pick it up she had given the last one to someone else....thanks for the warning? Super unfriendly people and the food didn't even meet half of my expectations. For being called coffee bar, it wasn't even that great...Not worth it. I'll stick to my Keurig..The only good thing about this is....maybe the ketchup, even that...a half empty bottle. Ok.
author: Tasha O.

description:
Coffee Bar's coffee is nothing short of amazing. The flavors in their pour-overs are well prepared and thought out. Their Vietnamese iced coffee will get you cranking out the jitters late into the night. Those gooey soft walnut chocolate chip cookies. Oof. 

I'm going to give them the X though. Well not an entire X because their coffee is just so darn good. So three stars it is! I sat for thirty minutes helplessly searching for any strand of internet connection...I remember being this hopeless the last last time I was there.

Aside from good coffee, one of the most vital offerings a cafe can provide to their customers is great internet connection. Thus, after I got my coffee from Coffee Bar, I picked up my laptop and walked to the Starbucks across the street to write a yelp review about how bad their internet connection is. 

Read all about it..here ^
author: Christine H.

description:
I ride by this place every time I head to Potrero.  It looked really interesting but I always had to be somewhere so couldn't stop by.  Finally yesterday I ran into a friend on the way home from work.  We started chatting and walking then I realized that we were only a couple of blocks away from Coffee Bar.  Yup, it's that close to my route to work and yet because I can't see it, I'm constantly forgetting it's there.  

So we went in to complain about work and catch up on gossip.  I was really impressed with the decor and atmosphere.  Outdoor seating with succulents scattered over the patio.  Chill atmosphere inside with seating upstairs.  Lots of wood and open space.  

I was also really happy to see them serving beer and wine here.  What a nice change from the usual FiDi happy hour - bad bars packed with suits.  Since it was warm inside and all the tables were taken with ppl on laptops (1 per 2-4 person table), we chose to sit outside on such a balmy evening.  You can also order food at the bar which they will bring out to your table.  And when you're done they'll clear it away for you.

I'm really thinking this will start being my go to spot for after work drinks.

Bike Parking: designated bike racks on Florida, or poles on Mariposa.
author: Jean K.

description: Lovely space. Good selection of tea as well as what looked like great coffee. Lovely chilled evening spot although closes at 7pm
author: Adam G.

description:
This place was really my favorite place.  And it still is.  However, just like a relationship, the longer Coffee Bar and I are together, the more problems surfaced.  

I give it that the staff are super friendly and we would chat from time to time; they play super cool music (though it begins to get a bit loud); it has warm yet modern interior design.  However, I'd also witnessed a fair share of subtle yet unsettling fights amongst staff, fruit flies over their pastries and less than reliable internet connections.  

Again, I really like the place.  And it hurts me to write a review as such.  But knowing that the owner reads our Yelp reviews, I hope he will do something about the bickering that's going on amongst staff and fruit flies problem.
author: Helen C.

description:
- free wi-fi
- lots of giant tables
- good coffee
- DELICIOUS food

i really like spending hours working on my laptop at this place. they play good music and the place is very nice. i've had a couple sandwiches here and they are SO good (and kind of expensive). the staff is nice, too. 

only drawback is that it's usually pretty crowded. although, every time i've gone and not found a place to sit inside, there's always been somewhere to sit outside.
author: Sarah J.

description:
If I was funemployed, I would be frequently visiting Coffee Bar to scope out the hotties while facebooking, craigslisting for jobs, and g-chatting. 

The coffee is DEEEELICIOUS (almost better than Blue Bottle, but not quite), the service is awesome.  I knew the Barista (a friend from Tulsa) and was chatting it up w/ the sweet girl at the register, who only made us pay for one latte instead of one latte and a mocha.  Could be b/c I knew the barista, but maybe not.  

Love the atmosphere.  They have a super cute large outdoor patio in the front that was filled w/ lots of puppies (Willie even came to say hello!) and your typical South of Market and Mission hipsters/skaters.   They have a large upstairs area too that was filled with great looking men and their macbooks.   

Apparently, they have a pretty sweet Happy Hour on Thursdays and Fridays with Radio Africa and Kitchen, who strive to create all  sustainable food options and methods inspired by recipes of the Mediterranean and Red Sea countries.  I would love to come back and try some of this food!
author: Jenny W.

description:
Love, love, love this place!  

Great coffee, great food, and great atmosphere.  They serve dynamo donuts, which makes this place even more awesome  :)  

Patio is perfect for sunny days.  

I love the fact that they are open late on Fridays for an African inspired dinner (or other guest chefs) and a glass of wine.
author: Maryam T.

description:
Coffee: check, excellent.
Croissant: check, delicious. No over-sized monstrosity, just a human-sized, delicious croissant, like it was meant to be.
Sandwiches: check. Try out the French Dip when it's available. You can thank me later.
Wireless access + power: check. And nobody will make you feel like a parasite.
Did I mention the people there were very nice, and the space light and beautiful? Yeah, I like this place.
author: Mathias B.

description: Good food, coffee, and pastries. This is a great environment to work in, but can get pretty busy on the weekends.
author: Tina F.

description:
The end of the human race: all you find there are rows of Mac's operated by techies with earphones on. No one looks at or talks to each other...SCARY!
Shame because their coffees and teas are pretty good.
author: Anastasia M.

description:
The designer in me took a skip and a hop in glee when i walked into this space. I just needed a cup of coffee to finish my what turned out to be a 12 hr work day. I walked up to the brick building and into their double height ceiling space. It was a cold day but the sun was out and washed through the huge windows that covered about 80% of their wall. I love bright spaces, especially for a work environment. 

The coffee bar sat at floor level with their menu written on brown paper at the upper right corner of the space. There were a few steps to get to the space that was 5' off ground level where all the laptops lived and their operators strongly focused on it with headphones jammed in each ear. The little bar area for the laptop users lined along the edge of the 2nd floor--it was like a barricade of soldiers protecting those dining/studying behind them.

They also had a special menu for the day's special drips. I was pleasantly surprised to see vietnamese coffee as one of their two specials. i was tempted to order it, but i decided against it and ordered their ice coffee. staff was very friendly and outgoing. i got my coffee and walked out sniffing it's intoxicating aroma. the coffee was alright, but i dont think i've acquired the taste of most coffees yet. it did it's job and i got through the day.

this was probably one of the first times i've felt like i'm missing on not living in the city. I just want to pick this cafe up and set it in oakland so i can stroll over to study in its warm space. sf, i am jealous.
author: Rena Y.

description:
This place is off the hook! It's got a modern SF vibe that I really like. It's also pretty packed (only been here twice) cause it's a great place to settle down and do work... if you can find an empty spot. Be ready to share a table with someone too. 

More importantly, they do a good job with their coffee here. Got a strong robust flavor and just a good consistency with their espressos. I recommend their espressos but not so much their vietnamese iced coffee. I can understand their take on it but vietnamese iced coffee is usually a lot sweeter. I wish I had tasted it before I left cause I would have asked for more condensed milk. 

My kind of cafe. Not sure what that says about me but I am enviously sitting here in the East Bay... coveting what I cannot have.
author: Victor H.

description:
Dilemma: the space is beautiful and the food was good, until it made me run out a half hour later like there was an angry cat in my stomach.  Rowrrr.  I soon got back to natural color (white, not green), so should I leave 1 star or give them benefit of the doubt?  3 I guess.  Slightly in their favor that they're open till 8-10 (depending on day,) may come back and re-evaluate.

The place is trying hard to carry a hip modern design vibe.  Wide industrial space, wood slab seating- although it has a nice flowery patio out front for sunny, non-shitty days (not today.)  It's kinda hard to find, part of a large artist studio building, which added to the feel that it serves a select crowd.  Location wise, cool.  Nearby chatters included 6-8 annoying grad student types and a trio of wisecracking old-timers.  Lots of workers on macs, less than great power access from where I sat.  Great wifi.  Wallpapery DJ beats were happening that didn't do a lot for me.  Food price was a bit higher than other neighborhood cafes, which I guess is part of the package.  My large decaf and portabella-mozeralla sandwich with side of greens tasted great, but rowrrr.  Not a great first impression.
author: Pat L.

description:
There is something very inherently San Francisco about this place. While I wish the outdoor seating was more accommodating, it does the job and the inside is pretty impressive. The vibe is very fun, upbeat, and professional. The sandwiches are pretty predictable but are done very well. The ham and cheese is great. They also have veggie options. The menu does have some cute and surprising items, like Vietnamese coffee, and does change fairly frequently. Other coffee drinks are very satisfying as well. Maybe the coolest thing about Coffee Bar is its location - and its successful position as a great cafe in a fairly newly developing neighborhood.

Nice spot, good food, great coffee.
author: Alexander M.

description:
Coffee Bar is a solid cafe. I can hang out here and write all day long.

Friendly, no-nonsense, and attractive baristas run a tight ship in this modern space with great light and air, roomy tables, good-quality yet unobtrusive dishware, and comfortable and varied seating, including a roomy front porch with potted plants and tables. The one-room toilet is clean and pleasantly decorated.

Patrons share communal tables, and most are working on laptops or meeting with someone. The atmosphere is youthful and professional. Free wireless works fine though it did boot me anytime I fell idle for a few minutes. Almost every seat in the house can reach an electrical outlet. Good tea and coffee complement a healthy and decadent if uninspired sandwich and salad menu with reasonable prices as well as fresh baked coffee-cake oriented dessert options. Yes, they have beer and wine.

This is a great place to camp out all day to write. I like that the floorplan puts me between my laptop and the outside door when I go to order another cup of tea.
author: Kristy L.

description:
This is my favorite cafe.

When I'm working remotely (aka hanging out in the Bay Area instead of working in NYC), coffee bar is my default spot.  I like the atmosphere which one could describe as urban, lofty or industrial.  It seems to be frequented by SF web folk (or SF is populated with mainly web folk), which is a welcome change from New York's robust lack of any real coherence of a tech/web community.  It's comforting to over hear people's conversions at adjacent tables about wireframing and UX and conversion funnels (sorry for eavesdropping).  One time a guy sat next to me and conducted a noisy business lunch with an acquaintance of his.  Turned out the guy was Tim Ferriss.  I like the people who camp out there.

Other details:  The wifi is fast and strong and never cuts out.  I've always been able to get a seat.  There's a paucity of plugs so if you bring a power strip you're sure to make friends.  Sandwich/salad combos there are decent and a great deal. My only suggestion for would be for the baristas to preheat the mugs.  The cold mugs suck a lot of warmth out of the hot drinks.  Before you know, you're just drinking soggy, espresso-y milk.
author: Greg T.

description:
One of the better 3rd wave coffee shops. Beautiful, beautiful space. Big industrial loft. It was pretty easy for me to find parking and a place to sit. Tons of outlets + free wifi. Relatively clean - not sticky and gross like Barefoot. Music is interesting - doesn't make you want to tear your hair out.

Had the cortado turbinado with their default Neopolitan espresso. They put enough sugar in there to bring out the flavors. Also had a macchiato. Good stuff. Will probably turn into my regular spot to read, work, and enjoy espresso.

Dogs are allowed on the bottom floor. Outdoor seating too. =)
author: Ta G.

description: Their Havana latte is really really good . It's kinda sweet but not too sweet ... it's perfect . The texture of it was really nice ... very light and foamy . I also had one of their pastries which was not bad . I forgot what it's called but it kind of looks and tastes like a Madeleine . They have upstairs seating as well as outdoor seating . They have sandwiches as well as wine . I think their outdoor seating would be good for enjoying a cup of coffee or wine with a sandwich on a sunny day .
author: Eileen L.

description: I stopped coming here over the summer because it was extremely warm inside, and they had a fly infestation.  This was the first time back since and I ordered a kale caesar salad, which I've had here twice before and had enjoyed.  For $15, I would expect similar quality every time. Today what came out had no artichoke, and barely any chicken or dressing!
author: xxxx x.

description: caramel latte was fucking perfect. also got their butter croissant. can't wait to come back!!!
author: Erika P.

description:
My wedding was so much fun. Seriously. I got married September 17, 2011 and had my reception at Coffee Bar. When planning our reception we knew we wanted a three things 1) a taco truck  2) an outdoor patio space and 3) a casual but modern atmosphere. Coffee Bar fit the bill! 

We met and worked with Nathan Downs, the Events and Development Manager, who was very laid back and receptive to our ideas. He assured us Coffee Bar would be happy to accommodate our party and bring our vision to life! And honestly, he did just that. Planning was a breeze. We told him what we wanted in terms of food, beverage and decor and, after discussing our budget, etc., he made it happen.

Most notably, Nathan really rose the occasion when, a couple of weeks prior to the event we learned that on the night of our wedding there would be an art festival in the street outside Coffee Bar with 400 people likely wanting to eat tacos from our taco truck...he problem solved ways to prevent party crashers and even went so far as to set up a decoy taco stand on the corner where we could re-direct non-wedding guests to fill up on tacos! Genius. Nathan also put together a gorgeous menu of appetizers and salads to supplement the taco truck fare, and he did a fabulous job of taking care of all the details of the day, all while maintaining a relaxed attitude. As the bride, I honestly didn't have to think about and/or deal with a single thing at the reception because Nathan was on it. Service from other Coffee Bar staff was also excellent and guests were able to have all the complimentary tea and coffee they liked. 

I'm fairly certain Coffee Bar couldn't really give our wedding rave reviews as, with most weddings, it ended in a drunken mess (hopefully we weren't too obnoxious). However, I can't recommend Coffee Bar enough for private events (including weddings!). Fabulous space, excellent service and working with Nathan was truly a great experience.
author: Maureen L.

description:
Great spot if you want free Wifi outside, and a wide range of food and drinks.  I have been here about 7 times though, and only once was I able to find a spot to sit inside comfortably with my laptop.  It is always crowded, even in the middle of the day on a tuesday.  The weird thing is all of the people there look like people with real jobs... don't you have an office to be at?

Coffee and drinks are average, and food is pretty decent, though I haven't tried much on the menu yet.

Love the front patio on a nice day
author: Kevin O.

description:
Great coffee but rude staff, you know the typical SF identity seeker types...Food is good but extremely pricey, I mean come on.. I go back for the coffee only.  Way too many fly's buzzing inside the pastry box....ughhh  

I miss the original owners of the original business, Arc Café, those guys were great!
author: Adam Z.

description:
superb coffee, the almond croissants are so good I recommend booking one!! 
The one area that needs improvement is shade outside... can't sit out there when it's Nice to scorching.
author: lisa s.

description: We have a winner!!! I am giving this place 5 stars.  (mind you, I don't pass these out all too often.)  Here's the reason why:  wife and I spent some time in Italy last year (Amalfi coast to be exact).  We ended up drinking some amazing espressos and other coffees.  We all know that the italians make a mean cup of joe, right? So, we end up stopping by the Coffee Bar as a recommendation from my brother-in-law. OMG!!!  They make a cappuccino just like in italy- no joke!!  The coffee is simply amazing. The foam is perfect! And the setting is very cool too.  There are tables to sit everywhere. However, it seems like you need to own an apple product to drink coffee here though...everyone had a macbook!  I luv SF!
author: Steven D.

description:
I worked about 2 blocks from this place but somehow didn't know it existed until about a month before I left.  Damn, it's good.

We used to go to the Atlas Cafe for lunch--it was good mostly, but it always took FOREVER to get your food, and a lot of times you'd sit outside and hear a loud grunt announcing the customer's name that was ready.  Somehow those grunts always sounded the same, and you'd have to get up, go inside, realize they didn't call you, then head back out.  Hear another grunt, etc.

Okay, enough about Atlas.  

Coffee Bar is everything I want in a lunch place!  Great sandwiches, soups, and salads.  The specials are always fantastic and they really try to mix it up with some interesting things.  

It's usually VERY busy.  It's quite interesting/hilarious to see all the people lined up at the bar seating above where you order--every single person on a laptop doing "work".

Best part of all, they actually bring out your food for you--no guessing what the loud grunt you just heard was! :)
author: Brian S.

description:
Good coffee, and good pastries: love this place!

Nice space to work on computer but only few outlets available.
Parking can be challenging depending on time.
author: Yoshiko M.

description: Really good, quality coffee, but it was extremely packed- this is my only gripe. Workers were friendly. There were no work stations/tables available inside or outside. I probably waited about twenty minutes until I saw someone packing their stuff upstairs in the balcony section, but some lady came out of no where and swooped on it. Sad I didn't get to get my work done here, but after I got my order, I grabbed my bike and walked up the street to Starbucks which was really empty haha.
author: Grey S.

description:
Update: November 4, 2012 - 

Lost 2 stars.  Too crowded, always.  I've gone off-times to have lunch (usually good food) and do some work, but the entire place is always filled with people very clearly set-up for the day.  

They've made an effort to block-off some tables for people wanting to eat lunch, so that the "workplace cafe" people don't take up every spot, but it's clearly not enough. 

It's no longer worth trying to go there with the amount of times I get turned away.  I'll take the $15-$20 I'd spent on food and coffee elsewhere while the people with tea and water occupy the tables. 

Bottom line: they need to still do a better job regulating their space to allow for drop-ins as well as the people working from the cafe.

Original: 

Great coffee and the food, although on the slightly expensive side, has not disappointed me yet. 

Expect the place to be pretty full, though, as this is certainly a hotspot for many people without a 9-5.  Being a good cafe is a double-edged sword, places that don't suck draw a lot of laptop-wielding seat-warmers.

Still one of my favored cafes for working.
author: John E.

description:
Very hard to find a spot.. looks like a university library right before the final exams.

Nice environment.

Their latte is tasty but expensive.
author: Shirley W.

description:
Love working at this coffeeshop. 2 floors, high ceilings, clean look, and the coffee is good! Free wifi and an awesome outdoor patio.
Main issue, it can get crowded and hard to get a spot to work especially if its more than just you.
Be prepared for a lot of ipads, iphones, macbooks... I didn't help that ratio though :)
author: shadi m.

description: Great coffee, plenty of light space, an outdoor area and parking - what more can a person ask for in an urban coffee shop?
author: Lindsey C.

description:
This is a review for the Radio Africa and Kitchen dinner at this place - I haven't been here in the daytime.

Friday night, date suggested "let's go to this place called Coffee Bar". Before I checked Yelp, I was like... "Coffee Bar? For dinner?". This place really surprised me. 
Great ambience - spacious, views of the neighborhood, lots of candles. 
Great servers - they were super-friendly and helpful, we got a table immediately. 
Food - really different and delicious. The flavors were very interesting, and well-matched. I had the vegetarian Israeli couscous/white bean gratin entree - and this had caramelized okra on the side! As I said, different but delicious.
