They don't have too many choices for vegetarians, so I'll have to check the menu before going again - but apart from that, it's a real find!
author: What's in a nam e.

description: AH love this place..new favorite area to come study, if only it wasn't so far from daly city!  plenty of seating, plugs, lighting is also good.  no air conditioning so it was kind of uncomfortable later on in the day with tons of people there...it was manageable though. coffee wasn't the best i ever had but i just got a iced coffee..will try a latte or something next time! 4 stars for overall atmosphere, great and friendly service, and coffee 10X better than starbucks!
author: Joanna M.

description:
They make a good coffee and have yummy pastries, but I hate it when non-Vietnamese places try to do Vietnamese iced coffee. Sure, it was nice that the quality of the coffee beans used was higher than your average Viet joint, but it still wasn't quite as good. 

I absolutely love the big, lofty feel of the place, very out of place for SF but in a good way.
author: Mark A.

description:
Coffee is affordable and straightforward, but not blue bottle taste.  Still, the staff is nice, music is good if you have to stay a while, and only $2 for a large.

Made to order hot or cold sandwiches and salad -- usually a good special of the day worth checking out.  My friend always orders "The Big Salad" or salad nicoise and swears by it.  Cobb salad is just under $10 but quality chicken, bacon, egg, cheese, avocado.....

Outdoor patio with about 7-9 tables that are usually easy to come by given most customers seem comfortable with only the dim light of their laptop inside...

I've watched an instant line form for lunch around 1245PM on weekdays so might try to plan around that if you can.
author: Gracie L.

description: It's extremely difficult, for whatever reason, to find the perfect coffee shop. Coffee Bar meets most of my criteria: communal tables if you're in the sharing mood, individual tables, counter seats over looking the first floor, bar seats near the register, outdoor seating, excellent pastries, savory dishes, coffee of course, and fresh pressed juices (kale, orange, beet, and carrot) every morning at 7am (these sell out sometimes by the afternoon). Outlets are everywhere, free wifi, very little metered parking, which ends up being both a good and bad thing. Impressive space, also open to rent for parties, private dinners, etc.
author: John V.

description: An utterly picture perfect vanilla latte with a taste to match. It also has awesome industrial decor inside. The service was ok, it was neither amazing or disappointing.  The only real negative was the parking; it took awhile to find a spot, but it is well worth a try.
author: Jeff S.

description:
Basically there is no reason for me to be in the neighborhood, but I was early to meet people at Circolo and would rather sit outside here and smoke and drink coffe than sit at the bar in Circolo. I Had intended to just get a small coffee, but was tempted away by the El Diablo. Don't remember all what was in it (at least four ingedients other than coffee), but I was sold on "chipotle infused milk".  Super good! I may come back just for this.

Also, I am a genuis. took my spicy coffee situation across the street, ordered a shot of bourbon, added it to coffee. Ultra good!
author: Dave J.

description: Great coffee and pastries with a great hangout bar.
author: Seth T.

description:
The Coffee Bar is a nice escape from the patchouli of everyday life, a place where you can be nakedly honest about wanting a nice, clean place to WiFI your worries away in your work clothes surrounded by lots of really awkward couples on blind dates. Bring headphones so you don't invade their privacy.  
 
The haircuts might be hipster in San Francisco, but they'd be pretty normal stuff in any blue collar neighborhood in Europe. And yes, there are tons of Euros here. Let's face it, Euros just kick our ass in style, and we should admit proper defeat.  Thank God they don't dance as soulfully as us, otherwise there'd be no level playing field.

The coffee's good, and it's usually crowded during the day. The dinner evenings bring on some really tasty desserts and I love nice African DJ music.  During the day it's a big pick-up scene, which is fine, but I like the evenings better for some reason. Maybe it's the candles.
author: Romy I.

description:
I LOVE this cafe!  

I can see why it's crowded all the time. 

- The BEST egg/brie/bacon sandwich EVER! (served on weekends)
- Yummy Cobb salad
- Great selection of coffees and teas
- Cool loft space with tall windows and lots of sunlight
- Cool music
- Free wi-fi and lots of technies
- Lots of Mac users so I stick out with my PC :(
- Nice staff
- Outdoor seating (to enjoy the Potrero sun)
- You can hang out here all day long
- They have special chef dinners here from time to time

It's actually at the intersection of: Florida and Mariposa St.

How I wish they would plop this coffee bar into my neighborhood.
author: Lis A.

description:
Wow.  It took 20 minutes from when I walked in the door to when I received my lunch order.  $9.50 got me the following:

1) A turkey sandwich (the loftily-and enigmatically-named "Diestal Ranch Oven"), consisting of three (yes, 3) slices of deli turkey on sourdough, plus two pieces of lettuce, 3 paper-thin tiny avocado slices, and 2 tomato slices.
2) A bowl of potato and cheddar soup with a layer of oil floating on top, that tasted suspiciously of canned soup. The temperature could have only generously been described as lukewarm.

On top of that, I probably stood in line for 5 minutes as the excessively slow person behind the register dealt with the two customers in front of me.  When it was (finally) my turn, he stood there on the phone without acknowledging my presence for at least a minute, then somehow seemed to not understand the words "iced tea", which last time I checked were part of the English language and probably something that a restaurant should be familiar with.
author: Rose S.

description:
Great Coffee
 plus
Tasty Food
 plus
Dynamo Donuts
 plus
Light, Airy, Open Space
 plus
Outlets and the Fastest Wi-Fi of Any Coffee Bar
 plus
Decent Music off iPod
 plus
Clover Machine
 plus
Radio Africa and Kitchen menu in the Evening
 equals
Big, Big Win.
author: Andrei Z.

description:
lots of tables, lots of laptops, lots of coffee, lots of parking, and delicious sandwiches.

we hung out here for a few hours playing laptops, drinking coffee, and snacking on sandwiches and salad.

i can't wait till the next laptop session here.
author: Ameer N.

description:
Coffee Bar is a charming breakfast/lunch spot tucked away in one of the less busy areas of the Mission. I've been here a few times already and am always pleasantly surprised that such a spacious, modern, always-crowded coffee shop with a solid menu exists in such a random neighborhood.

The food choices here are not out-of-this-world, but they are satisfying. The Atrani sandwich is a personal favorite of mine: prosciutto, fresh mozzarella, basil, and balsamic vinegar on a warm & fluffy roll. The sandwich is light and tasty and comes with a nice side salad. Overall a very satisfying lunch.

The coffee here is also pretty good, although the restaurant does not have as extensive a selection of drinks as its name would suggest. However, Coffee Bar does earn bonus points for serving Dynamo donuts, the $3-a-piece greasy pieces of heaven that are so unbelievably delicious that you'll find them on countless SF-best lists (including 7x7's 100 foods you must try before you die). I had the orange ginger donut and it was fantastic. I have yet to try the bacon maple apple, salted caramel and spiced chocolate donuts, but those are definitely next on my list of things to try!

As for the intangibles, service is pretty good, there is a lot of space to eat/work/chat with friends upstairs and in the outside patio, and prices are reasonable.

All in all, I give Coffee Bar a B+. Don't make the trek out to the Mission just to eat here, but definitely stop by if you're in the area!
author: Joseph F.

description:
This place is clean (tables aren't sticky), coffee is very good, tables are large, and staff is friendly.  However, what I liked most about this place is that you don't reek of coffee after you leave typical coffee shops (i.e. starbucks).  

We got their vanilla bean latte and it was the best I've ever had.  At $4.50 for a large cup of coffee, I clearly know that I'm getting ripped off, but for some reason I've found a way to rationalize paying this to support a local coffee shop.  We also got the blood orange Pelligrino which I really liked and haven't found else where.  

The one thing that I noticed about this coffee shop was that EVERYONE, literally every single person at this coffee shop was on their laptop.  I felt out of place since I didn't have one, but if you're looking for a quiet place to work, this place is perfect!
author: Kristie G.

description:
I'm sitting here at Coffee Bar and for some reason I feel like the world is my oyster.  haha!

I don't know if it's the full, open windows, good food and open space, or the coffee... I'm just the happiest camper in the world, right now.

Sitting here for the past three hours, I've written a blog, created a prezi, done a ton of marketing research and felt this overwhelming sense of happiness.

What an amazing place!  I'll be here all the time.  :)  All of my other wifi spots have just been replaced.
author: Steph M.

description: One of the best places in San Francisco to sit with your laptop for hours on end. Good coffee and food, great people watching, and plenty of outlets. What more could a working girl in SF need?
author: Charlotte C.

description:
So _this_ is the place to get some work done in the Mission. The noise and turmoil of Valencia street coffee shops behind you, experience ample seating, chill ambient music, and *gasp* power outlets at almost every chair in the house! 

I almost don't want to review coffee bar and suggest that more people visit it, the atmosphere is just so much more relaxing than other places in the city. There's nothing like being surrounded by other studious people, all working on their own computers and being rather quiet. 

Bonus for having good coffee (three kinds of the iced variety), and a great beer selection (including my favorite Trappist ale, Chimay). A slight warning: they often have special "dinners" here and limit the seating to only a few scarce seats at these events, so be prepared on one of their "restaurant" nights. I've heard the dinners _are_ exquisite, so maybe it's worth sticking around?

P.S. I've noticed many reviews complaining about the price of the donuts. These are _dynamo_ donuts people! Donuts of the gods! The people's donut! They're deliciously worth it!
author: Ralph G.

description:
Best place for coffee in media gulch. 

Great cappuccino. 

Best electrical outlet and seating situation of any cafe in San Francisco, but doesn't matter because it is too popular. 

Good variety of food.
author: Lion G.

description:
Busy, hip coffee shop. Awesome outdoor seating and plenty of space for laptops. Great people watching in there too.
My only issue is that the music can get night club loud and the baristas really pound the espresso machine for even more noise. I bring earplugs but enjoy the busy atmosphere.
author: jason h.

description: After so many years spending my money and afternoons at Starbucks across the street I decided to give Coffee Bar a chance. To be honest the I tried Coffee Bar because I was using my computer and internet was extremely slow and I can't stand slow internet connections. Since that I never went back to Starbucks because the quality of the food is way better at Coffee Bar. I can get delicious salads and sandwiches and even though it's not cheap I believe it's worth it.
author: Joe M.

description:
I've been here a bunch of times, but haven't been motivated to write a review until now. 

I came here for lunch the other day and ended up waiting about 15-20 mins for a grilled cheese. I was a little peeved, but the situation would have annoyed me much more if the guy at the register hasn't been so apologetic and friendly. They get pretty swamped at the lunch hour so I understand the usual whatever/rushed attitude. That day however, the guy at the register made an extra effort to please a customer who waited much much longer than necessary for her meal. I also received an iced tea and cookie for my trouble. 

The reason I only give this place 3 stars is because overall the food here is just ok. I have had some great sandwiches and yummy cookies but I have also had way overdressed salads and soggy, cold grilled cheeses. 

I will continue to come back with coworkers because of the convenience and most people in my office really like their coffee, but I wouldn't come back on my own.
author: Jen S.

description: Just came back from a nice experience at Coffee Bar. Coffee is strong and flavorful, but a bit pricey. I will stick to Peets. However, their chicken salad sandwich was really delicious. The chicken was lightly flavored with mayo, and the bread was very, very good. I like the setup of this joint, although download speeds was slow, just to check my email took a few minutes (download your porn or music at home please!). Nice, clean restrooms.
author: Thomas L.

description:
I like the coffee here!  They have variety and options.  They brew it well -- not burnt or overly bitter.  A few days ago, the specials of the day were from Kenya and Sumatra.

Oh, and I got a delicious donut with coconut flakes baked onto it.  The place is infested with laptop users, but they fear the glare of the outside, so you can usually find a nice spot to sit on the pic-nic tables outside.  People don't mind sharing their tables here.

People with dogs: you are welcome in the outside area.  :)
author: Rudy R.

description:
One visit and I'm a fan. 
On a sunny SF afternoon, I decided to go explore the City and venture out from my typical stomping grounds. A quick search on Yelp and I found myself Potrero bound to hit up this joint. The area is both industrial and, in my own mind, in the middle of f'ing no where. There's not much around except for Circolo, Whisper and William Sonoma's corporate offices yet ironically, parking in the area (from what I can gather in my mid-week visit) is a b***h. Nonetheless, the place is worth the trek out. 

First off, the place has a streetside front patio with ample seating. On that particular sunny day, it was hard to resist sitting outside at least for a minute. Second, the place is huge and offers a variety of seating that can accommodate practically every arrangement / group size. It was slammed at 2pm on a Wednesday (what was up with that?), but I managed to score a small table that faced the all-window front of the cafe/restaurant. It was cool to get my "work" done while at the same time looking out at the peaks of warehouse smoke stacks and then seeing the fog rolling in over the hills even further beyond. That and it has free WIFI. Oddly enough, the stark neighborhood and feel of the place made me appreciate the stuff I was doing and the time I was wasting away. 

I had a large ice tea and their potato soup. The soup was great and a promising sign that the rest of the menu could also be well executed. The tea was alright but be warned, there are no free or discount refills... you gotta pay full price if you're going for seconds. As for price, it's averagely SF - meaning I think it could probably burn a hole through your wallet if you get carried away ordering. 

Overall, I thought it was time well spent and definitely a venue I will be checking in on again!
author: Jonny Bobby G.

description:
Coffee Bar is the type of place that makes me want to quit my job, grow my hair out all shaggy and become an engineer or freelance web designer. The industrial space is teeming with hipsters and their MacBook Pros and iPhones. Do I sound jealous? Maybe just a bit.


 I want to spend my days in front of a keyboard, drinking in the ambiance of Coffee Bar while sipping on a soy latte surrounded by cute hipster girls with tattoos and nose piercings. I want to grab some space on the sunny patio with my dog underfoot, eating a panini while sipping on a cold Hitachino nest ale. I want to go there now.


 This neighborhood is becoming a must visit foodie destination - Slow Club, Universal Cafe, Blowfish Sushi are all within walking distance. That is, if you can pull yourself away from Coffee Bar. Good luck with that.
author: tvham

description: Only popped in for coffee. Loads of people riveted on their laptops working. The food looked good (there was some sort of pizza popup), but the espresso was mediocre at best -- over roasted and bitter -- and the black coffee du jour was only slightly better.
author: Justin M.

description: Coffee Bar is my favorite coffee shop in the city - and I don't even drink coffee. I rotate betweeen Spring Jade, Jasmine Green, Bergamot Black, and good ol' plain iced tea on hot days. The hood is generally warmer and I love being able to sit outside on sunny days to enjoy my tea and lunch. I'm a little obsessed with the Nicoise salad, so it's the only thing I've ever ordered but my friends say the Cobb salad and sandwiches are good too. I might get around to trying other items eventually and I'd really like to attend a pop up dinner one of these nights too. Love the space, love the food, love the energy - it's one of my happy places! =)
author: Queenie C.

description: Food is very good, and fresh, love the morning treats. The reason for the 3 stars is that they open at 7:00 am but often I've been there at this time and they're still closed or setting up the coffee bar, so you can't get an espresso drink. The prices can also be a deal breaker for a regular lunch spot.
author: Amber D.

description:
The illest coffee shop. Ever.

Lots of sunlight, Tasty Teas, Lots of outlets, Fast wifi, and full of cool, productive people.

I considered putting its address as my office on my business card.

I wonder how a coffee bar would do in Chicago...hmm....!

o ya, and they don't have annoying credit card minimum's like Ritual does
author: mar m.

description:
This place is tucked away, but worth trekking to. The layout and design is striking. It feels like a polished and very open warehouse loft with tons of natural light. The upper level seating is filled with people on their laptops or studying. Huge KUDOS for the free wi-fi! The little patio out front is perfect for a sunny meet-up with friends over coffee.

Notes on the drinks and food: The sandwiches for lunch are really, really good and around $10. They come with a little side salad. The coffee is good, not amazing. Also, I'd avoid the chai latte. Tried it twice.. meh watery. Other than that, an all-around solid choice.

Will be back to try the evening menu!
author: Merrill S.

description: After several great experiences at Coffee Bar I have upped my rating to 5! My Vietnamese iced coffee was delicious. My grilled cheese was even moooore delicious. And my gazpacho was the perfect delight on this warm and sunny day. The atmopshere is cute, sunny, and open. The staff is 100 times more friendly than the staff at a certain "color of bottle" cafe downtown. People with laptops line the balcony and sun lovers sit outside. This is my new regular lunch spot for sure!
author: Mark S.

description: I've come here numerous times over the years and still enjoy my visits. The coffee is good and potent enough to keep me going for many hours after I drink it.  Pastries they bring in here are also quite good as well are the sandwiches that are made to order. I do really like the atmosphere: high ceilings, industrial style appearance.  Certain sections have power outlets to use for laptop patrons which is nice although when I plan to do some light work with my computer I try to come early in order to get a seat because it is a popular coffee shop that gets quite crowded.
author: Kent W.

description: This is my friend's favorite spot for coffee, so I was willing to check it out with her.  I liked it a lot.  My Havana Latte was delicious.  Their coffee and food seem like they are better quality than most coffee spots.  The space is big and bright.  The crowd seemed like a nice mix of people.  I don't bring my laptop out with me, but if I did, this would be my first choice of cafes.  I like the fact that they have a few communal tables in addition to lots of 2-seater tables.   It's a very chill place.  It was pretty crowded when we were there, so I am curious as to whether I would be able to find a place to sit if I went again.
author: Kandi K.

description: Eight bucks for a snack-sized grilled cheese sandwich? And snooty service to boot? I think I'll skip this hipster haven next time and get gouged someplace else.
author: Tim B.

description:
I work close by and at the beginning I came every morning and on most of my lunches as well. Under this frequency, things like speed and price start to be noticeable. 
They are slow at serving food and food+ drink will add up to $15-20

I stopped going here, returned after a while and food has gotten so bad. The bread is stale the meat or veggies that supposedly come in the salads are very hard to find.
author: bleta p.

description:
I love the outdoor patio at Coffee Bar.  Sit, enjoy a delicious cup of coffee, have lunch or a cookie, and soak up the sun--or the diffused light we call sun in SF.

Seriously, when I'm in the neighborhood, Coffee Bar is my cafe of choice.
author: Todd X.

description:
A perfectly splendid place to cowork (http://hatfactory.net/), tackle your to-do list, or just sip coffee and read or mingle. The airy atmosphere and natural sunlight - pouring through the plethora of windows - mixed with the modern, urban photography and contemporary design create a balanced, energizing ambiance. The coffee's good, as are the sandwiches and salads. I mostly liked the music, but prefer my Pandora stations. 

p.s. this is more Potrero than the Mish.
author: Sally M.

description:
The place is very cool and nice but SOME of employees need to change their ATTITUDE. 
When I asked to heat up my chocolate croissant, the employee, who wore a blue shirt today,  threw his pen and went up to heat up my croissant. When he came back, the croissant was still cold, but I didn't want to bother to ask one more time. I didn't ask a big favor here! Hello?? what's the matter with you!!!
author: Soo N.

description:
It's nice to wander around and find the "best kept secret," but for the most part, I like to do research before finding a gem.  Kind of like when I begin dating someone and check his name on meganslaw.com and dontdatehimgirl.com.  I don't have trust issues, but as any former girl scout or jilted girlfriend will tell you, it pays to be prepared.

My new boyfriend *pauses while hearts across the U.S. shatter and knives are simultaneously sharpened* really likes architecture, cool interior design and... java.  He'd read about Coffee Bar on various food websites (check Yelp, Mister!) and knew it seemed like my cup of cappuccino.

Scene: 20&30-something singles with their laptops and time to kill.  Great menu.  Meats, cheeses, sandwiches, and pastries.  Soup of the day was a savory white bean & ham, served with focaccia.  

Tons of indoor seating inside the spacious loft area, but half of San Francisco got there first, and those peeps didn't look like they were moving anytime soon.

We found seats outside - red metal patio furniture - and were able to catch glimpses of passersby and the occasional belligerant drunk shouting "screw you all!  you're going to hell!"  Aside from that whack job (this recession hits us all differently, poor guy), the scene was yupster (yuppie hipster) and welcoming.

The boyfriend enjoyed eyeballing the impressive design-y, tenant improvement-y decor between people-watching and bites of grilled cheese w/ accompanying fresh green salad.  

Bottomline:  Coffee Bar is awesome.  Oh, and my new man has great taste - but that's a given.
author: Janney B.

description: Holy crap. My new favorite place on the city. The Havana Latte was yummy, very sweet, which I liked and the barista warned me about (which I appreciated just in case sweet wasn't my thang). I think the coffee is a little pricey ($4.50!), but on par with other coffee establishments around, I suppose. I tried the wood fired pizza as well, which was also amazing!! $12 for a pizza, which seems reasonable for San Francisco. I thought this place would be too cool for me, since it is definitely a hot spot, but most of the people working there were really nice and welcoming (except I overheard one server be rude the the girl next to me and tell her to bus a previously dirty table herself!). I wish I lived close enough to walk over!
author: M T.

description: Stopped here for a snacky dinner the other week before a play across the street. It's very spacious and lofty looking, tons of seats, but a good number of people there even right before it closed when we were there. There is outdoor seating too, for when it's warm enough for that. I had the prosciutto sandwich with goat cheese and fig jam - very tasty, not too filling, but good for a light dinner (I had a snack when I got home!) and a soy chai latte. A had the tono salad (tuna, egg, mozzarella, lentils, avocado, arugula, balsamic vinaigrette) with a coffee latte. He loved his salad, and I can see why, what a yummy combo of healthy proteins! Something I'd probably enjoy as well. You order up front, wait for your drink, take a number and they bring you the food. If I lived nearby, I'd definitely be here a lot.  I'm surprised it closes as early as it does though.
author: Merredith L.

description: Been coming here on and off for quite some time. If you're planning your first visit, and it's late morning or afternoon, be prepared for what feels like judgment when stepping in. It's like walking into a stadium surrounded by an elevated panel of judges peering at newcomers who enter over their macbook pros. Once you get over the feeling of awkwardness, you will be delighted to find some decent coffee in a pretty nice space. There's also a front garden area which is excellent on nice weather days.
author: J K.

description: Told us to clear out of our seats literally one minute after selling us coffees in "to stay" mugs for some sort of a games night. Not cool. Aside from that, it looks like a nice place in theory. Perhaps call ahead and ask if there are any events going on before venturing into this otherwise inviting cafe.
author: Aleks O.

description:
Coffee Bar is a very nice coffee shop.  I love the ambiance inside and out.  Their patio is small but very nice.  It has a high fence around it so your separated from the hustle and bustle of the street.  

The Coffee here is very good as well.  I consider myself somewhat of a coffee snob (as I only buy Barefoot coffee for the most part, yummm!) and the even the drip coffee here is robust and flavorful.  I have not eaten here but the food looks great.  I'll have to try is during my next visit!  4 Stars!
author: Ari M.

description: Liked the sandwich, loved the interior decor, enjoyed the espresso.... I think if i didnt work during all my day light hours i might like this place more but slow service on a not so busy Sunday didn't jive with me.
author: Denny C.

description: It's a nice space, but something about it is a turn off.  It's a bit too cool, too hip, all the girls look the same with their casually messy updos and multiple layer of stretch knit, the guys in their skinny pants and t-shirts.  The line of MAC laptops lined up on every counter seems so sterile and utilitarian, not a place I'd want to go and chat, for fear I'd disturb the very important work of the very industrious patrons in the cafe.  Outside is better, there's a nice patio and comfortable seating and no laptops.  We were there during a busy day and it took forever to get our drinks, and then they forgot to make one of them, so it took a bit more forever to get the entire order.  The coffee was good, no complaints there.  I think Coffee Bar cultivates a "hip" scene, which is cool, but it's not my scene.  I'm old and boring, and I don't have a mac, skinny jeans, or jersey knit leggings, so it's really not the place for me.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
This place is great - there just about every day.   I enjoy the coffee - my dog loves the gougeres (actually they are quite good - don't think their "for the dogs").

The staff if very friendly.    A great neighborhood place.

(I'd give it a 5 star - but it's just something I don't do).
author: Duke H.

description:
Beautiful location, tables, outlets, wifi; great for working all afternoon over coffee.

Plus, delicious sammiches.
author: Andrew W.

description:
I was introduced to Coffee Bar by one of their regulars.  Naturally, I was  skeptical ,I figured she had simply been wooed by the attractive wait staff and occasional free donut. 

Overall, the staff was helpful and patient despite the line trailing out the door. There are a few surprising combinations on the menu and the latte is a win.  This is a great place to transform into your temporary office or have  weekend brunch. This is quickly becoming one of my favorites.
author: Jes V.

description:
OK, 4.5, but I am reserving a full 5 star review for when they change their coffee beans.  "Mr. Espresso" just isn't gonna cut it. 

the greatness of this place also really depends on how many others think so. and yesterday, apparently the whole city thought so, which made it a terrible spot to try to relax and sit awhile. 

for a place that serves beer and wine, and calls itself a bar, i think they can stand to stay open later than 8pm on a saturday.  They might also consider putting in some taps to serve fresh beer.   I like that they have all the right glasses, but bottled beer in their own signature glasses is still bottled beer. 

but, they take AMEX, big pluses for that. 

also, radio africa and kitchen does its thing here on thursdays and fridays, but i still have a problem with expensive african food, it just seems twisted, and it makes me feel guilty inside, like how many lives could i have just saved with the $25 dollars it took to get the appetizer plate??
author: Nikki F.

description:
GENERAL
Hip and cool, such that I certainly don't fit the demographic.  :)  Seems to serve beer and wine.  Food looked good, coffee mugs were huge... I had none of this.  Tried to get a cocoa but my buddy thought I said coke...   :(

SEATING
Outdoor patio is big enough and pleasant on a nice day.  Indoors it's like a rather hip club that someone made in to a coffee shop.  Plenty of seating... some funky little autamins, rest are ample couches, tables and chairs.  Has an upstairs and downstairs area, tiered, so it feels really open.  

WHERE THE HELL IS THIS PLACE???
If you go to 1890 Byrant, you will be "where the hell is this place?"  Just round the corner at the starbucks and go 1/2 a block down the hill... there's the entrance!  Sneaky.

HOURS
This place is open until 9pm on  a weeknight... handy for after work meetings with your startup crew.  

AUDIO
Good music, a little noisy, but you can talk.
author: Dan M.

description: Picked up some Vietnamese Iced Coffee before work. Coffee was delicious. Nothing more to say. Had the Cartado from here as well a few weeks ago. It was amazing, but I had a bad coffee crash afterwards.
author: Brian C.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE.  

Best kept secret if you have to study or have work to do.

Unlike Sugar Cafe which is dark and loud with small tables, this place had huge wooden tables to spread out your books and papers, electric outlets for your laptop everywhere, the music was brazilian jazz, and there's a big painting of our president upstairs.

Have not tasted their food but their mochas and teas are delicious and Starbuck's priced.  Thumbs up for the clean bathroom, lots of parking and cute owner.

The only drawback to Coffee Bar is the lack of public transportation around.  More of a destination place.
author: Nezza F.

description:
I'll tell you what I hate about Coffee Bar.  It has completely ruined me for all coffee shops for the rest of my life.  They strike a perfect balance of all things that are important to me: wonderful coffee, free wi-fi, tons of electrical outlets, fantastic music, yummy food and cute patrons.  All of this is set in a beautiful, art-filled  room with a great view of Twin Peaks and Sutro tower.
The owners/staff are also welcoming hosts.  I feel like I'm taken care of with small touches like a second set of menus and a water jug with glasses located upstairs.  It is a great place to work, meet people, sit and enjoy the sunset with a beer.  I wish there were more places like this in San Francisco.
author: Natasha M.

description:
This is my favorite place to work when I need to get out of the home office - and clearly I'm not the only one who feels this way. When I have plans in the City in the evening, I go up to CB and work for the afternoon, and usually by about 1pm almost every seat is taken by someone on a laptop. 

I have been known to work here all day - and I don't even drink coffee! Very spacious, great light, good seating and the food is excellent. Also they serve Dry Soda, which I love even though my wallet doesn't ($3.50 a bottle!). Even better for me: it's not too loud to get work done but it's not so quiet that you can't make the occasional business call. 

The perfect Internet cafe for any home-office warrior who goes stir crazy after too long in the house.
author: Chaney K.

description:
YES -- the coffee is really good
YES -- there is free wifi
YES -- you will be verbally abused just about each and every time you order something from them.  

I work right around the corner from this place and amongst the 25 or so people in my start-up, we've all agreed -- great coffee, fantastic people watching, shitty staff.  

And it's not like it's happened once, right?  No, it's every. single. time.  I've been summarily yelled at for placing a book on a counter, not digging the change out of my pocket fast enough to pay them,  asking a question about the menu.  It's actually like _they kindof don't want my business_

So if you like it rough, and want someone to talk dirty to you each time you order a nonfat latte, this is the real deal.  Fact is, we live in a city with more than enough excellent (and friendly) coffee places, that I'll keep the dirty talk for the bedroom and get my coffee fix elsewhere.
author: Laura K.

description:
Coffee Bar is my favorite neighborhood hang-out, but I'd come here even if it were miles away.  Coffee bar is squeaky clean, has free wi-fi, and plenty of comfortable seating with large tables for working.  Also, I could be wrong, but it seems the baristas are the owners.  If you are looking for a totally perfectionist barista, look no further!  Also, they use Strauss Dairy's organic barista milk.  Strauss cows get to eat pasture for a lot of the year and roam around happy.  The milk most places are feeding you is from grain fed sad cows.

If you're here on a weekend morning and want some breakfast, try the french toast.  It's amazing.  Lunchtime?  No problem ~ their sandwiches are also incredible.  I also really love how I can order wine or beer here if it's evening and I'm not needing the caffeine.

Starbucks across the street on the corner is totally gross compared to Coffee Bar.  I can't believe they haven't run them out of business yet.  It seems like Coffee Bar was opened by a group of friends who got frustrated with sucky coffee shops.  I feel so lucky I only live three blocks from this place.
author: Kimberly B.

description:
This is a great, laid back, HUGE coffee shop, which also happens to have beer and wine. Because, sometimes, you need a a chaser for your coffee. Sensitive folk might need to put up their hipster shields, but seriously, all sorts of people come here, and they all seem comfortable, so you should too.

There is free wifi, and lots of power plugs, making this a great place to get some work done. There is also a lot of natural light, due to the fact that the Southern Wall is almost all windows, so it is bright and cheery - but you may need your sunglasses indoors in some seats. There is also outdoor seating for those sunny warm days.

I haven't tried the Rado Africa Kitchen food YET, but their standard sandwiches are tasty, although perhaps a bit expensive. Still, this is a great coffee shop, which I will return to many times.

Also, Note - it's not on Bryant at all, it's on Florida (the building address is 1890 Bryant, but their address is more like 1891 Florida).
author: neil c.

description: I love this loft-like coffee bar, and am surprised to have not heard of this place earlier! The crowd is pretty eclectic and yes there is a crowd. Fortunately this place is big enough so it does not seem crowded. My house coffee was...meah...ok, but the ham and cheese was pretty good. Free wifi and many electrical outlets make this place great. You'll find business people, people watchers, artists, and yelpers ;) among many other people here. There is an outdoor patio as well for a nice bright day. Although the house coffee is nothing exceptional, I would have still given the coffee bar 5stars (considering I go to cafes to work and for a good environment) but a couple of interactions with the employees did not seem too great. This is my first time here, and Im definitely coming back, so if I find that changes, I will definitely update my review.
author: Vivek N.

description:
Even though there is some pompousness going on here like others mentioned, this is a great place to ACTUALLY get work done.  the inside is very spacious compared to a lot of other coffee shops in the area, and the tables easily fit your laptop and more.

the main upstairs is very relaxing and calm, great naturally lit atmosphere.
and because the coffee bar itself is downstairs, there is no distracting hustle and bustle right next to your table.

tables outside seem more appropriate for those who want to socialize..

drinks seem tasty too.
...not cheap at all, but still tasty.


if the workers seemed nicer it would be an easy 5 stars!
author: eric f.

description:
Great coffee, good breakfast sandwich, bright, upbeat ambiance with lots of room to chill. 

Why only 4 stars? One of the baristas had dirty fingernails.
author: Ree S.

description: Came by with bf and started to drink Chimay. Problem solved and we are super happy about the Friday afternoon drinks. Saw bunch of people bring their laptop and work here... thinking maybe sometimes I will do that too. Huge place, two floors, friendly service and we were sitting at such an amazing people watching spots upstairs, outdoor seats seem nice under the sun. Amazing cafe/ bar. Lovely as heaven....
author: Flora F.

description:
Love the design and the food here, yet it was really crowded and the staffs there were not very friendly.
I went there on a Thursday afternoon because I needed a place to read. Since there were not many cafes around that area, I decided to give this place a try.

Like I expected, it was really CROWDED inside, I could hardly find a seat there, but I love the interior design, the pastry was pretty decent, not surprisingly good, but okay-good. The staff wasn't very friendly, I stood there for like 3 minutes, she didn't even look at me or attempt to help me......
Well, but anyway, I ordered my food and sat down to start reading my book, I noticed that although it was really crowded, but no one talked in the cafe, haha, except for the staffs, there are many Mac books opened and I couldn't see their faces...guess this is a place where Tech people hang out.:D

I may or may not come again...uhm...I don't know, I don't hate it, but I can't say I love it either, I guess I just don't like too many people.
author: Christy Y.

description:
For a long day of sitting and reading/working/people watching, there is no better place.  The tables are huge (if you can get a place at them) and they have a nice selection of snacks and food to nibble on if you find yourself there for extended periods...as I obviously have.

The service as curt and efficient- they're not gonna chat you up to convince you to be a regular, but they will get you a refill for you tea. 

The aesthetic is sleek with awesome photos of all things transportation. Be still my heart. There are also large windows so you can watch the day go from sunrise to sunset while not feeling as crazy as you really are.
author: Jessa L.

description: The staff is extremely helpful and the food is terrific.  My only hesitations about giving this place 5 stars is that because it is an "office" for a lot of people, it doesn't have the full feeling of a neighborhood cafe, even though it could. If you sit outside it has a completely different vibe than inside, so I recommend going on a beautiful sunny day in the Mission.
author: Lori S.

description:
I love Coffee Bar! It's places like this that make me want to throw off the chains of Russian Hill's old-school ways, move to the Mission and hang out in cafes with hipsters all day. Mac in tow, I'd write the most FUCed reviews this city has ever seen.

Coffee Bar looks like an art gallery. Reminiscent of a private loft, it has tall white ceilings where fixtures bounce light and paintings spew color into the room. All of the seating faces in, so eye candy is always on exhibit. Why is it that cafe people are more attractive than the general populace, anyway?

In addition to our espresso drinks we ordered four of the small plates, and nothing disappointed. We had tuna in olive oil on canneli beans and tomato, the cheese plate, artichokes with aioli and the charcuterie plate. This ain't yer average coffee food! In fact, I'd say it's the best I've had.

The owner Luigi, whose pops owns the infamous Mr. Coffee in Oakland, was working behind the counter and served our food. Gotta love a business owner who's passionate, hands on and feeds my addiction at the same time.
author: Nicole G.

description: Extremely disappointing. Was looking forward to my usual decaf iced havana latte with whole milk that I usually get at the Montgomery Street location which is closed on Saturdays.  This was more than a poor substitute.  Iced latte tasted like water with a slight coffee flavor.  I was irritated, but my teen daughter was with me and didn't want to me to talk to them about re-doing it. Besides, the service was bad and the barista wasn't looking too happy, as he was the only one there making coffee.
author: Perlita M.

description:
Fantastic loft-like space with local art on the walls. Seating is upstairs [wheelchair accessible!] and outside too. Free wireless. Lots of outlets along the wall. Big and small tables, plus a few couches. During the day, great natural lighting. At night, not so much. Studying at Coffee Bar in the evening is a strain on the eyes if you're not seated at the large table on the far left corner. I've not yet tried Coffee Bar's food [sandwiches and salads], but the iced tea and coffee are great. For coffee enthusiasts who might be interested in this tidbit, they serve Clover coffee. The wine and beer in the evenings puts the "Bar" in "Coffee Bar." 

Great Thursday/Friday spot! From 6 in the evening, delicious plates are served by Radio Africa & Kitchen [http://radioafricakitchen.com/], a nomadic restaurant. Chef Eskender Aseged often brings the dishes from the kitchen directly to your table himself, and there's a DJ mixing up some African music for the evening. The edamame hummus with green olive oil is a MUST TRY! 

Love is patient and forgiving. With an occasional missed order or a forgotten drink [they are totally wonderful and make up for it when they realize it], I am still forgiving and absolutely in love with this place and the people who work here. The owners are very cool - warm and inviting faces whenever I stop in. Everyone else working here is great too [*cough* eye candy *cough*]. The patrons sharing the space are friendly too. Aside from being a little closer to where I live [it's ~13 miles round trip] and longer hours [although their closing hours aren't too strict], it doesn't get better than this. 

Coffee Bar is my latest great find, and while I would like to keep it a secret, I'm all about sharing too. I'm usually here on my own, so if anyone wants to join me, holla! Parking in the area hasn't been too difficult, and there are buses running along 16th, Potrero, and Bryant. If I was ever to move out of my current living situation, I'd want to move to Potrero Hill because of awesome spots like this one.
author: Tinna H.

description: Theses people really know how to make a great cup of whatever the hell you want.  The lattes I've had there have all been fantastic.  I also really enjoy the arugula salad.
author: Jay R.

description: I like this place a lot. Their food is great and their coffee cups are HUGE. Its a little off the beaten path and can get busy but its worth the extra effort.
author: Jordan P.

description:
Let me establish some background for this review. 

I hate coffee shops.
I don't drink coffee. 
I hate dudes with acoustic guitars singing covers of Dave Mathew's songs.
And I'm just not down with the lingo or 'culture' of coffee. To me, it's just fucking coffee, in the same category as donuts and bagels and other breakfast items.

Last weekend my lady friend dragged me out of the dungeon I call my office to grab a bite and work on some files. After circling the block to find the spot, we walked in to a sea of laptops. Everywhere I looked there were apple logos, focused brows, and people working. The vastness of the space was filled with natural light and outlined by exposed structural elements.  I immediately felt relieved, and by the end of our meal was genuinely comfortable in a coffee shop for the first time in years. 

Coffee Bar is very well designed and the floor-plan and furniture is very accommodating for out of the office work sessions. The food was solid, and the service was prompt and not pretentious. They were playing good music, and I was able to sit still and work for over an hour, which is a rarity for someone like myself. 

Thank you Coffee Bar for giving me hope in coffee shops.
author: Benjamin O.

description: Espresso is good, but I can never seem to get a table due to people camping out with their laptops.  But if you have a MacBook you'll fit right in.
author: Joyce J.

description:
This is a review by a vegetarian

Firstly, though the address says Bryant, this coffee place is at the northeast corner of Florida and Mariposa. It's in a big warehouse building that occupies the entire block, hence the confusion.

How's this for minimalist: right now they still don't have a sign. I had to ask the barrista/manager/ possibly owner what the name was.

$2.80 gets you a pretty decent sized hot chocolate and place to hide from the rain for a while. I like the variety of seating. There are a few bars, two on the higher split level and one on the ground level. There are couches, and tables for two & four. There is one really long table with a bench on one side and chairs on the other. Finally, in a corner this is one huge square table that looks like the meeting place of the group of knights that opposed King Arthur.

Music is a bit too loud for my taste, especially given all the harsh angles of exposed concrete that make everything louder except what you're trying to say or hear. But the music IS pretty good.

The unisex bathroom is large clean and well furbished for a public area.
author: Bob R.

description:
Oh Coffee Bar, my new found love.

Maybe it is the bright open space?
Maybe it is the plentiful electrical outlets and room to work?
Maybe it is free wifi?
Maybe it is the good fairly-priced coffee?
Maybe it is the yummy foods?
Maybe it is the lack of unhealthy snarkiness replaced genuine humanity of the barristas?
Maybe it is the unspoken "No PC's" rule that exists?  Jokes people, sorta.

Maybe it just feels right, good and just?

Oh Coffee Bar, you are in my Top 3 SF Coffee places now!

See you later.  Don't ever change.
author: Bruce R.

description:
Arrgh!

I would generally hafta dock some points for being sooo hip, but honestly they make the best espresso drinks in the bay area. bar none.

I love Blue Bottle n all, but this place is a cut above almost everything I have had outside of some classic cafés in Europe.

The space is nice, too, and very comfortable to sit and chat, or settle down with a laptop or a book.

They really thought out the space as far as encouraging people to work from there, too, as they have generously sprinkled the seating areas with power outlets and provide decently-fast wifi.

The only thing I could take a star off for would be the music - the selections are weird (or I'm not hip enough) and the volume levels are usually a bit higher than desirable for me personally.

But the sunny spot you can find on the couch to curl up in makes up for it =).
author: Derek B.

description:
Love this place.  I'm not at all surprised that the overall rating is 4.5

The space is really open, clean and modern.  They have free wifi (I'm sure as a millie other reviewers have mentioned) and the food is legit!

I've had an organic butter lettuce salad with spiced walnuts, goat cheese, summer peaches and an amazing basil vinegrette.  I'm not a salad lover by any means.  I loved this salad.

Today I had their turkey sandwich...also really good.  Soft bread, thin sliced turkey..avocado...really filling and healthy.  A decent sized portion too..none of that foo foo $9 tiny sandwich crap.  And they carry wine and beer here as well which might be nice for a lazy weekend lunch...

Even though its located in a part of town that I do not usually frequent, I know I'll be back here pretty often.  

Kudos to Coffee Bar.  Oh, but also:  parking can be a BITCH.
author: Genevieve M.

description:
My third visit to Coffee Bar and I feel comfortable bumping them up to five stars. Three of the four dishes we shared today were absolute home runs - the cheese plate with three types of cheese and quince paste, the meat plate (mmm, meat!) and baked artichokes were all fantastic. The tonno in oil was ok but paled in comparison to the other dishes.

My iced chai paired well with the patio and the sunny afternoon. Throw in a couple of puppies out front, a friendly staff and cute hipster girls milling about and Coffee Bar is a fantastic place to waste away a Sunday with friends.
author: phil h.

description:
Coffee Bar is a lovely, light-filled, NEMIZ coffee shop and wine bar.  It takes both its coffee and locally-sourced food very seriously, in that manner typical of SF gourmet establishments--so the attitude is familiar, but its benefits are clearly spelled out in the food and drink.  I went in the morning, so I'll reserve comment on the boozy goods for a later visit.

I had a bacon-chive gougere (from Patisserie Phillipe on Townsend) and a latte:  the gougere had the appropriate contrast of soft and crisp textures and a complex richness that seemed more worthwhile than overindulgent (the small size helped).  I don't normally drink coffee (!), but seeing the serious equipment behind the bar (Clover, exotic espresso machine) I took a chance.  The latte had no trace of bitterness, sugar was unnecessary.  I'm no coffee expert, but this was several steps beyond the Starbucks down the street.

Coffee Bar's particular seriousness of intent has been more common to date in restaurants, and it's welcome in a neighborhood (my neighborhood!) coffee shop/boozery.  That said, if SF restaurants are temples to food, then SF bars and coffee shops are temples to their guests:  their focus is more on creating social spaces than any particular beverage of choice.

Coffee Bar hasn't done poorly there, but they do have some work to do for their ambiance to match their food and drink.  The concrete and steel industrial space is large and welcoming, but comes off a little spartan, especially on a rainy day with few customers.  I love minimalism as much as the next loft-dwelling yupster, but a bit more color, a bit more artwork, and a few more customers would go a long way towards making this cafe/bar feel less like a church/museum.  The staff is very warm and welcoming, as others have noted--now they just need the space to match the warmth of the food and the people.  

I'll be rooting for them.  Yum.
author: Kenneth B.

description:
So, I think there are challenges to accommodating THAT many people, on THAT many laptops, from morning 'til night.  I think Coffee Bar is doing a fabulous job of it.  My favorite things:

1) The plugs EVERYWHERE.  Like I barely ever have to implore the designer people to unplug their macbooks so I can use their outlet.

2) Obviously, the wifi.  It works good!

3) The people watching.  Lots of stylish looks, fashion all over the map but I love a place where people seem creative and are interesting to look at.

4) The food.  I had a Cobb salad at Denny's once and vowed never to order it again.  I broke that rule last week at Coffee Bar and it completely redefined my understanding of Cobb salad.  You gotta try it.  The arugula salad rocks too, though it's heavy on the parmesan, and the sandwiches are not very filling but hella tasty.  Nice pastries, though the tortes are too sweet.

5) The natural light.  Being able to wander around on the patio or sidewalk while I'm on the phone.

6) The succulents garden and local artwork.  Love it!  Cool furniture too!

5) Great service from both counter and kitchen.  People who are friendly and hip, but not hipper than thou.

The wine pours are a little meager but I guess that's for the best -- otherwise I'd really be tempted to start happy hour early!
author: Karen L.

description: Coffee is nice and hot, but the barista didn't know the roast of the beans used... sad. Also, I ordered coffee and a small cookie- no price shown anywhere for the cost of the cookie, thought, it couldn't be more than $2... $2.50?! Really? And I only find out once I've already been rung up and everything is set out. So $4.50 for a coffee and cookie. At least advertise that you sell overly priced food...
author: Amanda S.

description:
suc.cu.lent is one of my favorite words.  it carries with it an oasis filled juiciness that make a long drought of good coffee a forgotten past- right after the first sip!  it was only fitting that the plants that line the entryway and the wall by the stairway were an assortment of succulent plants - thick vibrant leafy varieties contrasting against the gray cement wall.  the modern decor inside was enhanced with huge mural photography of iconic industrial places in san francisco.  generous amount of lighting entered through the wall of window panes and the evening lighting from the retro lamp fixtures and wall chandelier open an invitation to come back later (for the pinot wine tasting perhaps?).

but what makes this a great coffee bar is the third seldom used meaning of succulent:" highly interesting or enjoyable; delectable." the coffee beans come from far exotic places like papua new guinea and bolivia but the effort of grinding and brewing individual coffee make this a worthwhile place to visit.  the 'bar' guy was hospitable and knowledgeable with the coffee selections  and even offered his compliment to each one.  several pastry selections were available as well but I found the apple crisp tarts so wonderfully mouth watering that he too agreed  would be a perfect compliment with the coffee...how could one turn down a crispy philo puff pastry covered with thinly sliced apples fanned across its entire length, sweetened by a film of caramel glaze underneath?  

so the next time you have a craving for something interesting, enjoyable and delectable (yes I am sure there's quite a few other things that come to mind)--add this one to the list--perfect afternoons are as rare as an oasis in the desert.

ps- they do have lunch and sandwiches here as well- maybe a brunch destination as well?
author: Arissa C.

description:
Y'all, this coffee joint is SUCH A FRESH BREATH OF AIR. I've been coming here ever since they reopened and I'm so happy they are here. I work a couple blocks down the road.

Today I went in and had a great coversation with the barista about our home state of Washington. She made me a killer americano with the crema on top (just perfect and how it should be served...none of that throw some water on the espresso shot. she knew how to make one). I was also needing something sweet to eat. You know how it is, the 3 o'clock lull at your desk in need of a jolt of energy...She served me a freshly made chocolate chip cookie that she had stuck through the toaster machine to goo-ify the chocolate. It fucken rocked my world. 

This is a great space for meetings, for solo trips to read the paper or a good book, to sit outside (when to sun comes out again), or to turn on the iPod and draw in your sketchbook.

Go check it out!
author: Matthew M.

description:
I finally got to check this place out after hearing my coworkers approve this place and the awesome environment. I wanted to get a Vietnamese iced coffee but was informed there was no iced coffee left at 3pm in the afternoon on Monday (weird), so I ordered an 8oz drip instead (no frills). Headed upstairs and it's seriously MacWorld here. 

Has a nice library feel since everyone and their Macbooks are spread out everywhere with papers, but much cooler than a library. Seems more like a study/hang place than for a first date/heavy conversation place. Will def. come here again!
author: Cheryl F.

description:
Yay Coffee Bar!  They make excellent espresso drinks that, regrettably, blow the Atlas Cafe out of the water.  The sandwiches are great too, but the kitchen seems understaffed, so be prepared to wait (too long) for your food.  It's strange because there seem to be a lot of employees milling around, which makes you wonder just who's managing the place.  Otherwise, the fact that they take credit cards gives them the advantage over the surrounding cafes that do not, such as: Atlas, Pirate Cat, and Progressive Grounds.

The interior is nice, as are the employees.  The patrons, however, can be a bit ridiculous with the all the laptops and cheesiness... for instance, some guy in line behind me referred to a ham sandwich as a "ham sando"... come on, does it make you feel cool to call a sandwich a "sando", WTH man?  During the lunch hour, at least 50% of the patrons on are laptops or handhelds.

I've been an Atlas Cafe customer for over 10 years, and I'm sorry to say that I'll be taking my business to Coffee Bar for now on... they have higher quality espresso drinks, better food selection, a cleaner interior, generally better service, and if I'm short on cash, I won't have to pay ridiculous fees at an in-store ATM to get cash... cards accepted.
author: Kevin X.

description: Used to be good across the board. Now it's hit-or-miss thanks to the crap-ass attitude of one of the baristas. Call before hand to see if he's working. Ask for the guy with the crap-ass attitude.
author: Chris H.

description:
5 stars for: 
- the beautiful, sunny, wide open, architecturally cool, well designed space
- the plentiful, convenient power outlets so you can stay longer than the life of your computer battery
- the friendly owner Jason, who takes pride in his 3 1/2 week old coffee bar (once a loading dock!)
- easy to connect to, free wireless (see password on your receipt)
- beautiful foamy milk leaf the coffee guy drew on the top of my lattee

4 stars for the *taste* of my lattee.

3 stars for the ham/cheese croissant (maybe it would have been 4 stars if it had been heated up - my fault for not asking, their fault for not offering). 

Also, Jason told me that at night, they serve wine and plates to share, too. He brought me the menu to look at since this is my first time here, and I have to say, it looks like a nice selection of wines, for AFFORDABLE prices (most  glasses between $7-9, and only 4 were in the $10-12 range). I'll definitely come back some evening for a little vino and food sharing, since I love this space so much.  

Thanks Phil H for suggesting I try working here - very cool! 

Now, back to work for me! :)
author: beth l.

description:
While my car was in the shop, we needed to kill some time and I needed to get caffeinated so we came to Coffee Bar.  Wow, it's the prettiest cafe I've been to in a long time.  Pretty in an industrial, loft-like way, of course, considering the location.  

All the seating is upstairs.  Couches, small tables, bar seating and one large table are well placed.  Lots of natural light from all the windows but the light fixtures and photo art they have up are perfect for the space and the sound system  and music selection were excellent.  Even the sound snob was into it.  There is also patio seating out front.  Seriously, I want to live there.

Jason, the owner, was cool and made me an Americano that woke me up right away.  Woo.  Then he showed me the lovely pastries that had just been delivered.  I love him. 

And for the ladies, well, and the gay men: at 8am on a Sunday morning, except for me, there were only men in there.  What a nice way to start a busy Saturday.
author: Seong P.

description:
This quadrant of the Mission boasts a few very stylish eateries (and drinkeries) that also happen to serve up excellent fare. I'm thinking of Universal, Blowfish, The Slow Club and even Circolo.

And Coffee Bar.

The setting is gorgeous. Spare but somehow comfortable. Perhaps it's the sunlight streaming through the big front windows, or the patio out front.

The coffee is first rate, and the food is good too.

And, free WiFi. Always lively but never crowded, it's a great place to work.
author: Shawn S.

description:
When it comes to the upper tier of coffee shops, Coffee Bar has thee best location to eat, power up your laptop, and get your caffeine fix.  Located in between Potrero Hill and the Mission District, 1-2 hour parking can be found fairly easy without having to bring a bunch of quarters.  The high ceiling and indoor/outdoor seating is more accommodating than most coffee locations and it's done in a stylish way, filled with a lot of natural light (really good when working).  

The coffee beans are roasted by Mr. Espresso, which I believe is one of the most potent beans here in SF.  For those that want to drink a high tech cup of joe, Coffee Bar does have the Clover Brewing System.  They have a great menu of lunch items, ranging from sandwiches to pastries.  So when Ritual and Four Barrels gets a little routine or over crowded, head over eastward to Coffee Bar!
author: Jason A.

description: Coffee Bar is great.  I like the oatmeal and the coffee is always good.  I walk several blocks farther from my shop to have coffee here even though there are coffee shops closer.
author: Marty W.

description:
This is a review for their 5 course pre-fix menu with Alex Marsh's Six-Course Dungeness Feast at Coffee Bar.

I had never been to the Coffee Bar before and asked my next door neighbor if he'd like to accompany me.  The menu sounded fabulous and it is only a 5 min drive away from my house.  I thought I should try it.

As soon as we walked in we noticed the fabulous jazz music and a very chic warehouse feel.  It was very modern SOMA vibes entering the Mission.  As soon as we sat down we didn't really like how far the tables were between us.  It wasn't til we started eating we noticed that there were paper napkins and the cutlery wasn't very nice.  The last  entree was prime rib and the knives weren't particularly good for cutting.

On the food side of it.  We were very impressed with Alex Marsh's cuisine.  It was all very small plates and we could've eaten more.  We hope he opens up a restaurant with regular entrees.  The wine pairings on part of Coffee Bar were spectacular.

First course.

Avocado Gazpacho
Dungeness Crab and Tomato

It was very refreshing and delicious.

Second Course

Winter Citrus Salad with crab, mache, and coriander fried meyer lemons

The meyer lemons were the best part of that salad and over it amazing.

Third Course

Spring roll with crab & minced bacon, cucumber, pickled carrot, and fava and a creme creme fraiche sauce

This one was my least favorite.  I thought it was bland and smokey but none the less I still consumed it as it was tasty.

Fourth Course

White Corn Polenta 
Artichoke and crab spiced with ol' bay

This was by far my favorite after the next course.  I love white corn polenta and artichoke.  I could've eaten 3 bowls of this.

The Fifth course was prime rib, crab sauce, and collard greens.  The prime rib was really small.  I was also wondering if they are supposed to leave the fat on.  We both had to take out this big white chunk that was not very delightful to look at when the plate was empty.

Dessert were this amazingly fresh donut holes with an apricot sauce.

My favorite wine was the Semillon.  During the pairing I had a really nice Prosecco and Pinot Noir at the end from Russian River Valley.  

For dessert a very nice Sancerres.

My neighbor was still hungry after spending so much money and had to get a slice of pizza on 22nd.  

It was a very nice meal.  I would suggest the chef do it else where and add larger portions.  I like the fact that it felt like an Italian style meal in regards to length.  It took us 2.5 hrs and I think that's how a nice dinner should be enjoyed.
author: Sabrina A.

description:
I am a coffee (and coffeehouse) snob. As a friend from Chicago who called me yesterday noted, I'm almost always in a cafe when he calls me. 

Today I have been working all afternoon from Coffee Bar and it is rapidly going to be one of my favorite cafes in the city, especially for productive afternoons working or meeting with people. My other favorite cafes - Ritual Roasters on Valencia and Blue Bottle Cafe on Mint have their appeal (though Blue Bottle which I think has by far the best coffee in the city and perhaps in the country, doesn't have wifi), Coffee Bar is probably the best of the three for being productive and especially for business meetings. 

I don't get the complaints of some Yelpers about the coffee or the prices - yes, these are not bargain prices, but neither are they particularly high (and the $3 for a Clover cup of coffee prepared quite well is actually a bargain). I had a cappuccino with a Madeline when I first got here - both were excellent and then now I'm enjoying a magnificent Clover coffee and one of their great small plates (anchovies over shaved fennel and oranges - a perfect afternoon light meal). 

When I see a new cafe beyond the coffee which is of course key, a personal measure of a place is the size of the tables. Small, traditional "cafe" tables usually create a space with few people sharing tables, are not conducive to laptop use or spreading out and working. In contrast a cafe with larger tables, easily shared, and with one or more great  big group tables is a cafe whih is designed with working in mind. And further, a cafe with tables than physically can accomodate groups is a cafe where people are that much more likely to talk with each other. 

Coffee Bar has by far the best and largest selection of shareable group tables I've seen in a very very long time. Three large tables each designed to easily accomodate 8-12 people around them on the large, comfortable benches, as well as a large couch seating area and a row of large tables along another wall which can easily also accommodate multiple groups. Plus two large bars along the edge of the balcony which are well designed for individuals with laptops to use and work at. 

Overall a space that also due to the very high ceilings is extremely well suited for groups to work together, while also working very well for individuals. Unlike Ritual Roasters which often suffers from a lack of available tables and tends to be very loud due to the relatively small space and cramped layout, Coffee Bar's two levels plus outside space (and I think a further private room) make for a much quieter space where multiple groups can be talking and working at nearby tables and I can still hear myself think, could even take a phone call if I needed to. 

In terms of the crowd Coffee Bar seems to appeal to a slightly older crowd (I'm sure the wine and beer help here, as well as the location). I would guess that most of the people in the space a the moment (about 40 people or so) are in their mid-30's. A professional and graduate student crowd vs. the more hipster crowd at Ritual Roasters. And I don't know how the crowd changes on the weekends, but at the moment at least there are a lot of women working in groups or by themselves and about a 50/50 ratio of men to women.

I don't live near Potrero Hill (I live in Noe Valley) but Coffee Bar is great enough that I fully plan on shifting my patterns to work here many afternoons.
author: Shannon C.

description:
WHOA someone's giving Starbucks a run for their money !!! Shiiit!

I go to the neighboring Starbucks for grab and go style coffee, but when I have time to hang, I'll probably stop at Coffee Bar. Note that the entrance is not on Bryant, but directly on the corner of Florida and Mariposa. They don't have a sign up yet, but they are apparently getting one next week...spot them by their cute red bistro tables outside. 

The space is very desgin-y and fits in well with the neighborhood. Visually, it almost looks more like a high end restaurant than it does a cafe. The cashier was super friendly and answered all my questions. I got a single latte, although their menu says that all shots are double, I asked for a single and was obliged. They use strause organic milk for all their drinks. The latte reminded me very much of the lattes at Ritual, complete with a cute design in the foam. 

They also have an extensive wine list, as well as an offering of pastries, sandwiches, soups, and other light bites. I'll probably try the food, next. I could definitely see myself coming here for a few hours and getting some work done. There was mostly a very professional-looking crowd there today, we felt a little out of place in our gym clothes...no one else seemed to care, though!
author: Shannon R.

description: Don't dare go in with a child - dogs get a better reception!
author: Jo H.

description: In short, rude staff members. I went to grab a quick iced mocha and head out. It was bright outside and I couldn't make out the brightness of the iPad screen on which I signed; I didn't have to wait in a line so it all happened really fast. I didn't have cash on me to tip and they gave me my mocha after 3 other orders behind me. Sorry that I didn't have cash on that particular moment. I am hopeful as people in this city are much better compared to people I have seen in New York City. However this coffee bar brought me back to my New York days; facing disgruntled employees who act indifferent. It shouldn't be like New York where most establishments care about profit, which in turn is reflected by the incompetent and ill mannered employees. I have worked in the service industry to support myself in NYC and I speak from experience. We should take our employment seriously during these hard economic times especially in California. This is to the employees of this coffee shop: when you walk to your car or to the Bart station through the Mission, please count the number of people shit out of luck on the streets!
author: Galib S.

description: Feels like an Apple store crossed with a trendy downtown bistro. One of the best spots around for a working lunch, so expect a laptop-to-customer ratio of nearly 1:1. Good food.
author: Nick R.

description:
Finally found the spot I can get good coffee at and get some work done or just read after leaving the office.  Was relieved to find Coffee Bar after trying other coffee spots in the Mission that quickly made it evident that I just didn't belong there because I wear slacks and a pressed, buttoned shirt to work or because I like to sit on chairs/couches that don't give me the distinct impression that said slacks are going to get up with food or another person's funk clinging to them.  

Coffee Bar can do the basics really well and always has unique coffee and tea offerings that make you occassionally venture out of your go-to zone.  Great sandwiches and salads make it a great spot to grab a light dinner as well.  They play great music at a reasonable volume, the space has an awesome layout, and everybody seems to have a purpose for being there other than to be seen not looking like they're trying to be seen (you know what I'm talking about!)  A new friend of mine told me that the MissionMission blog recently chose a slogan for the neighborhood:  "The Mission: Where latinos and hipsters politely ignore each other's existence."  CoffeeBar just feels normal, with no Mission stereotypes being perpetuated, just a solid place to go for coffee.  I just wish they would stay open past 8PM during the early part of the week (9PM would do fine!)
author: Dareyn S.

description: Cute bar in a urban, growing neighborhood with friendly staff.
author: Janet L.

description:
Love this place. Great coffee, nice, bright & clean interior, delicious food and friendly service. I come here to get work done on my laptop, and this is one of the few places where I can concentrate...

Oh and great music all the time...

I would love to find more places exactly like this in San Francisco, so if you have a tip, let me know...
author: Marc L.

description:
As a coffee snob from the Northwest I can say this is definitely one of the better coffee shops in SF. Great coffee and original menu.  Plus they have great evenings events.  
Check out Saturday evening Homemade Ramen.
author: A P.

description:
Coffee Bar is in such a cool space!  I'd like to live in a space like that.  The atmosphere is very hip and laid back - a cool hang-out place.  The coffee is pretty good.  The sandwiches are ok but a bit pricey.  I love their ham & cheese croissant and chocolate croissant.    Whenever I'm in the neighborhood, I try to stop by for a latte.

Parking can be very challenging during the weekdays.
author: Y K.

description: Good coffee. Solid selection of food from local bakeries, sandwich shops, donut shops and more. Free WiFi. Cool environment. Friendly staff.
author: Paco A.

description:
After hearing about this place for awhile, I finally check it out and was duly impressed.  

Very cool interior, great coffee and food but good luck finding a place to park your butt!  It was so packed and even though I walked around with my little plate of food looking forlornly, the hoards of laptop users couldn't be bothered to look up, let alone give up there seat to a gal in need.

*Sigh*

So I sat outside in the cold.  But I had hot coffee.
author: Suzanne L.

description:
I love I love I love. Except no syrups. The diesel turkey sandwich, and the almond croissants are heavenly. Cool atmosphere. I work nearby and they totally know what I want, and the girl with the dark hair is cute. Plus, the first time I went in, Jason gave me a heart on the top of my latte. I have met great people while dining there, because they also serve alcohol. HOME RUN!  Oh yeah, and did I mention Radio Africa?
Every Thursday and Friday they have this awesome nomadic-fusion restaurant and great DJ. I HIGHLY SUGGEST RADIO AFRICA.
author: Kiki C.

description:
Top notch! I'm so glad this place opened up in my 'hood. I had a great au lait and the toasted peanut butter and fig jam sandwich. (I'm vegan, and definitely appreciate that they had something on the menu I can eat.) I am personally a huge fan of the clean, spare decor, although I do think that slightly warmer lighting would be a positive change. 

The owner & staff were friendly and helpful.
author: Ellen B.

description:
Coffee 4 stars
Delicious baked goodies 5 stars
Healthy alternatives 5 stars
Service 1 stars UPDATED to 2 stars
Weighted average = 3 stars

UPDATE BELOW:

*If you want to skip the rant, I sum it up at the bottom*

Ok here is the thing.  Yeah it is a bit on the yuppie hipster side, and it is pricey.  These are things I can over look because it has some of the best coffee I have found in that area, and the food is delicious

The biggest problem is the blonde chic.  You will be able to spot her a mile away.  Tall lanky, SO boho hipster that she can't smile because that would be so uncool.  yuck.

The first time I visited she was cold and slightly rude, not a typical atmosphere for a coffee shop, but I thought "meh it is my first time and maybe it was a rough morning for her". 

The second time I visited she made it clear that dealing with us (customers) was SOOOO tramatic that it made her hate life.  I thought, "Wow!  her attitude about life sucks" and I kind of pitied her.

Then I went a few times when just the guys were working - super nice, fun, and helpful (The reason that service gets a star at all).  The kind of thing you normally expected out of an establishment and I thought "cool this place is that hipster type coffee shop that serves up high-end offerings, but welcomes all types - YAY"

And then she reappeared, serving only those she liked in the line (who knew she could feel!).  I normally tip big, but whenever she is working I don't because I have worked in several coffee shops and I know that the tips are usually split amongst all.

Basically, she is some either that is just a plain old rude little girl - OR has major probs in her life and doesn't know how to not let if effect her at work.  Either way, check out the Coffee Bar for amazing fruit, granola, and yogurt cup, almond toast, strong coffee, good sandwiches, and such.  Just avoid her if you see her, you never know if one wrong question might make her start throwing things!


UPDATED!!!!!  EXTRA EXTRA READ ALL ABOUT IT.

Ok, since I work 4 blocks from here, I have not stopped visiting the Coffee Bar despite the aforementioned chic.  To my surprise I have NOT seen her there on 3 subsequent occasions.  Instead I have encounter a super cool brunette who is friendly AND helpful... how exciting.  The people seem to really be working on creating a friendly atmosphere.
I am upping my initial 2 star rating to 3, if it appears this is not a fluke then the Coffee Bar with rise to 4 stars where it belongs.
author: Becky T.

description: Great place to get work done; I love the sign outside.  Parking is easy.  I haven't had their coffee yet; just their hot chocolate (which was so-so).  The place looks awesome.
author: Erika C.

description:
Just attended a reception held there, it was awesome.  the atmosphere was so fun, the building is beautiful, and the food was so nice.

Interesting spot for a reception, but worked out great!
author: Amy V.

description:
As many of you know, I am a charter member of the Starbucks-Should-Rot-in Holy-Hell movement ("Yes We Can") as evidenced by my somewhat emotional Yelp review of my hometown's Starbucks (http://tinyurl.com/24lzom).

Coffee Bar, in spite of it's remarkably generic name, is a Great Addition to our Potrero-Mission-Hybrid-Hood. Yelpers, I am in fact taken by how brilliantly they have opened one mere block from the Hated-Death-Star-Starbucks, and are scooping up the locals. I am so taken I even blogged about it here: http://tinyurl.com/225oj7
