Now that we have established I love Coffee Bar, let's focus on the problems. There's one.  How Generic can you get? Coffee Bar? Did the Naming Committee meet for more than 30 seconds? Was I invited? Are you guys seriously ADD or just can't focus for more than 30 seconds?

I know: Coffee in the day; Bar at night. How clever. Frankly I don't care. I'm on my way. Triple Espresso Please, the ADD Special. :-)
author: Jeff W.

description:
This place is great. I'm really starting to dig the Twilight Zone feeling of this neighborhood.. burnt out smoke stacks and web 1.0 company spaces slowly being taken over by new growth of small and varied businesses.

Iced coffee was yummy, with hints of cardamom and other spices that gave it Turkish undertones. The space is aesthetically pleasing, with good lighting and design. The free wifi is enticing, as is evident by the inevitable wall of MacBooks you'll see upstairs when you first enter the building. They also serve good food and Dynamo doughnuts. The scene struck me as friendly and more welcoming than attitude-laden places like Ritual.

You'd never notice this place biking or walking by, as it has an opaque fence in front of it. It also shares the same address as the block-long building it's in, so it is actually on the corner of Florida and Mariposa. Definitely something to address (pun intended) lest they lose potential Yelpers looking in vain for the business on the unfriendly Bryant-facing facade of the building.

Another great addition to the neighborhood.
author: Eric G.

description:
Mission Stop Numero Dos: Coffee Bar

With food in our bellies and mimosas still a-lingering, L and I decided that a stroll all the way over to Coffee Bar would be a good idea.

And a good idea it was. 

It took a bit of figuring out to locate Coffee Bar. Don't be fooled by their puzzling address, which leads to an apartment or business-like building entrance. They're actually located around the corner on Mariposa St. Once we stepped into their patio area and into the bar, I instantly fell in love with the place. This hidden spot, tucked off the beaten Mission path, is a little oasis for everyone who wants to either just chill or get some work done.

There's plenty of seating available: counter-style seating, tables & a couple big, comfy couches- a big gigantic plus in my book. The atmosphere is perfect. I don't know if it's just cuz it was a Sunday, but everyone seemed real laxidasical. The baristas didn't seem all stressy or grumpy, just completely pleasant. The loft-like space really works for them and the outdoor seating is ideal for a warm day reading the paper w/ your pup in tow. The faux window w/ a shot of the Muni Bus yard behind the baristas is neat, plus another view of some East Bay structures, which were both very locals-themed. 

Coffee Bar was just the place I was looking for to sip on an Iced Limonata, melt into a sofa, and curl up w/ a book. I noticed that the popular Radio Africa & Kitchen drops in on Thurs & Fri's to serve some of their food. What a treat! They also host movie nights w/ themed bites to nibble on, beers, and bubbly! 

I couldn't be more smitten w/ them. 5, big ol' shining stars for Coffee Bar.
author: Tiffany M.

description:
Coffee Bar is pretty much everything you'd want in a café.  In the daytime, it's superb both as a work place and a place to meet up with a friend for coffee or a relaxed lunch.  In the evening, the space takes on a certain quiet San Francisco urban sexiness and becomes a fantastic place for a glass of wine, or even an intimate conversational dinner if it's a Thursday or Friday (when the Radio Africa Kitchen prepares a menu). It's a beautiful open loft space with abundant natural light, seating above and bar below.  There are plenty of large tables, but the wonderful long bars - made from the same glossy birch and with ample outlets underneath - are my favorite place to sit, looking down below to coffee preparation.  I adore the oversized prints of the Oakland ports, which only add to my Seattle nostalgia when I'm here.

The real source of my nostalgia (and, after all, the point of the bar), however, is the coffee, which is simply fantastic.  Forced to keep score, I'd say on an average day it's just below Blue Bottle and Four Barrel, and just above Ritual for my taste.  I've had Mr. Espresso elsewhere, but no where else seems to get it nearly as good as Coffee Bar.  This makes some sense in light of one of the owners also being a Mr. Espresso owner.  But honestly: it's *so much better* than Mr. Espresso coffee I've had at other cafes around town that I'm sort of amazed that it's the same stuff.  On a good day, their Neapolitan blend produces a cup of something that makes me immensely grateful for being alive, down to the very last sip.

I tend not to order off of the lunch menu since it doesn't excite me much; the food seems well-prepared, just a bit unimaginative, but sometimes simple and well-prepared is something to be grateful for, especially when the ingredients are of high-quality (which they are).  I've tried a few of the small plates in the evening with a glass of wine (the artichokes, the tuna with cannellini beans); both were good, a better option than the lunch fare if you tire (as I do) of salads, soups, and sandwiches that you could make at home for less than half the cost.  The real food treat here, though, is the Radio Africa Kitchen, which I highly recommend checking out.
author: Lulu W.

description:
Coffee Bar is not in the best neighborhood, but, you can always find a parking spot. We love the lighting, high ceilings and clover coffee here. They also have seating outside, so, if the weather is nice, its fantastic. However, if there is too much sun, they have no umbrellas or anything.

I always get a coffee from their "clover" machine. A pretty hefty cup is $3 and you choose from a selection of about 4 beans. I never feel rushed at Coffee Bar (if I can get a seat). I can sit all day and I've even found outlets for my laptop.
author: Joan L.

description: Coffee is good (particularly the Vietnamese Iced Coffee) but the service is slooooooow. It's a nice space with yummy food but the service (or slowness of it) really annoys me.
author: Ben L.

description: Best coffee shop in SF, hands down. Amazing coffee, beer, wine, food, and daily specials. It's a great place to work as well - lots of seating with outlets and wifi. The natural lighting is so very nice and the music selection is perfect. Stop in!
author: Max E.

description:
Love this place. I'm a coffee shop lover and have checked out 15 or so around the city (have the time since I work remotely at home or places with internet like this one) and this is one of my top choices. And this is my first visit!

Great atmosphere - industrial and chic, spacious, good lighting, peaceful. Friendly staff, good coffee and food (sopressata sandwich and organic veggie soup with chard and butternut squash), free wifi. The only two set-backs: wish it was busier/more social (but it is a Monday) and it still doesn't compare to my all-time favorite coffee shop (Tryst in Washington, DC).
author: Cyndie H.

description:
The place is lovely, inside and out. Latte was quite nice, barista was polite. 

Cloudy at home but sunshine here. Why I no bring sunglasses? Mildly frightening to look up and see wall to wall macbooks, no room to fit donut. Think imma walk in there with my 4" thick DELL next week, nestle it in between macbook number 5 and 6, and get me some work done.
author: D'arcy N.

description:
The best thing about Coffee Bar is the space itself - open and airy and perfect for those looking for a place to work.  There are outlets under the bar tables and free wifi.  The outdoor patio is great for those just meeting up with friends.
Not a huge selection of food or pastries - and I can't comment on the coffee :)  
Parking was surprisingly hard to find and expensive ($2 an hour for street parking).
author: Cathy L.

description:
I feel soo SF in here!  I'm truly glad they are in the hood, right down the street from my work.  
Serves as a cozy little get away from the modern, airy aesthetic of my loft-warehouse-office-space: Just Kidding! 
It's as sleek and sexy as can be, for a coffee bar.  I can tell they were really trying, like really...but then the barista, not the guy taking the orders and chatting everyone up, but the grunt work guy- was so slow, I think he needed a shot or two.  
I applaud the Coffee Bar and their wine list.  I think I might like them more for the wine and sparkles than the coffee, actually. 
Love the succulents. Can I get a cutting?
author: Melissa B.

description:
I come here a few times a week.  I heart Coffee Bar!

My drink of choice of is the Soy Cappuccino.  The world is definitely changing when I can stumble across a top-notch cappuccino in my neighborhood.  I prefer to go to non-chain shops.  

Coffee Bar has, by far, the best Soy Capp in SF.  

Everything about this place is good.  Breakfast, lunch and dinner.

oh and customer service is awesome!  They deserve every bit of success.
author: Delilah B.

description:
It's a hidden spot where the entrance isn't found by looking at the address.  Turn down Mariposa St. and on the corner of Florida St. you'll find the way in.  The birch colored wood lining the second level was especially nice.  The owner, Jason Paul (yes two first names), promised it wasn't Ikea wood but the real deal.

They had a wine event last evening, which they'll probably be having more often given how many people showed up.  We stayed back at the bar drinking champagne and eating sandwiches.  The food is good but priced a bit on the high-end for what you get.  It is though comparable to other wine bar prices.  I hear the coffee is wonderful but haven't had a chance to try it yet.  Next time..
author: Kimmie N.

description:
I frequent this joint regularly, it's pretty hit or miss.  Staff is friendly enough and their coffee is decent. 

At my most recent visit I ordered the mushroom soup, hoping for a cream of mushroom concoction. What I got was a giant, sad bowl of oily water, uncooked carrots and partially rehydrated mushrooms. Bleh. 

For veg-friendly diners, go with the grilled cheese.  The fruit salad is also a winner. Real fruit! None of that bummer cantaloupe and honeydew mush you'd get other spots.
author: meghan l.

description:
This is one coffee shop done right! They continue to amaze me with their quality and creativity. First off, the space is incredible. Take a moment to look around and appreciate the tiny little touches that add character to the place. Secondly, they utilize everything they got. They're an amazing cafe by day and transform into the Radio Africa Kitchen at night (Thurs and Fri only). I've heard a few different people throw private parties there and I think that's a fantastic idea. I'm just searching for a reason to reserve the space now. 

Tips: Lattes and cappuccinos are perfection (don't ask for flavored syrup!). If you're hungry, get the turkey sandwich. If you're not hungry, grab one of those little blueberry thingamajigs. They are damn tasty! 

The word is out and now it's always crowded. No real solution to that - you just have to go and see if you get lucky for a seat. Bold statement, but Coffee Bar just might be good enough to keep me in the Mission for a very long time. It's THAT worth it.
author: Susan L.

description:
It pains me to write this but my love affair with Coffee Bar as the go-to place for home-based workaholics needing a daily escape to eat, drink, work, meet colleagues and socialize has come to an end. Yes,  I will miss the slightly edgy, urban, frenetic atmosphere that has well suited my mild ADD for months (or has it been years?), but alas, I can't patronize an establishment where my business means so little. Everyone has their tipping point. Mine wasn't the sudden policy change from low cost to full price refills on drinks, or the constant wireless access issues, or the oft rude baristas who'd sneer skeptically when asked to make up for the frequent-buyer-card stamp they'd overlooked or mention that your lunch order had come out wrong--no, I've accepted these customer faux pas as the standard operating procedure that comes with a business recognizing that they have you hooked and that you're bound to come back no matter what they throw your way. However, today the spell was broken: I came in mid-day and could find nowhere "legal" to sit. One staff person, seeing my dilemma and my computer, invited me to use one of the several coveted (yet empty) "no-computers-during-lunch" tables. I ordered my lunch and got down to work. Just as I settled in, another staff person approached and asked me to relocate, wagging his finger voraciously at the sign on the table (as if I should know better) while claiming he didn't make the rules. I explained that I'd been kindly invited to use the table by his colleague as there was no place else to sit. He persisted (grumbling under his breath a question about whether the invitation had come from "kitchen staff"-- note-- I won't even go into the blatant classism associated with that question); I mentioned the large amount of money I'd dropped on the place daily, and he invited me to spend my money elsewhere. My view: any self respecting business person that could muster even the smallest amount of appreciation for paying customers (regular or not) would simply, and graciously, have sucked it up, apologized for the inconvenience, and dealt with his frustration about exceptions to rules internally and behind the scenes at the next staff meeting.  

So, I figure now is a good time to take this guy up on his offer.  If the Coffee Bar people want to find me  (which I am sure they don't), at least in the short term, they can check out the not-quite-so-hip and politically incorrect Starbucks across the street where the baristas couldn't be nicer, there are plenty of comfy seats. AC outlets are plentiful, the wireless almost never goes down, I can get hot or cold drinks any way I want them for half the price of CB with close-to-free refills, the temperature is pleasant and constant, and a steady jazz rhythm plays at a reasonable volume to keep me entertained and awake. It is really too bad that a successful business can get so into itself that it stops seeing its paying customers as its greatest asset.
author: Tori S.

description: Nice people that work there, nice place to work and friendly strangers. Only one star off for switching to dinner service at 7??? Still not sure if that is correct.
author: Chris S.

description: Great atmosphere, lot's of space, great espresso (though it can vary a little bit depending on the barista...), great food, and really friendly workers.  I love going here, grabbing a table, and getting some work done.
author: Tom J.

description:
Coffee Bar is a great place to study for three reasons: (1) lots of laptop outlets, (2) ample natural light, (3) good Americanos (referring to both the drink and the people).  Two characteristics, however, prevent me from giving it five stars: (1) drafty and (2) can get crowded pretty quickly. 

As to the laptop outlets, they're all over the place.  They might as well have a statute out front with the inscription, "Give me your tired, your poor, your huddled masses yearning for electricity."  

There are huge windows that allow a flood of light in.  As someone who is often stuck indoors, the natural light makes me feel like I'm outdoors.  There's nothing wrong with pretending, right? 

Third, the people and coffee are good.  That's a plus. 

But as to my concerns, they're admittedly not Coffee Bar's fault.  First off, the place is like a cold-blooded animal: if it's cold outside, it's cooler inside; and I assume that if it's warm outside, the same effect holds.  No big deal.  Just a warning for folks to bring their fleece.  Second, perhaps as a byproduct of the place's success, the place gets crowded quickly.  Was here on a Monday morning, and the place was pretty crowded by 9:30 a.m.  There were still spots, but get here early.  

Solid place.  I'll be back.
author: Marc P.

description: Good coffee and atmosphere, the kind of place you can hang out at for a few hours.
author: Amy A.

description:
Okay, I have to say I love this place.  Mainly because I've trained myself to work here.  It's like I'm on autopilot.  I order my drink and/or food, then I buckle in with the laptop and zoom!  Yes, there are lots of folks and sometimes they run out of seating.  One time my friend and I sat across the room from each other.  It was okay though; we both had stuff to do.  

The staff is friendly, and everyone is generally working on a laptop.  The food is good enough.  Oh, the music is great!  Urbanish-hiphopish a la folksy, indie and sometimes retro groove.  I especially like their taste because it's never too loud like Ritual Coffee.  I tend to get bumped and bounced right outside of Ritual with their music.  I just wish this place was open later.
author: Monikah B.

description: Five stars for a modern and functional space AND great lattes and sandwiches.  The interior is designed like a lofty workspace, stocked with plenty of tables and outlets.
author: Jenny K.

description: This is a very trendy style coffee store. Every where you look there are people with their apple computers holding up the chairs. So this makes it hard to find a chair. I ordered a Turkey with bacon sandwich. It came with a salad. The sandwich was warm and the salad was good. Next time I am in this part of town I will stop by and get another sandwich (to go).
author: Don and Regina S.

description:
Excellent place to get some work done. So long as that work doesn't require a desk or a phone. Since Jimi Hendrix's greatest hits was just a bit too loud on the overhead speakers and every table and outlet in the place was taken.

That being said, wi-fi is free, location is great, couch is comfortable and staff is friendly. Oh yeah, and the coffee isn't too bad either. Taking into account that I'm not really a coffee guy, more of a free wi-fi whore when traveling, that's saying something.

Clearly, I'm not the first person to dig this place, but being from San Diego and frequenting a few coffee shops in my day, Coffee Bar did not disappoint. 

Again... if I could only hear the person on the other end of the phone.
author: James G.

description:
Almost makes the top of my list... of shameless free internet users.

Its a large space with high ceilings so it gives a good sense of spaciousness.. lots of places to sit and plug in your laptop. If you are part of that crowd (which I certainly am)... seeing other people at work adds to the atmosphere and perhaps motivates me to work which I like.

Yay!:
1. Lots of seating
2. Lots of power outlets
3. Relatively chill atmosphere
4. Enough coffee and snacks to keep me happy

Boo!:
1. Can get crowded

So overall I would rate this place pretty highly
author: Krishnan S.

description:
My boyfriend and I dropped by Coffee Bar last Thursday for a drink before dinner at Universal Cafe up the street.  Walking in was like stepping into an Apple Store/Ikea/coffee shop//loft apartment with the soaring ceilings, white walls, blonde wood tables, bright light and multiple levels.  Frankly I was stunned they served wine... It seems that most places that serve alcohol keep the lights low.  We joked that they should put a dimmer on that light bulb sculpture on the wall.  I love the couple of big plants that soften it up (maybe they keep the lights up for the plants!)

The staff was very friendly and eager to help, maybe too much- it felt like they didn't quite have the confidence yet for their new place.  The wine list is nice- good selection by the glass and bottle.  I love when a place offers more than one bubbly by the glass!  I had an excellent Roederer Estate sparkling Rose which tasted better after sitting out for 20 minutes (coolers a tad cold for wine...)  

I love the neighborhood and that place wasn't crazy full of the obnoxious wine bar crowd (I work near District and never go because I dislike that type of crowd).  It's close to some awesome restaurants (slow club, universal cafe, blowfish sushi) and you can always find parking. 

One thing about this place was that all the patrons appeared to be there for a purpose, like they were conducting important work.  A lot of people had laptops, uncommon in a wine bar but common in a coffee house. Maybe the bright light...

I'll definately come again, maybe bringing a business colleague for a glass of red. (or just some pals)
author: Kate T.

description:
Airy and spacious
Free wireless
Super friendly staff
Front patio
Open all day and night
Organic ingredients
Pretty decent+ food
Wine!
author: Melanie C.

description:
Part cafe, part bar, part restaurant: an awesome combination in a cool loft space.  Went here on a Friday evening and couldn't believe the Starbucks across the street was full with a gem like this nearby.  I just went in for some coffee and to do some work on my laptop.  Jason, the owner, was behind the bar and was really welcoming and nice and encouraged me to order something to eat from Radio Africa & Kitchen (http://www.radioafricakitchen.com/).  I got the edamame hummus, and it was great, but what was even better was the big hunks of bread that came with it...which they replenished without me even having to ask.  The Clover coffee was great too.

Since I came in at dinnertime, all the tables were set, so I had to move the plates over to set my laptop down and felt a little awkward about that, but no one seemed to mind.

I'll definitely be back!  (Hopefully with friends for dinner and a glass of wine rather than by myself with my laptop and work to do.)
author: Gina K.

description:
Whats with the dissing on ARC? I liked ARC, they had good food and chai lattes. 

That being said, the people who run Coffee Bar are much nicer than the people who ran ARC. I definitely don't miss being served by the cooler-than-thou staff that ran that place. Fucking trendy cumsluts that they were. The guy at Coffee Bar (next time I'll get his name so he doesn't have to be "that guy" anymore) actually remembered me, which was cool because I am a pretty nondescript person. 

I work down the street at the Hound Lounge so I'll probably try more of their stuff as time goes on, but of what I have had their peanut butter and fig jam sandwich is very good indeed, as is their fruit salad. They had some type of fruit in their fruit salad that I didn't recognize, but it was SO good. I'll definitely be back for more of this place.

Hooray for someplace good that I can make it to during my ten minute break!
author: Slasha S.

description: Sit at the bar on the second floor to watch people come and go, spicy house-made chai, sunshine streaming in the tall windows...
author: Elizabeth M.

description:
Best latte in San Francisco. No contest. I am procrastinating at this very moment writing this review as I sit on one of Coffee Bar's heavenly like sofas. I am big on coffee and coffee shops in the City. I have South American blood and I spent a fair amount of time in Western Euro Land, so coffee is a real big deal to me. This place lives up to the hype and then some. It's not as pretentious as I was expecting it to be. It's perfect. Great music, friendly-cute baristas, and plentiful, peaceful workplace. 

Orgasmic....wow did I really just type that?  Yes, I did. It's THAT good!
author: A H.

description: Generally very good-to-great espresso drinks, good food, decent wi-fi.  Often very crowded, few seats available, and even fewer outlets.
author: Ari M.

description:
i like this place. 
Coffee and atmosphere are nice.
Lots of 'too cool for school' looking people zombied out on their laptop computers.

Was taken aback when the barista seemed to encourage me to get my coffee to go. Was it due to my square appearance wearing Brooks Bros tie, starched white shirt, and slacks?
author: M E.

description: Johnny O. has been hyping this place up to me for quite some time now. I finally found a free day in my schedule to spend some leisure time in SF and hit this place up. Let just say I wasn't disappointed in the least.  The Papua New Guinea Clover Coffee was outstanding. So rich and full bodied. Their pastries, especially the apple strip, is outstanding too. The music piping throughout the coffee shop is nice and relaxing. All the baristas are hella cool folks. While your waiting for your coffee you can nosh on some dried fruit and admire the mechanical process of the clover machine; I want one now.
author: Marco M.

description:
Best damn cup of joe in the city! Pass up on that hum drum Starbucks down the street and venture to a place that makes REAL coffee. That Clover coffee machine is pure magic! Don't forget about the menu - ordered the cured meats with fig jelly and cornichons. Very nice.

Although the address is on Bryant Street, the doors are open on the corner of Florida and Mariposa. Best to go for a happy hour and after evenings. The posh open space is perfect for large groups of people.
author: Judy L.

description:
Well Im only giving 3 stars why because that's all they deserve I understand the concept Coffee/bar yeah what ever I expected a little more. We went at night so we could try the wine bar portion it was okay a
little IKEAISH for my taste though. I like that it is big and the fact that they have free wi-fi but my experience was nothing to write home about.

The waiter our order by sitting down across from us like we invited you..He was slow I had to ask for the plates that we did order which had been already finished for a while

On top of that he was one of the owners maybe he has never done table service in the past anyways it's not somewhere I would hang out at..Although he did suggest a coffee that was so good I drank it black

Wine was just okay
author: Kim R.

description:
Nice coffee place. Good quality coffee and teas. Big and spacious.
Free wifi and plenty of outlets. If you want to sit outside, there are sunny spots for you too.
It's the perfect "work from home" office space.
I noticed that the majority of laptops here are Macs... it's good to feel at home.
Have to try their food next time.
This place gets packed.... be patient, eventually you'll get a place to sit.
I really like the music they play! From Samba to Trip-Hop.
author: Geordie E.

description:
First of all, the only coffeeshop I found at the corner of 1890 Bryant was a Starbucks. I was like wtf? Then I realized that was just the mailing address. The physical location of Coffee Bar is actually on Florida and Mariposa, just down the block (right across the street from Circolo, one of my favs).

I'll admit I'm not really a coffee drinker, but I had a pile of donuts from Dynamo (I didn't know they already sold Dynamo donuts at Coffee Bar....that just makes them even more awesome!) and I needed something to wash down all the sugar. 

What I found at Coffee Bar was a great, not-so-little coffee shop. It made me wish I lived next door cuz this would be a great place to read the paper, study, and hop online on their free wi-fi. The workers are super friendly and props to them for their excellent latte art. Again, I'm probably the last person that should be talking about the subtleties in the taste of the machiato and the cafe au lait that I ordered, but I thought they were good. I found lots of seating outside and upstairs and apparently the place turns into the traveling restaurant known as Radio Africa & Kitchen (Moroccan, Ethiopian) on Thurs and Friday evenings.
author: Cristofer P.

description:
I had the day to work from home, and I chose to spend it working at Coffee Bar.  Best. Choice. Ever.

First of all, on a nice day (which today was), the patio is clutch: nice tables (including a communal/picnic table) with plenty of space.  

I got the Cobb Salad, which is not normally TOO exciting, but this was great: great proportion of "toppings" to greens, and the tomato vinaigrette was pretty outstanding. Staff was super friendly and happy - generally nice to be around!

WiFi, great food, beautiful place.  Highly recommend if you need a place to work!
author: Josh L.

description:
Great space. Very open, comfortable vibe. Sit above the bar to people watch and let your mind wander.

The clover coffee was smooth with no bitter aftertaste.

The sandwiches are just ok. I'll have to try the baked goods another time.
author: A B.

description:
UPDATE 22 March 2008: NEW SPECTACULAR CHANGES ARE IN FULL EFFECT NOW THAT SPRING IS HERE... The sunny outdoor seating is killer, they now serve a really elegant Chai (YUMM!), and the crew decided to open up on Sundays (beginning March 29)... I also discovered their most delicious combination: granola with milk/yogurt/seasonal fruit and a glass of their Prosecco. Yelp, I think we have a problem: I can only rank Coffee Bar only 5 stars and not 6. 

ORIGINAL 19 February 2008: I hate this place. The coffee tastes like piss. The wine and beer are no good. The workers are mean. It's as horrifically crowded as Ritual Coffee Roasters...

[Read: I love this place, the coffee tastes like manna from heaven, the Meantime IPA and the Cab Sav are the best evarrrrrr, the workers are better than the personal shoppers at Barney's... Ritual Coffee Roasters, The Grove, Blue Bottle, etc. have a lot to learn from this place. The only thing it's missing is an Apple iTunes partnership because the music Andrew, Antonio, Jason, Luigi, MARY, etc. blast through their sound system kicks Starbucks' ass. I can't wait to move to Potrero Hill to be closer to Coffee Bar!]

In all seriousness, stay away from here--it's all mine!!!

P.S. Okay, maybe there is one thing... They don't serve sweet chai tea lattes--I know they're called Coffee Bar and not Sweet Chai Tea Latte Bar--so Royal Grounds on Fillmore will remain the best for those...for now.

P.P.S Royal Grounds, watch out! They now serve a Chai that tastes less like a scorching-hot generic spiced tea and more like a classy beverage you'd think was shipped via UPS SonicAir from the Shangri-La in Jakarta.
author: Travel Swagger R.

description: Would not recommend anyone spend a dime in this establishment.  Food is poor and overpriced, service is horrible and staff comes with big attitudes with little reason.  Don't step foot in this place.   Much better options for coffee 1 block away at Blue Bottle without the headaches.
author: Tracy Y.

description:
OK. FINE.  Let's talk about Coffee Bar.
 
It's obvious that there's something about this place seeing that I'm not an active Yelper, and I'm begrudgingly writing a review.  
 
But it's that awesome of a place.  I like the simplicity of the layout and design.  I'm all about high ceilings and space, so this place is perfect.  There's also massive amounts of sunlight that come through the industrial windows during the late afternoon.  

If they have good coffee, WINE, BEER, food, FREE wifi, good music...um, could you ask for anything more? I've only had coffee & tea but the food seems good too.  The owners are extremely friendly.  I'm definitely coming back...and I guess I can share it with everyone else.  And that about finishes my yearly Yelp review quota. 
 
 
**It's not really on Bryant Street; it's more like on Mariposa and Florida.  Bryant Street is overshadowed by a building with big green block letters - I believe, it says, "STARBUCKS"...that might be new non-corporate cafe too.
author: Eszter K.

description:
Universal Cafe and Atlas better watch out, there is a new brunch place in the neighborhood.

The boquerones, shaved funnel, and orange plate was such a pleasant surprise.  Also nice touch was the Patisserie Philippe croissant.  And we just came in for coffee with our Sunday paper.  The only drawback was the wait.  They still need to figure out how to serve restaurant-grade food at cafe speed (see Atlas).

I'll be back to have some more food and wine and to enjoy the comfortable couches, the rich speakers, and the book on sneakers in their stack of neat coffee books...
author: Jennifer H.

description: Ordered out but the food was pretty tasty. I'm definitely for having fewer awesome dishes but when the food is just pretty good, i'd hope for a bit more of a selection.
author: Whitney F.

description: Good food, people are kind, but wifi was unstable
author: Elisabeth M.

description: The staff was really nice and cheerful, digging the fact that they have designated no laptop tables which is cool. The White Crow sandwich (turkey) was a lil plain jane for 9 bucks in my opinion but the fact that they were bumping Jamiroquai and Erykah Badu most of time I was there earned them an extra star
author: Dennis W.

description:
This is a great place.  The coffee is excellent.  The baristas were on point, and the food was pretty darn tasty as well.  

The atmosphere is what makes this place.   The music definitely adds to the vibe of the joint and it was pleasant spending the afternoon working from there.  Oh yeah they have WIFI!  I enjoyed this place so much I think I am going to have my birthday party here.
author: Jimmy V.

description:
This is the spot.  If you are looking for a place that is cooler than cool, but a place that is not so cool that even a non-hipster can still feel comfortable, then coffeebar is the place for you.

Every time I come here I continue to be amazed at the quality of the ambiance.  I really like a place that has a lot of foot traffic, friendly workers, free wi-fi and plenty of power outlets - coffeebar hits on all fronts.  The only reason that they are four stars instead of five is because I wish that the tea were loose leaf (I am not a coffee drinker).

Aside from my one concern on the tea (as long as I come in the afternoon I get iced tea anyway) it is a great spot.  I will even go out of my way to schedule meetings at this location so that I can hang out here for a portion of the day.

Look for me!
author: Laurence T.

description: Pretty good food and nice outside seating area, although they need some shade for sunny days!
author: Mike G.

description:
Don't you hate it when you're given a sandwich with stale bread?  Yeah, me too.  And, don't you hate it when all of those individual people take up an entire 4-person table with just them and their laptop?  Yeah, me too.

My buddy and I went to Coffee Bar today for lunch.  I'd never been there before, and it looked pretty cool.  The menu was small, but had some very creative sandwiches and salads.  I had the turkey sandwich on wheat, and we split the anchovy/fennel salad.

The salad was really good!  And, it was definitely big enough for two people.

The sandwich, however, was a joke.  Even if it had had fresh bread, the TWO thin slices of turkey, coupled with the ONE romaine leaf and the TWO TINY slices of roma tomato and tiny bit of avocado made this the weakest sandwich I'd had in quite a while. 

I mean, seriously, do you expect me to just fill up on the stale bread and not notice the lack of meat?  Plus, what about some condiments?  It was like they sprayed on a thin layer of mayo and mustard, and then tried to scrape it all back off.  

Plus, for two sandwiches, a salad, and two drinks, it was over $29!  That's quite a bill for a very lackluster lunch.  

Outside of the food, the place has a cool, industrial vibe.  And, the guy working the register and delivering the plates was pretty nice and friendly.  But, the place (today) was a haven for people with laptops.  So, while there was probably room for 50 people in the whole place, most laptoppers hogged a whole table for themselves.

There oughta be a rule that if you are by yourself and the restaurant/cafe is crowded, you should sit with another single person at a 4-top.  Wouldn't the world be a better place?
author: Jason R.

description:
What a pleasant surprise!

I arrive here on a stunningly clear and blinding Thursday morning for a meeting. Blue skies, smiling on me...yadda yadda yadda. The only distraction was the intermittent fire alarms ringing in this place. But even THAT couldn't change the experience. 

A short to medium sized line will keep you at bay from your coffee and snacks, but when you finally order and get your coffee and snacks, you can truly step back and appreciate this place.

Free wifi, lots of light, and ridiculously affordable, unpretentiously cheap coffee and breakfast? $7.80. For two (yes, count em two) Americanos, a financier cake and a croissant. At any other cafe this would be like $14. 

Yay.
author: Aaron F.

description: Open and spacious inside - very relaxed. Friendly staff, great java and tasty breakfast bites.
author: Mike C.

description:
Disclaimer: I'm a little biased, because a friend from high school is one of the owners. 

Nonetheless, this place is undeniably the quintessential coffee bar. 

It's spacious and airy with lots of natural light for reading, sitting, chatting, studying or working on your laptop & accessing their free wi-fi. 

Their interior decor, signage & artwork is thoughtful & creative and complements its industrial/residential locale. 

Their food, drink and alcoholic beverage selection is vast, although I just went in for a latte-- which by the way, was expertly crafted.

I went in on a random, windy, Saturday afternoon and my friend was actually (and unexpectedly) behind the counter making the drinks & serving customers himself. This is big in my book: I respect small businesses which are owner-operated, because I myself own & operate a small business.

Another plus, their outdoor front patio, which is large enough to hold a small party, but fenced off from the street lending to some level of privacy.

Next time I'm back in Potrero Hill, I plan on making a stop.
author: John Eric S.

description:
I love their coffee, including clover which I'd never tried.  
I love that soy is one of the options on the condiment bar.
I love the abundance of places to sit, work, chill, etc.
I love all the succulent plants outside.
I love the option of outdoor seating, not enough of that in SF!
I love how the menus are written on brown paper and chalkboards.
I love the picture of the Muni station framed in window frames.
I love free wifi.
I love how it turns into a happening place at night to drink wine and listen to music.
I'm sure I'll love the food once I try it.
I love coffee bar!
author: Sarah M.

description:
I been starting all my reviews with pros, and then ending them with cons. For this review, I will be doing the complete opposite. 
the Cons: 
- why is the address of this place 1890 bryant st, when the entrance isnt on bryant st? hell, nothing relating to this establishment is on bryant st?
- i really wish coffee shops in general starts selling their pastry at a discounted price 30 - 60 mins before closing. 
With that being said there are plenty to like about this establishment....
Pros:
- the coffee here as previously stated is pretty damn good. 
- price wise, its on par with a lot of other coffee shop in the city
-  the over all space is amazing! i will be the first to hate on anything CA, but this place is cool in my book!
-  if the cheddar scone  was heated and perhaps a little cheaper, it would have been amazing!
- over all the main reason why i love this cafe was mainly for its space and overall coffee quality.
author: Mike C.

description:
I came in to coffee bar for a meeting and a snack.

First thing I noticed: food's a bit pricy. $8 for a grilled cheese? That's one hell of a grilled cheese.

I attempted to order a soup. I asked the cashier to compare the sizes of a cup and a bowl. I pointed to a large mug and asked him to use it as a reference.

I then became trapped in a bad episode of the Twilight Zone (or perhaps Candid Camera) where he spent three minutes telling me about a bowl and I kept asking him for a cup.

What a jerk.

They get two stars because the soup was actually pretty good.
author: Paul S.

description:
Good, not great cappuccino.  I was hoping for one of the greatest but the double was a bit watered down.  Not enough flavor.  I would venture to guess that the coffee is where it's at.  Maybe I'm just a Caffe Calabria (SD) cappuccino junkie!

Creative remodel, for sure.  Butcher paper roll menu, spacious outdoor space, minimalist.

Didn't try the food yet, but maybe next time.

SUPER friendly service.  They're trying, for sure.
author: Sandy K.

description:
Coffee Bar does what every coffee shop wants to do here in San Francisco, but they do it very, very well.  

Do you want great coffee?  Check.  Would you like delicious - may as well apply to your thighs tempting - pastries?  Check.  Would you like a savory and tasty salad or sandwich for lunch?  Check.  Would you like a glass of well picked out wine with your lunch?  Check.  How about a beer because you don't work in an office(jerk %$#@! I'm jealous) ?  Check.  How about music that doesn't make you want to stab your eardrums with the stirrers?  Check.  How about some diminutive munchies like cheese or salami to nosh on while you read?  Check.  How about free wireless and enough space to think and sit and are stylishly done, but not pretentious?  Check.

Lastly, how about service that does not make you receive your AARP card  while the staff gets the order finished?  Check - reasonably fast service covered.

The coffee there is amazing.  The staff is extraordinarily kind, funny, patient and informative.  I have not once come in there and had a staff member give me a fresh, hot cup of bad hair and tarnished tiara day.  

The drip coffee there is excellent.  And, on the rare days that San Francisco reaches above arctic temperatures you may sit outside and hang with the neighborhood pooches with our latte.

Go get some coffee and stop staring at your screen, now.
author: Gwen P.

description:
Jitter-free coffee! I'm a fan!

Coffee Bar doesn't appear to be a place you'd just stumble upon when about town--but whatever it is that does bring you here, you'll be mighty glad it did. Clean, light, and airy. Good music (albeit loud). Tasty pastries--both sweet and savory (thumbs-up to the cranberry-rosemary bread), and everything here is as green as can be. Plus--and as a Bostonian I find this super, super cool--you can order beer and wine here, too. Nice touch!

There are a few lunch items on the menu here--and I think one or two nights a week they do dinner as well. An outdoor patio makes this place all the more wonderful; however, it could benefit from some umbrellas to protect its patrons from the sun and the radiant heat of all that concrete and metal.
author: Holly S.

description: Excellent place to work (free wifi), meet people (plenty of indoor and outdoor space), and a great location! I'll be back!
author: Jason W.

description:
SO wonderful is this place I wish this was in MY neighborhood.. instead, it's in my grandma's. Go figure, didn't realize i was outdone by her for awesome neighborhoods to live in. 

 This place just opened over Christmas 07, but people are definitely catching on. And the coffee is AMAZING. Hopefully they will start retailing the beans soon too.

The guy at the bar took his time to make a fabulous latte, super smooth and pillowy foam, nutty full taste. love it. 

The space is great too.. big, high ceilings, clean space, really great to take your work on the weekends. Apparently it's a wine bar at night too.. but haven't tried that yet. The guys behind the counter are very friendly as well...

And as a side note, the branding they did with the place, their logos, the cups -- is awesome. Don't be fooled by the generic name.
author: Subie C.

description:
There are plenty of seat-level power outlets here. No scrounging around on some nasty floor begging your neighbor to spare some space.

Not that you'd ever have to. My laptop magically consumes less power in this place. I am completely unplugged right now, as a matter of fact.

The ambiance is very comfortable. I don't have to feel like I'm not cool enough to be here. It's the perfect place to wait for my coworkers to arrive at the office after I've locked myself out.

The only minus is that their (free!) WiFi network is called "linksys". I'd rather they named it to something like "CoffeeBar". I don't want to add every "linksys" in the world to my "trusted wireless networks".
author: Rob T.

description:
I love this place.

Great crowd of people here, and a generally friendly staff.  I use Coffee Bar for my daytime studying needs, because the light is fantastic and the coffee is excellent.  Also, their pastries (they don't make em, they get them from somewhere) are pretty good.  Best chocolate croissant I've had in awhile.

But the dinner crowd makes it hard to study there at night.  And the food was not very good.  My dinner plate was very ambitious, some sort of lamb with some couscous and some sort of vegetable all mixed together on a plate.  Tasted okay I guess, but presentation was poor and the whole thing just kind of had a tv dinner consistency to it.  I had a sandwich for lunch and after I ate it I wasn't hungry anymore, and that's about all I have to say about that.

So, 5 stars as a coffee shop, 2 stars for food.  Seeing as how it's called Coffee Bar and not Coffee Restaurant or Food Bar, I'll only dock one star for the food.  See you soon, Coffee Bar.
author: Chris H.

description: This place was highly recommended, and is great for startup, but really... it wasn't stellar wow yipee crazy!  Maybe I had high expectations. :)  They do have 4505 meats chicharrones. :p I don't know. For food, 3 stars. For startup atmosphere, 3.5?
author: Tracy L.

description: A lot of times when I feel like I'm leaving too late for work. I'll skip making the coffee at home to save some time, then after my 25 minute routine of looking for parking is complete I'll go in the office and have some of our office coffee (If you work in a office that has good coffee regularly I want to know.). but sometimes I'll find parking right away and realize I'm 20 minutes early to work. I like bundle that enjoyment of finding an easy parking space with the enjoyment of a good cup of coffee from Coffee Bar. A perfect pairing. Maybe they would get 4 stars for their food or service, but seeing as I only visit them on days when I'm on easy street (parking), I'm only going there when the days are staring great.
author: Parvarti S.

description:
4 1/2 stars ... a little room for improvement to reach perfection. 

Hard to find location. Once you find it ... you won't regret it. 

- Way above average coffee joint. 
- Superior above average food selection. 
- Daily food specials...makes food selection from being boring. 
- Very computer user friendly. Power outlet almost everywhere. 
- Pretty roomy... have the potential to seat more. 
- Outdoor patio. 
- Superior quality pastry. 
- Generous natural lighting (best type for the eyes, especially for reading. 
- Full kitchen and staff, rare find for a coffee place 
- Radio Africa meals Thur & Fri 
- Accepts credit card 


-    ( I will remove the following when they fix the following problem ) 
Need to dust the platform where the keep the beer cups. 
(Noticed the dusty platform where u could see clean cup dragged thru the dusty platform. I saw a poor bloke served nice cold beer in a salt rimmed cup...(ooppps ...dust rimmed cup)


Good for group(s) and kids only outside. Popular place...gets full inside easily.

Update. 10/22/09 - They had an "El Diablo" on the drink special...
         Chipotle Chocolate Cuppucino with Chipotle infused milk....
          It was very creative and delicious!!!
author: S.K. Y.

description: Such a great place to sit outside, eat delicious and thoughtful food, and drink great coffee.  I love the large windows and communal seating and get addicted to most everything that I try here.
author: Jessie J.

description: This place is awesome.  Great coffee and great sandwiches.  The decor is trendy and the vibe is awesome.  I would definitely be here all the time doing work/studying/reading if I were closer.
author: Bert N.

description:
Just found coffee bar today as a result of a friends recommendation. Actually I'm there right now! 

More often than not what I want out of a cafe is a good place to read or work and Coffee bar fits the bill. There is a lot of seating, free wifi, and good light. It also seems like it would be a good cafe to grab a coffee with a friend or small group. 

It leans to the trendy side, but not too much. The food isn't cheap, but I do like dynamo donuts now and again. The outdoor seating area would be terrific on a nice day.
author: Daniel F.

description:
My perspective on Coffee Bar is similar to one that I'd have if I happened to be dating a really smart, ambitious, and cute girl with, say, a terribly annoying voice. You have really high hopes for it and your desire to see the place/relationship succeed depends on how well you can make yourself look the other way and ignore the annoying traits, and on how persistent you are in telling yourself about all the amazing and wonderful and innovative things they bring into your life. 

Coffee Bar is amazing. The space itself is beautiful! The coffee they serve is wonderful, both the espresso and their Clover flavors are to die for. The tea brand and selection is fantastic.. In short, their coffee selection and preparation and experience are all on par with the best in the city. There is a huge amount of seating, parking is easy to find nearby, there are plenty of power outlets, and the staff is helpful with questions (see my comments on their wine selection later). In other words, as far as being a coffee shop, Coffee Bar gets six stars.

But I dock two of the six stars for the transformation that happens in the evening hours. In the evenings it becomes impossible to enjoy as much as in the daytime because the music seems to be a few decibels too loud; the place itself becomes very noisy when all the voices, the music, and the industrial, concrete feel coalesce into an orgy of reflected sounds that make holding a conversation harder than it needs to be. 

But. the wine selections consists of vineyards and varietals that I have never heard of before and that has never disappointed me. However the food menu is extraordinarily yuppie and I feel like it could use some more reasonable options, especially when I work from home from here for a couple of hours in the afternoon and would like to get something to eat. 

The DJ that I've seen a few times on the weekend afternoons is a nice touch, though.
author: Joe K.

description:
Rita C says that the staff is snooty. I'll never questions the experience of someone else (if I wasn't there to witness it myself), and I'm sorry to Rita if that happened to her (what a bummer, that's happened to me before....see my review of Cafe Soliel....YUCK). 

My experience at Coffee Bar was the complete opposite. I've found EVERYONE on the staff to be really welcoming, warm and professional. So good, in fact, that this place is a stand out to me customer service-wise.  

Overall, I just can't say enough good things about this place. For me, this is THE coffee place I was looking for....and I was looking for a while. 

Rita, I'd give it another try...maybe someone was just having a bad day. I bet you have a different experience next time and who knows, it might just become your favorite coffee place too!
author: Dan P.

description:
I've been here twice now and I'm a huge fan. We always come here on the weekends to take care of homework or personal projects and it's a really great atmosphere to hang out in. 

If you plan on sitting around for awhile I would really recommend getting the cheese plate, it is beyond delicious. I don't drink coffee, but my boyfriend tells me it is delicious. They do have a really great selection of teas and other drinks as well, not to mention beer and wine (yay!)

They have a nice a assortment of bar tables, single tables, huge benches and couches. It's really a nice mellow place where you can get absorbed into your work without distraction.
author: Allyson S.

description: Love this place. Real chill atmosphere and modern design setup which I am a fan of. The food has been tasty as well as the coffee bar drinks ($3 average price). There are laptop stations and group seating inside and outside. The staff are all really nice from my multiple experiences going here. My favorite place to grab a coffee and hang out. Totally worth a visit!
author: Marjorie Stewart B.

description:
So I'm visiting SF for a couple of days and staying with a friend just 2 blocks from Coffee Bar so naturally we headed here to get a glass of wine while waiting for his girlfriend to come over so we could decide on dinner.  I was with my GF so the 3 of us walk in and wait to order a glass of wine at the bar.  The guy helping us was friendly and knew about the wines so he could intelligently answer our questions and supply recommendations.  I really wanted wine, but the coffee smelled so good I almost changed my mind.

The few stools at the bar were filled so we walked up the half staircase to look for a table.  I was stopped and asked if we would be dining.  Being in the restaurant business I can understand holding tables for diners but I explained we were just having the glass of wine and would be willing to get up if in the next twenty minutes they needed all seven of the empty tables.  We were offered 3 ottomans that were arranged around a low coffee table.  We ventured outside instead.

We probably would have stayed for a second glass of wine and/or some small bites if we had a table.  But since it was cold outside we ventured on to our next locale.
author: David H.

description: I changed my mind: the servers here are nice. I think (read: know) I'm just a bitch in the mornings/afternoons/always.
author: Rebecca P.

description:
Im already in love with this place.
So happy to see a place that has sandwiches and soup (and other yummy things) after say, 3PM. Staff is exceptionally nice and non-snotty which is a big plus in my heart AND great coffee.
-
Anchor Steam, Veggie panini's with soup and good espresso drinks? I'll be there plenty.

BEANS: Mr. Espresso
BIKE RACK: Multiple ones (maybe 5 altogether), just outside - next to their open patio, so high visibility if you are outside.
author: ninja M.

description:
Somewhere between my last review 8 month ago and now, there was a brief departure from the original construction of THE BEST EGG SANDWICH IN THE WORLD.  What was that departure? They changed the bread from Brioche to a Bun.  Granted, it was a phenominal tasting bun and the core of any great food is a combination of great ingredients, so it would be hard to say th sandwich was no good...afterall, I continued to order it every Saturday morning.  Nevertheless, changing anything that is the best in the world warrants the question: ''Is it still the best in the world?'' Pondering this question for the past few Saturdays, I'm very happy to report I don't need to answer........

The Brioche is back!  Very nice move guys...very nice. 

And to the novice egg sandwich eaters, eating the sando fresh, as soon as it's served, will help minimize bread degredation and provide for a more complete experience.
author: Joe T.

description:
Finally a coffee shop that can make a cappuccino!  Don't mean to sound like a snob, but most coffee shops in Cally can't make them.  Probably having something to do with the barrister being Italian.  

I was invited  here for a "pleasure party" for women only....I'm not that kind of girl...honest ;)
author: Anastasia Beaver Housand J.

description: Fantastic coffee and great people.  One of the best shots of Espresso in the city.
author: Christian M.

description: felt like ive trapped into a place for macbook lovers.  hehe  neway i love their coffee.  its amazing that their coffee even works on the hungover to the max day!
author: Jee C.

description: Very Potrero, a great place to work specially if you need a "Standing desk", their tall tables are excellent for this.
author: Gonzalo M.

description:
3 metrics: 1) ambience 2) taste of the coffee 3) service

1. ambience - 5 stars - this place is ideal for those of us who always have our macbook. Plenty of outlets, large wood tables & benches. sometimes it gets too crowded though. it's like an advertisement for Apple with the rows and rows of Macbooks all over this place, but it's my kind of place.

2. taste of coffee - 5 stars. never had an iced latte or cappuccino here i didn't like. they also have a yummy 'savory loaf' along with all the standard baked goods, and they have lunch selections too.

3. service - meh. that's where the dock comes in - 3.5 stars probably. it's not terrible but it's just SLOW SLOW SLOW. given how crowded this place has been getting, they need to be able to keep pace a bit better!
author: Latte Queen W.

description:
Coffee Bar combines my two favorite artisan beverage categories, coffee and wine, in an elegant, modern atmosphere.  The design and architecture blends perfectly with the surrounding area; sorta industrial, yet still casual and inviting.

You enter through a great little courtyard with tables just waiting for a sunny weekend afternoon.  Outdoor seating is a huge plus, there are so few places in SF which provide comfortable not-on-the-sidewalk-or-in-the-middle-of-the-street tables.

Drink menu is comprehensive, with both pick-me-up and mellow-me down options to suit your need or addiction.  I went with a latte which was very smooth and well balanced.  All too often many baristas either go overboard on the milk or get so absorbed in designing some Rorschach froth art they forget someones going to drink it in about 2 seconds.  

Sat at the little bar on the side of the counter, which was a great spot for watching preparation and just general comings and goings.  Upstairs seating looked very casual as well, with some spots looking down into the entry and out the huge glass wall.

Why go to Coffee Bar instead of the Starbucks across the street?  Simple..this place has SOUL.  You feel connected to the rest of the world in a way that Starbucks and Peets just can't reproduce.  

Good drinks, mellow crowd and supporting a local business.  What more could you ask? Drink early and drink often...
author: Jason M.

description:
Early March09, night time, meetup for CouchSurfing. We packed out the place upstairs and they were happy to have us. WOW, isn't that a rare treat!

The location is actually at the corner of Florida & Mariposa, not Bryant as the address would have you believe. 

I had a tea which was in an elegant tissane bag with a muy hearty mug of hot water, $1.90. 

The snackies looked enticing and other patrons were saying that they were happy with their food choices. Loved the reasonably priced beer and wine options.

Super nice interior decor, big, airy, modern. Location is a bit devoid of foot traffic at night but not unduly unsafe.
author: Miel H.

description:
Ah.. okay so the layout is awesome and love the industrial feel.  They just have to get the whole feel right;  People come to coffee bars to talk to friends, study, and surf the net (work).   This is not the ideal place to meet with people, unless sitting out on he patio.  The MUSIC is way too loud.  Yes, I'm old, but not old enough to turn down my hearing aid...so you just can't really read anything important without 'house music' bumping in your head.   The tables are also close enough, that you really can't talk without the person sitting next to you also involved in the conversation.   Strike 3, the parking.  Unless you work for MUNI or live in the area, good luck.  

Oh, the coffee and food are great.  If you are just going to get coffee from Starbucks from up the block, this is a better choice; Unless you only will settle for the super frosty, double tall, extra hot, honey, crap latte that Starbucks has brainwashed the world to buy.
author: H D.

description: I ordered the caramel latte and thought it was made very well.  Overall, good service.  I'd come back here again.
author: M B.

description: Great coffee, but the crowd keeps getting worse and worse.  I feel like I'm in a peet's in cow hollow or something.  Ech!
author: Daryl W.

description:
Coffee Bar does it right.  It has great ambiance, high ceilings, fantastic sandwiches.  WiFi is free and fast, and I love the communal tables.  Most importantly, they keep the temperature above an arctic freeze unlike most other cafes, and the soundtrack doesn't suck (Sugar Cafe, I'm talking to you). 

Definitely check it out.
author: Sarah C.

description: This is a great, non-pretentious place to pop in for a relaxing drink and WiFi hour. I especially like being upstairs in the loft.
author: Brad N.

description: the person that talks about one of the managers is DEAD ON.  Dude makes it uncomfortable to even be there.  He gives patrons and co-workers bad looks, talks with a degrading tone, and rushes people like no other.  Seriously considering not going there, all because of this one dude.
author: Timothy S.

description:
Having lived in Seattle for four years during college, I had come to expect certain things from a cafe. Things like free-wifi, good food made to order, baristas who know how to pull a decent shot, a large, open space with plenty of natural light, beer/wine in the evening, etc. When I moved down to SF, I was surprised to find that these traits were pretty much impossible to find in a local cafe. That is, until coffee bar came around. 

I was thanking one of the owners the other day for creating such a great cafe in San Francisco and remarked on its similarities to my favorites in Seattle. It turns out that Seattle cafes were the inspiration for coffee bar, and in particular, Victrola. It's nice to see I'm not the only one who missed Seattle cafes down here! 

My only complaint is that they use Mr Coffee espresso. If they switched to something lighter like blue bottle, stumptown or zoka, it'd be perfect.
author: matt m.

description:
I truly love this place. It's clean, has a beautiful view, and is spacious. I'm not even a coffee person, and I come here because the atmosphere is so great. I've (shamefully) become one of those irritating people who spends hours hoarding valuable table space at a coffee shop, this coffee shop, doing...

My homework. Hours of my homework which would otherwise go undone until night, forcing me to stay up until my class time because I can't focus in my own cluttered desk and would rather spend money to buy a coffee (which I'm not keen on in general) as an excuse for me to take up approximately a 1 foot circumference of study space on their table. (Commence scathing comments from the internet criticizing why I spend money foolishly and emphasizing the importance of organization. Thanks, mom.). 

So I thank you, Coffee Bar, for being my study space, and making my eyes slightly less bloodshot. I love you almost as much as I love sleep.

Also: One of the baristas was really nice. Apparently when someone tried to take my pastry (Oh no they didn't.) when I wasn't present, he defended my plate. I appreciate that, mystery barista.

Oh and for people that actually like coffee: It's quite good. The Vietnamese Ice Coffee is especially great.
author: Sora O.

description:
Great coffee, really nice and airy and great for working/studying.  These guys take coffee seriously, and I respect that.  They made a beautiful leaf on the top of my latte.

Free wifi of course.  Thumbs up!
author: Reggie G.

description:
Great aesthetic, brilliant coffee, nice baristas... I love it!  And it's only two blocks from our apartment, too.  Double win.

Minus one star because they inexplicably do not serve chai or tea, which is a deal-breaker for my non coffee drinking fiance.  I know they're called "Coffee Bar," not "Tea Bar," but they also serve wine and beer so it's not like they're mono-beverage oriented.  If they add a decent chai (I emailed them requesting this), I'll up to five stars.

****EDIT:**** They have chai now, a tasty home-made blend, and as promised I'm upping my star count.  Hurrah!
author: Jess L.

description:
Stop #2 on a getaway party pub crawl on a rainy Saturday night.

They have Chimay beer! Yay! They have not too much food left around 10pm! What do to? Drink slowly and stop somewhere where you can get something before hitting the next bar.

Great space, cool redesign, I have to come back to check out their coffee soon.
author: Roland A.

description: I want to like you more, but I just can't. The service is so disappointing. They seem to always mess up my order and don't ever seem to care. Too bad, because the space is great.
author: Rebecca W.

description: Just not a free loading wi-fi hoarding laptop whore, I see the appeal to folks who are, just not me. Call me old but how dehumanizing is it when the real focus here is not the restaurant itself but screen that's open in front of them, shame on you for just sitting there for hours and hours on end sipping on one coffee and nibbling on a teeny pastry thinking that you are patronizing an establishment, as for charging for space or "free" wifi I'm all for it, will show who your true patrons are.
author: B H.

description:
Been meaning to stop in here for a while, and this morning was a "two coffee morning"... Great cappuccino: dark, rich espresso, nice crema, properly sized cup (not huge). Friendly, attentive staff. 

My only knock is that if you're really a "coffee bar", you should have sugar _on the bar_ as you would find in any proper cafe in Europe. Not all the condiments, just sugar, so that if I sit at the bar (as I did) and they slide my coffee down in front of me (as they did), I don't then have to get up and make my way over to the "condiment bar" just for a packet of sugar. It might sound like a minor point, but it puts a minor dent in the coffee bar experience. Going to the condiment bar is always a bit of a downer; makes me feel like Starbucks. Get a few proper sugar boats. 

Otherwise, I like the space and the feel, minus the assh**e on his iPhone speakerphone in line -- so lame. Good stuff. PS, for detailed coffee ratings, check out coffeeratings dot com, it's pretty neat if you're really into espresso.
author: Bowen D.

description: Love this place. After learning that they use Mr. Espresso coffee which is supposedly number two of local beaneries- I decided that Coffee Bar will be my new cheers bar. This  may be the first time I am sad that I don't live in the mission, but now I have  a great excuse to get my self out of the marina to lounge, mix and mingle with some of San Francisco's most attractive baristas and upwardly mobile coffee goers.
author: Michelle K.

description: Love the coffee, love the food, love the music they play, the wifi & outlets.  Will always spend my money here.
author: laura g.

description: I really like this place. If I lived in the Mission I would go here a lot more frequently. The high ceiling and layout of the space is really interesting for a cafe, and I really like it. (Did I say that already?) Yeah anyway, the food is good too, if perhaps a little overpriced.
author: Richa A.

description:
I love this place.  The food is creative and delicious and the coffee really something.  I am picky too but just love to hang out there.

thanks for making my special place so great!!
author: Joyce G.

description: Coffee served with an attitude.  Beautiful environment, snotty servers.
author: Brett N.

description: Food is okay if you need to grab a quick lunch, I would suggest getting it to go, the employees are not friendly.
author: Michelle B.

description: Great place overall, even if the food is somewhat overpriced.  You go to the Coffee Bar not to relax, rest, and chat in a cozy coffee shop setting, rather its atmosphere and vibe is more conducive for working and focusing on getting something accomplished.  No, really, this is a good thing.  How many times do we need to get work done, but we don't want to stay at home and don't want to go to the neighborhood coffee shop to hear locals musing about the weather?  Expect a visit to the Coffee Bar to invigorate you with its charged atmosphere of hip hop music and utilitarian, industrial vibe as you sit amongst fellow patrons who are deep in thought, tirelessly typing away at their laptops.
author: Mike B.

description: Great for coffee-drinking and tech-celebrity-watching.
author: Paul K.

description: Excellent coffee in a beautiful space. Their patio is also one of the only sunny places to drink coffee in the Mission that I know.
author: Luke A.

description:
My cousin and I checked out the place for the first time last week. We were very impressed with the space and the relaxed yet unpretentious warm atmosphere created by the friendliness of the staff, minimalism of the design, and music selection. Not to mention, free wi-fi! 

The cheese platter is incredible. Such a wonderful combination of flavors! And I also love their donut muffin. I have to say, I'm not an avid coffee drinker but based on the setting alone, I will definitely come back.

The downside? It was closed on Sunday.
author: Monica N.

description:
I like this place.  I want to like this place more.  I believe in second chances but they definitely need a little bit of an overhaul.  They need to work on first having more regular hours.  I like that they claim to be open late, but if they don't deliver like they did last time (they kicked us out at 10 even though they claimed to be open till 11 on the phone), it leaves a lot of customers (like myself) confused and frankly, disappointed!

Their coffee is excellent (a good deal if you ask me - it has enough caffeine in it to keep you wired for a whole week - you never have to sleep)! Their wine menu is decent.  But I get the feeling they don't know how to pull off both.  At this point they seem more like a coffee shop that just so happens to serve wine (kind of like Nook on Hyde).  Sugar Lounge on Sutter manages to pull of both quite well.  I believe that this place would be more attractive to me if they had decided how to pull off both BEFORE they opened.  

This place definitely has some potential - it's a beautiful space, their staff is friendly, and their coffee is EXCELLENT, their pastries are a nice touch (LOVE the donut holes!) ... but they do need a little bit of work, and a little more thought put into their concept wouldn't hurt either.  IMHO they should stick to serving their lovely clover coffee and not really emphasize the "bar" part of it.
author: Jean A.

description:
I'm so happy I discovered this spot.  It's a great space.  Excellent for grabbing a cup of coffee or glass of wine with a few friends and/or doing a little work on the laptop.  The natural light is great, the decor clean & sophisticated.  The clientele is friendly and hip (but inviting).  Food is pretty solid though a little on the light side.

I want to give this place 5 stars but the blonde working behind the counter is often cold and snobby.  Everyone else (owners & workers) are awesome and friendly.  The music can be a little loud but overall I love it here.
author: Rafael s.

description:
I just went there for a cup of latte and some pastries.

Unlike other high profile coffee shops in Noe Valley/Hayes Valley area, there was no line, and it was not overly crowded at all, and parking is easy (did it just happen to be my lucky day....?).  No wait, no damn driving around to look for a spot being a total turn-on already, my latte was delicious - this place made my day.

Pros:
No wait
Plenty of street parking (on a Saturday at least)
Good latte
Good pastries
Friendly service
Clean/cute interior

Cons: nada (so far)

As I was passing by a Starbucks on my way back to my car, I thought  "why would anyone even think of going to Starbucks when there's a nice coffee shop half block away where they can get real coffee drinks?"  Now that I think of it, I haven't held a cup with Starbucks logo for a very long time.
author: Yoko S.

description: We happen to have offices in the same building as Coffee Bar, so over the past several years we've had hundreds of coffees, teas and light meals from their kitchen. We're never disappointed. Friendly people, good atmosphere, fast service--and good coffee and noshes. Can't imagine the neighborhood without them.
author: Malcolm D.

description:
There are a lot of hip coffee shops in SF. Add Coffee Bar to that list.
This loft-style coffee shop is quite beautiful. The menu looked great and the food was excellent: light but delicious. 

Two weird things happened during my visit. 1) They brought our food to our table, but not our drinks. They didn't even announce that a (insert specific coffee drink) was ready. Weird. The other oddity (or quasi-Twilight Zone moment) was the proliferation of Apple laptops, iPhones, and iPods. I expect coffee shops to have a few people glued to their computers, but I've never witnessed such a clean sweep of one companies products. And everyone (except my friends and I) were using them.
author: Tim B.

description: AMAZING ICED COFFEE.  Need I say more?  OK, since you asked, I'll say more.  The place is great but it gets VERY crowded by people wanting to work on their laptops all day.  This sucks because, of course, I want to work on my laptop all day.  But OK if you get there at the right time you can sit there for hours sipping iced coffee and one of their amazing sandwiches.  Did I mention the iced coffee?  Cold-brewed over 24 hours?  Seriously, iced coffee everywhere else tastes like burnt dog poop.  I mean, in comparison.  Anyway.  GO GET SOME.  Oh, and the outside area rocks.
author: Charles G.

description:
I love this space. 

If I can turn this place into my loft space, I would be in heaven.

Great place to come for a coffee. I wish it were open a little later on some nights. Its a great place to come instead of a bar or an all night Starbucks.

Coffee is pretty good too and so are the sandwiches. I'll be back again soon!
author: Rocky K.

description:
This has recently become my favorite place in the city to sit with my laptop and sip coffee.

 +  Big windows let a lot of light in
 +  Clean, chic furniture
 +  Plenty of power outlets
 +  Plenty of parking
 +  Good wireless connectivity
 +  Decent coffee and desserts (haven't tried their food menu)
 +  Good beverage selection
 +  Outside seating available
 +  Excellent music all the time

I ah-like!  Why not?  It's a-naice!
author: Abid M.

description:
Been to Coffee Bar twice now, once for dinner, and again last night just for drinks.  I agree with the others that the decor is just lovely (though, I've sat outdoors on both of my visits), and the place from the outside is completely unassuming, preserving is neighborhood gem appeal.  An additional plus is that they allow dogs on the patio, so my pooch and I can enjoy the outdoors together.  

As far as the food, decent, not spectacular, over priced, and the staff isn't necessarily terribly friendly nor helpful - especially on the evenings when they serve dinner.  It could have just been an off night, but I have a sneaking suspicion that's it wasn't.  Also, the prices for alcohol are outrageous - I ordered a glass of Proseco last night and it cost me $9.33, and it wasn't even a generous pour.  Did I mention it was Proseco?  Usually can be found for $10 a bottle!  Also, they don't allow smoking on the patio, WTF?  It's a patio....

Nice if you have low expectations and unlimited funds, but otherwise, hit Zeitgeist - they may be rude, but at least they're cheap.
author: Alison L.

description:
If it was possible to give negative stars...I would!

I have been frequenting Coffee Bar for a number of years as it used to be in my work building.  I want to like Coffee Bar; I have given them many many chances.  I would like to support them as I know they use local bakeries (that I generally like).  The food is decent, but definitely overpriced.

My moment of ANGER today is after my 4th drink in a row that is luke warm in addition to not being drinkable at all.  Today, I asked for a "burning hot" chai, as I know they never make their drinks hot enough.  A regular warm drink should necessitate a drink sleeve; after asking for EXTRA hot drinks....not once have I needed a drink sleeve.  The drinks are luke warm.

Today, however, was my breaking point.  In addition to my drink being luke warm, which was not a surprise, it was absolutely undrinkable.  It must have been 3/4 Chai and 1/4 milk (or some ratio that had way too much chai).  I had a colleague try my drink to give an objective opinion, and she too made a face (you know the one....like when something is too sour).

I left the shop knowing the drink was bad and didn't say anything about my $4 drink because the customer service is so snooty and consistently rude (and I'm a regular, they should know me by now).

Did I mention that I hate Starbucks?  But, from now on I will frequent my new favorite coffee shop in this part of the mission.....the Starbucks on Bryant and Mariposa, where even though its a Starbucks, at least the people are friendly and their customer service is reliable.
author: Sunny Y.

description: I live in Oakland, but when I am in the city and need to get coffee and work, this is my favorite plcae.  i love the industrial space and the coffee.  It's hard to find a table at times, but otherwise this place rocks!
author: farangis f.

description: Changing from 2 to 4 stars. My first experience was not great as the staff were disinterested, but I've been back 4 times recently and everyone I've dealt with has been lovely. Coffee is excellent.
author: Sean H.

description:
cute place
tasty coffee
super-friendly and helpful barista guy
counter guy is obviously not a hospitality major
author: Vicente G.

description:
God Bless this place for being close to my work - I can add another place to the list.
two words: CLOVER COFFEE
best $3.00 cup of coffee you'll ever have and THANK YOU for having this.  Clover's hard to come by in this neck of the woods. I first experienced this fabulous creation at Stumptown in Portland. I highly recommend it - especially if you ADORE coffee.
author: melissa h.

description:
i went last night to meet a friend for a little meeting.  He got one small plate and i nothing but I did drink a lot of water.  They didn't hassle us and let us sit as long as we wanted.  I feel like most places would have asked us to leave after an hour or so, but not here.  The waitress was super nice and friendly, and the owner was also great.  He speaks Japanese, and encourages the ppl who speak it to speak it with him  :)

great place, with great vibe, but i still have not eaten anything there.  one say soon.
author: Andrew r.

description: I stood in line here yesterday and watched as a customer walked up to the counter and first asked the barista "do you take plastic?"  He said yes.  Then the customer said "good because I'd like to buy every single chocolate donut that you've got.  They are the best thing I've ever put into my mouth and I'm going to see my nieces who love chocolate."  I think that's a pretty darn good review in and of itself.  I didn't get a donut (there were none left).  But I did have a delicious latte and croissant and loved the high ceilings, up beat atmosphere, etc.  And, yes, I'm going back to try one of the chocolate donuts.
author: Kate H.

description: Exceptional staff that is cordial, personable, and polite. The food is awesome (fresh, tasty, great combinations of ingredients).
