OK, they lost a star today.  The guy making my drink wasn't paying attention and overran the espresso shots.  Rather than starting over, he simply poured off the top of them and used them.  Not to be a total pain in the ass, and the drink wasn't bad, but just not the type of thing I'd expect at a place that is professing to be coffee-geekish.  Just a great place to hang for a bit though (socially or with your laptop).
author: r h.

description: My favorite study spot in the city.  Need I say more?  Sometimes I wish I lived here...
author: C. M.

description: Lame.  Granted, a nice space, if perhpas a bit...a bit...snooty.  Walked in, paid for a cup of tea, walked upstairs to sit and was immediately told they were closing for dinner.  A conscientous and appreciated employee apologized for the poor service and admitted that this was a a mis-managed issue they'd been having trouble with.  Suggestion: just tell peole who are about to purchase beverages if you are 10 or 15 minutes (or so) away from closing the seating area.  Problem solved.  I went to the spacious and freindly STARBUCKS around the corner on Potrero and Mariposa instead.  Not the same, but more customer friendly.
author: Bartholomew H.

description: Best coffee place I have been to as far as coffee, atmosphere, decor, and theft-worthy furnishings.  From the outside, the place looks cool enough, but more rundown Mission cool, a place that has history and character.  You step inside, though, and it becomes clear that it is a newer, remodeled loft space, one that you would find in SOMA.  Jet high ceilings and carefully selected details, like coffee books on bookshelves, rows of wine glasses, and chrome lamps create a wonderfully open, airy space.  The coffee beans are from Oakland-based Mr. Espresso.  This is their first cafe, which makes for an admirable start.  There is free wi-fi, plenty of outlets, and the signal is pretty good.  You can read, write, work online, do everything with relaxation and serenity.  Lastly, the coffee is delicious.  The soy latte and regular latte are perfect with thick, creamy foam, just the right texture and flavor, and arrive on your saucer with lovely artwork, to boot.  Get the dirtbombs.  They are a cross between a muffin and donut and are coated with sugar sprinkles, a fabulous accompaniment to the flawless coffee.  If I lived nearby, it would be a no-brainer to make this venue a regular haunt.
author: Dee C.

description: Coffee Bar opened on Friday, where ARC used to be. The updated space is really nice, leather couches and tables upstairs, a share table that seats 12, a private room for small meetings. The coffee is great. It's Mr. Espresso (the coffee of choice of Chez Panisse), they offer two different roasts, and a small, artisan, delicious-sounding menu. And don't worry about the ARC vibe -- I was greeted three times by staff before I even hit the front door, and everyone is super-friendly. When I stopped in for coffee in the morning, I got a tour of the place from one of the two guys who owns it, met his wife, and felt the excitement of the first days of a new neighborhood place that people really care about. I went back for lunch and had a delicious cabbage and tangerine salad with sesame dressing. They will have wine/beer and small plates in the evening pretty soon too. Love this place. Love it.
author: wendy l.

description: While I really like the atmosphere of this place, they really need to get a grip on their prices! In my opinion, the food is mediocre at best. A tuna sandwich $8, a donut $3.25...Lunch bill $12. GIVE ME A BREAK! I don't mind paying 8 bucks for a sandwich, but jeez, if you're going to charge $8 for a tuna sandwich, make it worth the 8 bucks. The sandwich was dry, barely any tuna and two pieces of bread....boring and not worth it. This place gets 1 star for me for the atmosphere.
author: Joseph G.

description: Just met someone here for a meeting a couple of days ago and fell in love with the place. They know that I don't drink decaf so some snobby barista can serve me water-down brownish flavorless blah. They gave me the the jet fuel I deserved!  Awesome patio, etc. I'll be back.
author: b b.

description: Decent coffee, has food, swamped with laptop users hanging out there all day.
author: Max D.

description: Love this place; Coffee Bar exemplifies the great things about San Francisco; also it makes one ponder; why aren't there more of these kinds of places and fewer of the chains?  Coffee Bar lured from the street by it's beaming red sign.  I figured I have discovered all the coolest places by now.  I was surprised I had not been here sooner.  This is a highly stylized  palace for all things Java; I like the format and there are elements that tell you how the principals are engaged in their business; it is more than a business but a passion.  I like how there is a roll of shipping paper that cleanly depicts the days offering.  The art work was fantastic; the front coffee bar shows an homage to the bus park nearby.  The art work and the higher level seating transport you to a nice coffee house experience -- more like a coffee salon.  So nice; so needed and it feels like my out of the way secret coffee palais.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description: lots of light, great sandwiches, great coffee, free wifi!  when i went it was quiet and i was hoping it hadnt been 'found'  yet but based on the other reviews it looks like i was just lucky that day and it actually is some hipster hangout.  may i continue to be blissfully oblivious to the hipster schedule!
author: X X.

description: my photo group likes to meet here because of the huge wooden tables. we can spead all of our stuff out and share our work. it also doesn't hurt that they have free wifi and great coffee. indoor and outdoor seating is a l=plus!
author: Jennifer M.

description:
sexy, minimalist, euro-style decor and excellent coffee...

such a great spot...at least during the day as i havent been at night yet.

valencia street can have ritual coffee all to itself.  this place is more like a cafe/bar you'd find in berlin...

and, ok...im editing my initial review here as I've frequented coffee bar many times since it first opened.

the coffee and the cookies still make my day, but I have to agree with other reviews about the volume of the music.  you really can't accomplish much given the noise level.  so forget about trying to prep a report, or reading Judith Butler here.  less house music would be a fine thing. can i get an elliot smith, or stereolab a bit more frequently?
author: Marc A.

description: Awesome coffee, great staff...tough parking. If not for the latter, I'd give it an easy 5 stars. The food is very tasty, as well. Great place to set up shop for a few hours if you're an independent entrepreneur.
author: shannon a.

description: Love the space and it's nicely out of the way, so perfect for a Sunday morning hot chocolate.
author: Sarah B.

description: OK, so I'm one of those people that gets some of there best work done with music playing ....and sitting next to strangers in crowded cafes. But there's a fine line between too loud, too close, bad wifi, and that perfect hum of music you like playing that's audible but not deafening; sitting companionably side by side to work or hearing every chew and sip of your equally deadline driven stranger/neighbor/workmate and actually ordering crappy coffee or actually something you want  to imbibe so you can enjoy the comfortable couch AND free wifi. Well, Coffee Bar just earned me as a regular today. I've been here before for a fine cappuccino pit-stop on what was, unbeknown to me, a sleepy weekend morning but today was like the office of my dreams. A sea of motivated people meeting, greeting, eating and web-surfing, afternoon Pellegrino, followed by yam soup and a, later still, a nice Pinot to transition and random copies of Art in American from afternoon rewrite session to happy hour chilling. Yeah I parked it for the afternoon when I needed to concentrate and got work done and coddling at the same time. Score! Clean, healthy, adult, light and life-filled. Yes, the owners seem to care.
author: Deborah C.

description: coffee is great (better than starbucks across the street), food is great, ambiance is great, but it's hard to find a seat.
author: David H.

description: Unless most of the other reviewers, I've ONLY been to Coffee Bar for dinner on a Friday night with the Radio Africa kitchen. The hours listed said that they closed at 9pm, but we got there at 9:05 and the very friendly hostess agreed to seat us once a table opened up. The food was a little pricey ($15-$25 main dishes... not very much food), but I guess that's the case with most places in SF. Without knowing anything about Coffee Bar, or Radio Africa nights, our group of 6 was pleasantly surprised with the delicious scallop dish, edamame hummus, and mezze plates. I would go again if I lived nearby. The waiter was very friendly, our water was refilled often, and the wine was tasty. A great atmosphere for a dinner out with friends. Something about it was very fresh but also cozy.
author: S. C.

description: This place has amazing food, cool design, nice staff, but most importantly the best espresso and lattes. These baristas know their business, go in and try it, you will not be disappointed. Plus, on a sunny day you cannot beat their outdoor patio. Sadly, it's a non-talking coffee shop: everyone glued to their [insert apple product here]. Also, food is a bit pricey for the portions.
author: Francisca J.

description: strange that i would be reviewing an elite coffee shop when i'm not even a real fan of coffee. i have been here a few times with friends who seek the java fix. the chai tea is wonderful (thank you for a delicious alternative) and the food is exceptional (fresh and delicious). must try the turkey relish sandwich- party in my mouth! the daily soup specials are always a pleasant alternative when you want something light on a foggy mission afternoon.
author: c k.

description: Espresso drinks are right on, free wifi and comfortable sofa and chair makes a long stay. Don't forget to try Radio Africa dinner nights for a fun food experience.
author: A P.

description: updating to a star power increase for the non-coffee, extra-coffee uniqueness of this place.  plus it's very warm on a rainy late afternoon.
author: Today Y.

description: I've been here 3 times now.  And that is saying a lot because this isn't my neighborhood coffee spot so I need to drive each time.  Parking is really easy though.  I've gone twice for bkfast and once for early dinner wine & snacks.  The atmosphere in the morning is nice - full of natural light.  Great place to have your morning coffee (and it's very good coffee) and use their free internet.  But last night was my favorite experience so far.  We shared a couple of items on the menu (tonno w/ cannellini beans in a tomato sauce and their version of a salami plate) and it was awesome.  Everything was extremely tasty and it was great to be enjoying it all while lounging in one of their couches.  Pretty cool that they can transition from day to evening like that.  The guys working there seemed sincerely interested in how much we were enjoying our food/wine so that is sweet.  I am looking forward to going back on a sunny afternoon and enjoying their patio.
author: Piper B.

description: Coffee Bar is not as good as it gets. Epicenter may just edge it out.
author: Patrick C.

description: cool place, as in you feel hipster cool when you're there. my steel cut oatmeal was cold, which kinda sucked and made me think i shouldn't have ordered it to begin with. my chai made up for the lame oatmeal and was deliciously frothy and not *too* sweet. i think this is a good place to come out on your own since many customers were in their own virtual worlds typing away on their laptops. I'll come back and check it out at night sometime.
author: joolia f.

description: this place is awesome, finally a cafe that is super comfortable to chill out in, has awesome coffee and i am a coffee fanatic, there coffee is good, single origin espresso shots, and the clover machine this coffee is up there with the big dogs like (blue bottle and ritual) but, as much as i love blue bottle coffee (it really is freaking good)  i cant chill there, and ritual is also sweet but man i can never find a place to sit down in plus they dont have food. and now coffee bar one ups them all with get this WINE and BEER. to make coffee bar my new favorite cafe in the city. plus free wifi what more could i ask for
author: roman p.

description: I just spent my first morning there, working away, and I'll definitely be back. It was sunny, the people were friendly, the music was diverse (and appropriate to the crowd), and the coffee was good, even when it got cold.    Nick C's review below pretty much sums up my experience, minus the slow WiFi.
author: Celeste L.

description: went there on saturday with nathan. i had a kenya macchiato -- not bad, not bad. claudia (of the doge) says that their coffee, mr. espresso, is not consistently quality. this may or may not be true, but the single origin macchiato i had was quite tasty indeed. however, looking at the cappuccinos the barista was making, well, let's just say i didn't see very much in the way of leaves.
author: Aron H.

description: Tasty coffee.  Big tables and fairly mellow/quiet music makes for good studying atmosphere.  Oh and the place gets amazing sunlight because of that whole front wall being all windows.  And I had a bite of a friend's apple tart which was delicious.  Only downside was that it got pretty warm and muggy on the upstairs floor but not terribly so.
author: A K.

description: I'm a regular here. It's an awesome place to work, eat, drink. cool space. great staff. owners are honest and friendly. try the cobb salad, almond croissants. keep meaning to try the radio africa dinner...hear it's yummy. i tell my friends about coffeebar...so grateful they exist!
author: Missy D.

description: this place is great--tasty little salads, sandwiches, and snacks--but it falters as a work environment. i mean, it's okay if you have busy work to do. but unfortunately, they blast the radio. and i like music. but radio commercials and random crappy songs you don't want to hear creates a situation that is less that ideal for the worker-on-the-go. still great for the coffee and food, tho!
author: martie j.

description: A comfortable place with decent (if pricey) food, excellent pastries, and decent coffee.  Calm enough vibe to prevent you from too deeply noticing that it's a yuppie study hall.  Nice staff.  A few surprisingly interesting beers rotate through their selection.  I wish they were open a bit later.
author: Matthew H.

description: Despite the clean white modern minimalist feel it's actually quite comfortable in here. It's obvious from the minor design details to the friendly greetings of the staff that the owners really care about this place...nice change from the cafe that was here before. The coffee is dark and a source of pride. Hello food? It's called Coffee Bar but the food and atmosphere is fit for a high-powered business lunch. They are new and receptive to critique because they want to be the best they can...gotta appreciate a business like that!
author: Jasmine d.

description: awesome food! awesome environment. hip people. wireless. kick ass cofffee... what else do you need? get the Clover Coffee... enjoy the ride!
author: Randy S.

description: Coffee Bar is a nice alternative to the less spacious, often more crowded cafes in the mission (Ritual and Four Barrel, I'm looking at you!) if you still want quality coffee and reliably good music while you catch up with friend, read, or study (those signs that say no laptops on this table between 11:30 and 3 are purely decorative, so don't worry about those if you need to get work done, the tables are roomy and there are usually enough plugs to go around).  Tucked into a large industrial space, the windows are huge, so if you have to do work on a weekend, you don't have to feel like a mole person who doesn't get exposed to daylight.  And, the decor is clean and classy- nice array of succulents on the patio, cool light fixtures inside, and if you look long enough at the art above the bar, you'll realize it's a picture of the bus depot, who knew the bus depot could look so classy.  Also, a great spot for brunch on the weekends- they have only three things, but all are delicious, I especially recommend the potato madness because I haven't found another place that has the genius to combine roasted red potatoes, guacamole and egg (and bacon for the meat lovers).  I've always found the staff friendly and relaxed, 'tis a great spot!
author: Jessica W.

description: stopped by for a nightcap...these kids are full of attitude...why? so silly...i was embarrassed for them....top dollar for 2 tablespoons of cheap wine...they should be ashamed, but then, they must be, or they wouldn't overcompensate so much with the tude....sad...avoid his place.... zero stars.
author: M L.

description: very cool, hipster space. friendly staff and customers. lots of outlets and seating, plus free wifi. delicious scones and coffee. pricey, but worth it for the atmosphere and plentiful seating.
author: A S.

description: the staff and owner are snooty.  the coffee is decent.  the food is overpriced and its always very crowded with similarly snooty people sipping decent coffee and paying too much for food.
author: hector b.

description: yep, it is a nice place and the coffee drinks are good.  clean, friendly, and free wi-fi.  better place for locals as the parking in the area is tricky.  music is a little louder than needed.
author: K J.
